 8 Annex 2 Page I IN~DIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Estimation of Project Costs 1. Implementation Schedule. The project implementation phasing for each project agency with the work program phasing for each project agency is detailed in Table I of the respective annexes. The relatively heavy programs during the first three years of the project reflect that a large proportion of the instrumentation and associated works will be procured and installed during that period. During the latter part of the project life, the work program mainly relates to consolidating the institutional strengthening activities and the initial O&M related to the data collection and operation of the data management systems. Most of the computing facilities will be procured early in the project period. 2. Project Cost Estimates are based on information provided by central and state organizations participating in the project. The project costs are summarized by main activity and by project agencies in Table 3 of Annex 1. Expenditures by component/activity and responsible agency are detailed in Table I of this Annex. The cost estimates for each of the national agencies and participating states are detailed in Table 1 of the respective annexes, broken down into surface water and groundwater components and by capital and recurrent costs. 3. Unit Costs. Standard unit costs have been adopted for all appropriate equipment and works items and for their associated recurrent costs. To simplify cost tables, standard packages of equipment and/or works have been used to make up items such as gauging station configurations and equipment ancillaries, current metering sets, reservoir sedimentation equipment, and various computer packages. These standard unit costs and packages are shown in Table 2 of this Annex with some items described in more detail in paras 6 to 9 below. 4. Foreign Exchange Cost. The foreign exchange cost element of the project represents the cost, net of Indian taxes, of goods and services of overseas origin procured directly by the project or purchased from an Indian importer. Indirect foreign exchange costs (the cost of foreign components and materials in Indian made goods) have not been included. 5. Taxes and Duties. Calculation of the weighted tax element of project costs has been based on the following assumptions: (a) staff salaries and allowances, consultants, training, software support 0.0%; computers, peripherals and software - 12.0%; and other equipment, vehicles, materials - 10.0%. The operating costs of computerized data centers assume zero tax and are based on standard computer packages and include software support with hardware maintenance and consumables. For equipment packages with items in more than one of the tax categories, the predominant items are used to determine tax rates. In practice tax rates vary considerably within these categories and from state to state. Thus apart from computers, the cost of imported equipment are based mainly on prices reported in India and these are assumed to include taxes. With the above assumptions, the estimated total of taxes and duties is about US$ 4.0 million. 6. Data Management Systems. The packages of computing equipment to be provided at data centers have been standardized. A full list of computers, software and ancillary equipment to be supplied to each type of data center and other costs are detailed in Sections 2.31 to 2.36 of Table 1 to this Annex. The cost estimates for all computers and software make an allowance of 50% of the original cost in year six of the project to allow for system replacements and upgrades. 7. It is assumed that basic items of equipment, which are currently available in India, are procured locally, and other equipment and software is imported. Imported equipment cost is based on the international price (US/UK retail price), plus 20% for additional handling and shipping, plus taxes. Equipment of Indian origin is priced at local market levels which, for computers, is
 9 Annex 2 Page 2 approximately double the UK price. However, if computers are procured under ICB, then it is likely that Indian manufacturers will be able to obtain additional tax benefits and supply equipment at internationally competitive prices. Computer operating costs include an annual on-site maintenance contract costed at 12.5% of the cost of computers and printers. 8. Computer Software. The cost of specialist hydrological software is based on costs provided by Institute of Hydrology (IOH), UK, and the Delft Hydraulics Laboratory, Holland. In addition a sum is allowed for consumables and stationary and for support from overseas for specialist hydrological software. The latter is based on estimates for IOH. 9. Buildings. A lump sum has been allocated for up-grading buildings for computer centers Types A and B (Rs. 200,000) and C and D (Rs. 100,000). These allowances are not included for the Type D centers installed in laboratories and where the project constructs new buildings that would accommodate the computing equipment. 10. Equipment and Scientific Training Equipment. Standard packages of training and scientific equipment are included for all State surface water and groundwater organizations . A mini-bus for transport of trainees is included for most State surface water organizations. Institutional Support and Strengthening. 11. A substantial amount of the project work program will be carried out departmentally or by force account. Incremental costs to the agencies related to these activities have been estimated in terms of costs for incremental staffing salaries and allowances, O&M of facilities, additional transportation costs and other routine recurrent costs. Generally all incremental institutional costs during the first three years of the project (until March 31, 1999) are related to implementation of the various work programs, training and initial testing the works and equipment installed. Thus. the recurrent and incremental O&M expenditures are assumed to commence in the forth year of the project (i.e., after March 31. 1999). 12. The project generally improves or strengthens the total program of the units in the agencies responsible for implementing the project and thus directly will involve all existing staff. All these agencies have budgetary provisions for existing data collection and processing activities, and for administrative overheads. The incremental recurrent costs to implement and manage the project activities is on average about a third of the present annual recurrent costs in present value tenns. In the first three years of the project, the disbursement percentage against these incremental recurrent costs will be 90 percent. By the beginning of the forth year,most of the implementation activities will be completed and the agencies will mainly undertake routine O&M of the expanded networks and data processing facilities. The incremental O&M costs associated with upgrading and improvement to the existing networks and facilities under the project will, on average, increase the current recurrent O&M budgets by about 35 percent. Thus, the project also support the incremental recurrent costs (mainly O&M of completed works and facilities) on a declining scale as follows: (a) 90% of incremental recurrent costs up to March 31. 1999; (b) 75% up to March 31, 2000, and (c) 50% thereafter under project completion.. 13. Standard packages of office equipment are provided and office operating costs include an allowance for equipment maintenance. Office operating costs are provided for those offices that have been newly established for the project, or substantially improved under the project, and therefore an incremental O&M cost. The numbers of incremental staff and the related costs were primarily obtained from state proposals. The staff numbers and salary and allowance costs are detailed in the project proposals prepared by each of the national agencies and participating state. The costs have been collated and summarized in the Table 1 of the Annex for each project agency .

The following assumptions have also been made to estimate the incremental O&M costs: (a) 3.5% of the capital cost from the year following procurement for maintenance of river gauging stations and equipment, meteorological stations, and groundwater monitoring equipment. (This figure is low since many standard equipment packages include an installation cost and the equipment will all be relatively new during the project period). (b) One percent of capital cost from the year following construction has been included for maintenance of new buildings. (c) An annual operating cost of reservoir survey equipment of 5% of capital cost for maintenance, plus 10% of capital for fuel and consumables. (This equates to about Rs. 0.9 million per equipment package per year). (d) Operating costs of Rs. 60,000 per year for vehicles and Rs. 4,000 per year for motorcycles. (e) An annual maintenance cost of wireless equipment at 5% of capital cost. (f) An annual cost of consumables for water quality laboratories at Rs. 10,000 for level 1, Rs. 50,000 for level II, Rs. 150,000 for level II+, and Rs. 350,000 for level III. (Equipment maintenance for level I is included in this lump sum, while an annual allowance of 5% of equipment costs is included for levels II and M.) (g) 25% of the cost of the laboratory equipment at any level is made in the sixth year of the project to cover any equipment items requiring replacement or major overhaul. 15. Training. The training costs were estimated be generating a unit rate for each training course as summarized Table 1 of Annex 10). These unit rates were then used to calculate the costs for the proposed training programs for each organization participating in the project. 16. CWC and CGWB Training Institutes. The base cost estimates of the CWC (Table 1, Annex 15) of some Rs. 33.0 million for building and some training equipment for their proposed National Water Academy to be established at Pune. Similarly, the base cost estimate for the CGWB (Table 1, Annex 16) includes a lump sum of Rs. 91.0 million for the construction and provision of equipment for the National Institute of Groundwater Research and Training. Both cost estimates are based on detailed proposals prepared by the respective agencies. A provision has been made to fmance some of the operating and staff costs of both Institutes. Physical and Price Contingencies and Deflation. 17. Physical contingencies have been applied to allow for possible variations in the physical quantity and design, and the unit prices assumed for works and goods as follows: 10% of works, equipment and incremental recurrent costs, 5% for training activities, and zero for consultancies and R&D activities. In this respect, the physical contingencies applied to the incremental recurrent costs makes allowance for: (a) variations in the assumed incremental staffing levels; (b) the grades of staff employed; (c) variations due to salary increases over the project period to staff who have successfully completed specialist training; and (d) variations in the unit costs of O&M activities used to generate routine O&M costs for project facilities, works and equipment. Price contingencies of 3.0% in 1994, 1.5% in 1995, 1.8% in 1996, 2.6% in 1997, and 2.5% thereafter were applied to the foreign exchange component. For local costs, price contingencies were added at 10.0% in 1994, 9.0% in 1995, 8.5% in 1996, and 8.0% in 1997, 7.0% in 1998, and 6.0% thereafter. The project costing also take into account the expected changes in the currency equivalent over the project period as follows: 1994 - Rs 31.4/US$; 1995 - 32.3/US$; 1996 - 34.81US$; 1997 - 37.4/US$; 1998 - 39.81US$; 1999 - 42.0/US$; and 2000 - 44.3/US$.

 19 Annex 3 Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Improvements to Surface Water Observation Systems Introduction 1. This annex examines the present status of surface water hydrometry in the NP project area and reviews the current practices for data collection, processing and validation. It then goes on to describe the proposed improvements to the hydrometric networks and data processing systems under the project. The institutional requirements and training needs for improvement of the hydrometric services are described in Annexes 9 and 10 respectively of this report, and more specifically in the Annexes describing the CWC component (Annex 15) and the individual state components (Annexes 20-26). Improved data management and communication systems to be provided by the project are described in Annex 7 of this report. A. Background and Present Situation DeveloRment of Surface Water Observation Systems 2. Since the mid- 19th century, development of surface water in India has been led by the need to create large public sector irrigation schemes to secure and increase food supplies to support the growing population. Planning and design of large river diversion structures, their appurtenant canal systems and irrigation command areas, and any reservoir facilities constructed to support these facilities required knowledge of the hydrological characteristics of the rivers on which they were placed. Thus, surface water measurement sites were located originally for project planning and design purposes, and measurements were often discontinued after this short-term objective had been achieved. Some early network were established on major rivers mainly for flood waming purposes and often observed only the river stages. 3. Historically, the networks were not designed to evaluate the surface water resources of a basin or sub-basin. While water resources were abundant and relatively uncommitted, this lack of total resource information had little consequence. But as levels of surface water development increased and conflicts between riparian states and users in the basins have emerged, the need for such information has grown. Unfortunately, the state river gauging networks generally have not developed to meet the needs of basin water resource evaluation or to support basin water planning and management. Moreover, the common occurrence of shared basins between states, the status of water as a state subject, and the over-riding interest of state agencies in construction of projects have mitigated against basin planning and the development of state stream gauging networks for this purpose. 4. With the creation of the Central Water and Power Commission (CWPC) in 1950, a national organization had a mandate for surface water resource evaluation and management and to provide flood warning services among its other defined duties. In response to these requirements, CWPC and its successor, Central Water Commission (CWC), established an organization for collection and evaluation of surface water data. CWC now operates networks of hydrometric stations on all the major rivers of India. Though the observation sites are generally located with a view to basin
 20 Annex 3 Page 2 resource evaluation, their density is sparse and inadequate for modern needs without complementary data from state networks. 5. The early interest in surface water hydrometry was concerned almost entirely with water quantity. Water quality was determined through limited observations and then only with regard to the project use to which the water would be applied. Sediment loads attracted little interest excepting at the design stage of dams. However, the last twenty years has witnessed a gradual increase in water quality and sediment monitoring in the CWC networks and in some of the state networks. But the information generated is inadequate, particularly with regard to water quality data in respect of present needs for pollution control and environrmental protection. 6. Existing Hydrometric Networks. Within the eight participating states, but excluding the Ganges basin area in Madhya Pradesh and the Narmada basin area in Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra and Gujarat, the CWC operates 235 river gauging stations where stage/discharge observations are made. Water quality observations are made at 131 of the stations and suspended sediments are monitored at 121 of the stations. In the same area, the state surface water agencies operate 776 stage/discharge stations of which only 30 also monitor water quality and 241 monitor sediment loads. A breakdown of networks by state area, operating agency and observations made at the sites is shown by Annex 1, Table 1. 7. Instrumentation and Ancillary Equipment. All stations are provided with a staff gauge for stage measurements and some stations also have float type, autographic water level recorders set in a stilling well. Cup type, and occasionally propeller type current meters, are predominantly used for flow measurements, and timed float measurements are more rarely used except in times of high floods. Arrangements for making current meter measurements vary according to river size and site conditions including bridge set-ups, travelling cableways with boat or cradle arrangements, and independently powered boats for large rivers. Water depth is measured by sounding rods or by echo sounder, as appropriate. Most of the equipment is of Indian origin and of good quality. However, the maintenance of equipment and instruments - particularly current meters and pivot points -needs to be substantially improved. 8. Field Practices and Procedures. The stream gauging stations of CWC and most of the participating states are permanently manned with crews that reflect the type of station and the equipments used. Additional staff are employed during the flood season. Staff gauge observations are made thrice each day during the low flow season and hourly during the monsoon. Measurements of discharge are generally made once each day, excepting on Sundays and official holidays. The area-velocity method is used for measurements of discharge. Velocities are generally measured by cup-type current meters, and depths are measured by echo sounder or by sounding rods, although in some cases pre-monsoon cross sections are used. Widths of river segments are measured by wading for shallow depths, and by segmentation done by the pivot method for larger rivers. 9. In theory, the practices for discharge measurements are set according to the Indian Bureau of Standards (IBS) and methodologies recommended by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) and the United States Geological Survey. In addition, the CWC and some states (Gujarat, Maharashtra) have prepared field manuals based on these procedures. However, inspections have revealed a number of deficiencies in actual field practices due to departures from specified standard procedures. 10. Data Processing. The officer-in-charge at the gauging station - a Junior Engineer or
 21 Annex 3 Page 3 Overseer - has responsibility for recording the raw measurements and the computed discharges according to standard formats. After checking for arithmetic errors, the data is forwarded through Section and Subdivisional offices where it is further scrutinised, and then transmitted to the Divisional office for further checking and finalization. The circle offices of CWC and some state surface water agencies publish year books of discharge data for their observation stations. The quality control procedures related to data collection and verification need to be substantially strengthened. I l. Sediment and Water Ouality Data. Sediment samples are collected and analyzed according to standard procedures. Simple 'Punjab type' sampling equipment is commonly used. 'The samples are analyzed at on-site laboratories which may serve two or three sediment observation stations. So-called Level I chemical laboratories (see Annex 5 for details) are located at river gauging sites where water quality is monitored to measure certain parameters which must be determined within 24 hours, such as pH, electrical conductivity (EC), dissolved oxygen (DO) and biological oxygen demand (BOD). A Level I facility may serve two or three adjacent water quality observation sites. Standard analyses of the common chemical parameters are carried out at divisional laboratories of CWC and in some state agency laboratories. CWC publishes year books of sediment load and water quality data for the observation stations under each of its circle offices. B. Proposed Improvements to Surface Water Observation Systems Upgrading and Expansion of Observation Networks 12. The CWC will not expand its existing network in the participating states of NP (para 6), but it will upgrade the existing stations, where necessary, by providing additional equipments and structures at some stations and/or replacement equipment and structures at other stations. Details of equipment provisions are given in Annex 15. The additional instrumentations include: autographic water level recorders; various types of current meters; digital counters for current meters; and echosounders for depth measurements. The equipments include a variety of cableways and boat sets for current metering. Provisions are made for suspended and bed-load sampling packages, and for upgrading of existing and creation of new sediment sampling laboratories. Improvements to the water quality data collection system will include provision of 75 new Level I laboratories, upgrading of ten divisional laboratories to Level II, the Coimbatore regional laboratory to Level II+ and the Hyderabad regional laboratory to Level III (see Annex 5 for details). 13. The state surface water agency networks will be improved by upgrading existing stations and creation of new stations. The number of stage/discharge measuring stations will increase from 776 to 1201 locations. Sediment load will also be monitored at 386 of the stations and water quality at 211 stations. The distribution of the networks by state area, operating agency and observations made at the station is shown by Annex 1, Table 1. 14. The instruments and ancillary equipments to be provided for the improvements of the state agency networks are of similar types to those listed for CWC (para. 12). Facilities for sediment sampling and analysis and for water quality monitoring will be improved in all the participating states. Details of improvements to the surface water observation systems in the participating states are described in detail in the respective Annexes 20-26. 15. Inventory of Existing Stream Gauging Stations. As noted, both CWC and the states operate gauging stations on the same river systems, and the state stations were not necessarily located to be complementary to the CWC networks. It is known that some state gauging stations
 22 Annex 3 Page 4 are located in close proximity to CWC stations, and thus one or other of the stations may be redundant. In other circumstances, gauging sites are poorly selected for providing accurate measurements. Moreover, the equipment and instrumentation provided may be inappropriate for obtaining good measurements at a specific site and/or mnay require repair or replacement. 16. An important first step before finalizing the programs to upgrade and expand the networks would be for CWC and the surface water agency in each state to jointly inspect the gauging stations and assess: (a) need for obtaining measurements at the locality; (b) appropriateness of the actual site location for obtaining good stream flow measurements; (c) operational status of the installed equipment and replacement/repair requirements; (d) appropriateness of the equipment installed and the need for change or upgrading; (e) procedures followed for obtaining stream flow measurements and recommended improvements; (f) situation regarding existing or future sediment and/or water quality sampling activities at the station; and (g) the quality of the historical record from the station. 17. The inventory of station specific information would detail the infrastructural and measurement procedure related improvements necessary to ensure that stations record reliable data. The review process would also identify redundancies in the existing networks. After completion of the inventory in each state, it would then be possible to properly plan the upgrading of the existing stations and the proposed expansion of the state networks. 18. Selection and Design of New Stream Gauging Stations. The WMO gives broad guidelines for densities of stream gauging network in terms of area of catchment covered per station. It is suggested that there should be one station per 1,000-2,500 km2 in flat regions and one station per 200-1,000 km2 in hilly and mountainous country. In practice, area specific characteristics actually define where gauging stations should be located to properly understand the hydrology of a river system within its basin area. The configuration of the river system and its tributaries, and the need to have measurements at appropriate locations before flows converge are the main determinants that influence network layouts and densities. The need to capture the impact of rainfall distribution patterns on the runoff contributions from various parts of a basin also must be taken into account in defining an optimum stream gauging network. And gauging stations must be reasonably accessible by road. 19. Once the general pattern of the stream gauging network and the approximate locations of the new gauging stations are decided, it then becomes necessary to select the exact site at which the river will be gauged. Site selection considerations include: (a) the stability of the river section; (b) the absence of major distortions of flow at the site; (c) the stability of the water surface at each stage; (d) the foundation conditions on the river bank if a structure is intended; (e) the availability of a bridge from which measurements could be made; and (f) reasonable access to the site for positioning a measuring crew and for supervision of measuring activities. The measuring site geography and river flow conditions will then decide the types of instrumentation and ancillary equipment that will be required for the gauging station. 20. Each state surface water agency will be required to follow the above described sequence of network planning, final site selection and detailed specification of instrumentation and ancillary equipment requirements before undertaking procurement of equipment and works to install new gauging stations. Advice will be available from CWC and the project consultants who will also review final proposals before implementation.
 23 Annex 3 Page 5 Implementation and Supervision of Measurement Procedures 21. Although flow measurement procedures have been well defined and would be appropriate if properly followed, actual field procedures depart from the defined standards. In addition, instruments and ancillary equipments are not maintained according to laid down standards. Such failures result in flow estimates which are of questionable validity. The failures are most apparent and widespread in the majority of the state surface water organizations. They demonstrate lack of discipline and/or expertise in the measuring crews, and this reflects inadequacies of supervision by the professional staff at all levels in the hydrology units. Basic reasons underlying the weaknesses of hydrometry in the state organizations are their structure and professional staffing practices which do not encourage continuity of service and specialization in hydrology. An important project objective will be the creation of free-standing surface water hydrology units which have the mandate to develop and retain specialist cadres of professional staff who can regard hydrology as an attractive career prospect. This question is discussed further in Annex 9 of the SAR. Use of Rating Curves 22. As noted in para. 8 above, CWC makes flow estimates by current metering daily (excepting Sundays and holidays) at all gauging stations where stage/discharge characteristics are monitored. Rating curves derived from stage/discharge relationships are used mainly as a check on the daily measurements and to compute flows from observed stages on Sundays and holidays. The state organizations follow similar practices and some measure flow twice daily. 23. The daily repetition of flow measurements appears to relate to the fact that stage/discharge stations are permanently manned to make current meter measurements. But this frequency of flow measurement is certainly unnecessary at stable observation sites where secure rating curves can be developed, and even fundamentally unstable sites have periods of stability between important flood events. Moreover, taking more measurements does not necessarily result in better measurements, particularly when supervision is slack, and ill-trained and unmotivated crews are employed on repetitious work. An objective of the project will be to encourage development of valid rating curves and their more general use in making daily and more frequent flow estimates. Each gauging station will require special attention to take account of site specific characteristics. Highly trained and supervised current metering crews will be developed and provided with the necessary mobility to serve several gauging stations and making the measurements necessary to develop secure rating curves for their observation sites. The site crews will concentrate on making sufficient stage readings (and/or servicing autographic water level recorders) and carrying out any other monitoring activities for which the station is designated. Thus, more reliance will be placed on using stage/discharge relationships to derive flow estimates. As a result, it is anticipated that the validity of the flow data produced will be enhanced, and some savings in staffing costs for stream flow gauging will ensue.

 24 Annex 4 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Improvement to Groundwater Observation Systems Present Situation 1. The CGWB has established a nation-wide network of observation wells at about 16,000 locations for monitoring groundwater level and groundwater quality changes through time, and about 8,700 of the monitoring sites are in the eight states participating in the project. The State Groundwater Organizations (SGO) of the participating states have developed their own groundwater monitoring networks to provide a total of about 19,500 observation sites. Thus, within the project area of about 1.74 million km2, groundwater observations are being made at around 27,200 locations, giving an average density network of about 62 kM2/site. 2. The observation points are predominantly hand-dug, open wells which are not owned by the agencies - onlv about 6.0% of all observation points are tubewells. With the exception of a few small areas, the networks are designed to monitor the phreatic aquifer systems which provide by far the greatest proportion of the groundwater used for irrigation, which in tum uses more than 90% of the groundwater abstracted. The open well observation points are chosen to be lightly used, to minimize water abstraction effects on the water levels observed. Village drinking water wells form a large proportion of the observation networks. The characteristics of the CGWB and SGO networks in the participating states are shown by Annex 1, Table 1. 3. Water levels in wells are measured manually (using a steel tape or biaxial electric tape), excepting at a very few tubewell locations where autographic water levels records have been installed. Throughout the CGWB network, water levels are measured during fixed ten-day periods in January, May, August and November. SGOs follow individual practices - Tamil Nadu makes monthly measurements; in Andhra Pradesh, observation timings by department staff range from twice a year (pre-monsoon and post-monsoon) in most of the network to bi-monthly or monthly in a few wells; Maharashtra and Madhya Pradesh now make measurements four times a year; Gujarat mainly makes pre- and post-monsoon measurements; and most of Orissa's and Kerala's networks are measured only pre-monsoon. 4. The CGWB and most SGOs sample their networks for water quality at the time of level measurement immediately prior to the monsoon. Gujarat's SGO samples its main network twice a year, and more often in the area of saline water invasion in the Saurashtra. Inadequacies of the Existing Networks 5. LimitationsQLOpen Wells. The use of privately owned, open wells for water level and water quality observations has become an increasing problem. Some now tend to go dry before the end of the dry season (due to water level decline in their vicinities) and others fall into disrepair after being abandoned by their owners. Both situations can cause the loss of all or part of the record at an important observation site. The CGWB has had the intention to gradually replace open well observation sites by purpose-built observation tubewells, but has yet to make significant progress in this respect. Some of the SGOs are adopting this practice on a small scale. The project provides for replacement of key open well observation sites which are becoming problematic by purpose-built tubewells which will be owned by the CGWB or the concerned SGO as appropriate.
 25 Annex 4 Page 2 6. Monitoring of Deeper Aquifers. As noted (para 2), the existing networks were designed mainly for monitoring the shallow aquifers which support most of the irrigation development. This will remain a priority, and provision is made under the project for strengthening these networks as necessary by adding new or replacement shallow observation tubewells. However, deeper aquifers are being increasingly exploited for riral water supplies, municipal supplies and irrigation. In some circumstances, this exploitation is in areas of potential overdraft due to limited resource and/or in fragile hydraulic situations with complex water quality relationships adjacent to the coast. In these situations, networks of properly designed observation wells are required to monitor piezometric relationships and/or water quality changes and relationships in these deeper aquifers. The project makes provision for such network improvements. 7. Inaccuracy and Infrequency of Water Level Measurements. The present practice of relying mainly on manual measurements of water levels in wells can produce data of questionable accuracy for a variety of reasons relating to: the diligence of the observer; the measuring instrument used; and the fact that a privately owned well may have been in use immediately prior to the measurement being made. Of equal importance, the intervals between measurements of levels on the CGWB networks and most of the SGO networks (para 3) result, at best, in a very crude hydrograph and, at worst, in a poor indication of high and low water levels. The provision by the project of agency-owned, purpose-built observation tubewells in the CGWB and SGO networks makes installation of automatic water level recorders a practical proposition at appropriate observation sites where reasonable security can be assured. The project makes provision for instrumentation for such network improvements. 8. Groundwater Qualhity Sampling. The requirements for groundwater level monitoring and for water sampling for quality monitoring in an observation well are opposite. The first requires that the water levels in the well should be undisturbed by abstraction so that the -level measured indicates the piezometric situation in the general area monitored by the observation site. The second requires that the sample taken represents the aquifer water at the location, which means that the water in the well should be turned over by abstraction to avoid taking a sample of water that has stagnated in the well. The use of open wells, which are not owned by the agencies, for monitoring both water levels and water quality carries the risk that either or both requirements may be violated. Proposed Improvements to the Networks 9. The improved CGWB network in the project area would comprise 8,802 observation sites of which 6,298 (72%) would be open wells, and 2,504 (28%) would be observation tubewells, and 1,698 (68%) of the tubewells would be fitted with automatic water level recorders. The state agency networks would comprise a total of 22,290 observation sites of which 16,678 (75%) would be open wells and 5,612 (25%) would be observation tubewells, and 3,787 (67%) of the tubewells would be fitted with water level recorders. Table IB of Annex I shows a summarized breakdown of the above totals by state, agency and type of observation site, and presents the existing situation for comparison. More detailed descriptions of the actual facilities are given for each state in respective Annexes 16 and 20 to 26. 10. Observaton Tubewell Design and Construction. A very large proportion of the purpose-built observation tubewells will be constructed in hard rock to depths of 30-50-m. Some of the balance will be in hard rock to greater depths. The remaining wells will be drilled in alluvial or consolidated sedimentary deposits to a range of depths from 30 to 400 mm. As noted (para 15), when digital water level recorders are to be fitted on the observation wells, the internal diameter of the completed
 26 Annex 4 Page 3 well need be no longer than 100 mm, (smaller diameters could be used if the construction technology is not a constraint) 1. 11. The wells will be drilled at a suitable diameter for completion with 100 m ID PVC tubular materials. In the case of wells intended for monitoring water levels of phreatic aquifers in hard rock systems, the wells could be constructed rapidly and at lowest cost using small down-the-hole-hammer equipment. In most cases. such wells would require casing only in the upper part to prevent caving, and could be completed in open hole below where the rock is competent enough to stand uncased. The observation wells intended to monitor deeper aquifers in hard rock could also be drilled with down-the-hole-hammer equipment, but would require casing to total depth with a slotted section covering the aquifer. Grouting of casing would be limited to ensuring aquifer isolation when essential, and to stabilizing the uppermost section of casing in the drilled hole. 12. The observation tubewells to be installed in alluvial or soft sedimentary deposits will be drilled using rotary drilling rigs with mud tlush. The wells will be lined to total depth with 100 mm ID PVC casing with a slotted section opposite the aquifer to be monitored. In most situations, the development process together with collapse of the overlying cut section will provide adequate isolation of the aquifer, and grouting will be required only to stabilize the uppermost section of casing in the drilled hole. 13. Implementation and Procurement of Observation Tubewells. Installation of the observation tubewell networks for both the SGO and CGWB regional office programs should be completed in the first three years of the project. The size of the programs requires that much of the work may have to be carried out by contracts with private drilling companies. This carries little risk if the work is properly supervised. Moreover, the private companies have the small down-the-hole-hammer rigs which are required for the hard rock well construction which forms the largest part of the programs. The agencies may chose to construct part of the programs, particularly the wells with more difficult designs, using their own drilling rigs. 14. Selection of Automatic Water Level Recorders. An automatic water level recorder (of the Leopold and Stevens type), driven by a clock mechanism and with a float vessel in the well, has been manufactured in India for many years. These instruments are of relatively low cost and robust. However, they have several serious drawbacks, particularly when used on observation tubewells which are intended to be visited only at relatively long intervals (though clocks can be fitted to last three months or more between windings). The float mechanism normally requires a well internal diameter of 150 mm, and even then the float may hang up against the side unless the instrument is perfectly centered. The pens have a tendency to dry up. The charts tend to stretch or shrink with temperature/humidity changes and then wrinkle or otherwise impede the autographic record. And the charts must be interpreted to produce data for entry into the record and transmission to a data bank. 15. Responding to a shift in preference to electronic recording instruments for monitoring water levels, one Indian manufacturer has been marketing a digital pressure transducer type water level recorder for the past several years. Moreover, the SGO of Andhra Pradesh has had satisfactory service from 13 of these instruments (adapted to pump test work) for the past four years. The instrument is battery powered, and a hand-held electronic device is used to transfer recorded data directly from the digitizer to a computer. The battery, which is rechargeable, will keep the instrument operating for much more than one month. The price is somewhat higher than the Leopold and Stevens type recorder, but the pressure transducer level sensor fits very easily into a well of 100 mm I A 100 mm internal diameter casing has been assumed for costing the observation tubewells.
 27 Annex 4 Page 4 diameter or less, and its position is fixed once installed. A second manufacturer has developed a digital instrument with an electronically controlled electric contact sensor, with other characteristics similar to those described above. Moreover, foreign manufacturers of digital instruments have shown interest in establishing agencies with service backup for marketing their products in India, and other Indian electronic device manufacturers are beginning to develop digital water level recorders. Digital instruments are considered preferable to the autographic recorder and will be provided under the project. 16. Selection of Sites for Observation Wells with Water Level Recorders. There will be need for coordination between the CGWB regional offices and the corresponding SGO of any state territory in planning for network improvements to obtain optimum coverage from the combined networks and avoid redundancies. At the more detailed level of actual site selection, the security of the facility from vandalism will be a prime consideration. Provision of guards may not be an affordable solution, except in the case of observation wells clusters (installed to monitor interactions between aquifers at various depths), where several observation wells and their instrumentation would be located within a very small area. Thus, reasonably secure locations, such as a manned climatic station, a police post compound or within the compound of a senior village official, would have to be sought. A compromise may have to be reached in site selection to achieve the essential level of security. The participating states and their corresponding CGWB regional offices are deciding, locating and mapping their combined observation tubewell networks as a pre-project activity. 17. Servicing of Digital Water Level Recorders. The digital water level recorders are powered by heavy duty, long life, rechargeable 1 2V batteries. Though manufacturers may claim that instruments can run for 12 months or more without servicing, this is not a good practice except in exceptional circumstances. Other parts of the electronic instrument may fail, apart from the battery, and a long, important and irretrievable record will be lost if the servicing interval is made too long. On the other hand, costs for servicing become very high if the servicing interval is made too short. A good compromise would be to service the instruments at one to two months interval. Experience will show which is the safest and most appropriate interval in Indian conditions. Servicing staff must carry spare rechargeable batteries and have recharging facilities at their offices. 18. Interval between Digital Level Recordings. Though the instruments are capable of recording levels at very short intervals, the characteristics of groundwater level changes in wells installed for regional monitoring purposes make short interval records unnecessary. Four times daily measurements should normnally suffice. This will reduce energy demand from batteries. 19. Instrument Service Contracts. All electronic instruments are subject to breakdown requiring skilled servicing. It is envisaged that instrument suppliers will be required to provide service contracts as part of the procurement.  29 Annex 5 Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Surface Water and Groundwater Ouality Monitoring Introduction 1. General. Planning of water resource development involves ensuring the availability of water in the required quantity and appropriate quality at the right time for the anticipated use. Biological water quality is particularly important because of potential health problems related to water borne diseases. Drinking water has to meet stringent water quality standards and appropriate water quality is important for agricultural and industrial uses. In addition, the water quality needs for preservation of environmental systems are now of increasing interest. The water quality of some Indian rivers is now deteriorating, due mainly to uncontrolled discharges of chemical wastes from industrial processes and of untreated or partially treated sewage. Groundwater resources are also being subjected to this type of pollution. And artificially imposed changes of flow regimes in surface water and groundwater systems are causing water quality deterioration in coastal regions and elsewhere in India. 2. Water Ouality Monitoring in India. Water quality monitoring has received somewhat limited attention in India. However, it is now recognized that industrialization and urbanization processes and the use of fertilizers and pesticides in agriculture contribute to the deterioration of water resources, and that water quality monitoring must be undertaken seriously to provide a firm basis for development planning and the imposition of remedial measures. 3 . The government agencies involved in the project which have an interest in water quality are: (a) Central Water Commission (CWC); (b) Central Ground Water Board (CGWB); and (c) State Irrigation or Water Resources Departments and State Groundwater Organizations. The CWC and CGWB started basic water quality monitoring some 20 years ago. The CGWB maintains laboratories at each of its 12 regional offices, and CWC maintains chemical laboratories at both divisional and regional levels. Most state surface water agencies have only limited laboratory facilities but State groundwater organizations generally operate several laboratories. Furthermore, State Pollution Control Boards (SPCB), the Health Departments and other government agencies carry out special water quality monitoring programs, always closely related to their specific mandates, such as drinking water supply or the control of industrial effluent. No organization carries out a comprehensive monitoring program on a river basin basis. And there is little coordination between the programs of the agencies at national and state levels. 4. The mandates of the central and state agencies participating in NP with respect to surface water and groundwater quality are not well defined, particularly with respect to surface water. The agencies are interested in water quality mainly with regard to irrigation water supply rather than overall water resources assessment and development planning. Monitoring of surface water quantity and quality rarely has a long-term perspective. Furthermore, these agencies generally have no clear concept of what their precise role in surface water quality monitoring should be in the future, nor do they possess the information and skills to meet the environmental challenges that are known to exist. The Central Pollution Control Board has a mandate for improvement of water quality in streams and wells throughout India but only limited means for its implementation. State Pollution Control Boards generally function as licensing agencies for industries, undertaking water quality monitoring only in streams near major urban areas and industrial belts.
 30 Annex 5 Page 2 5. The planning of future water resources development, the implementation of new water infrastructure and the preservation of the water resources of the state rests with state agencies, and mainly with the state irrigation or water resources departments and state groundwater organizations. To exercise these responsibilities, these agencies must be able to monitor actual conditions and trends in the quality of their increasingly scarce water resources. Therefore water pollution monitoring will be given greater attention under NP than has hitherto been the case, with a focus on data collection for water resources assessment for water resource development planning. Water Ouality Monitoring Requirements 6. Intemational Developments in Water Oualitv Monitoring. Water quality monitoring started in the developed countries some 50 years ago with emphasis on general chemical parameters and dissolved oxygen in surface water. Water pollution with heavy metals (lead, cadmium, arsenic) and other toxic trace elements became a major issue in the late 1960's. This was rapidly followed by increased interest in organic micro-pollutants. Pollution due to use of pesticides and herbicides in agriculture also became a matter for concern. During the 1970's, it became evident that monitoring should not focus only on water, but also on contamination of suspended and bottom sediments, and on accumulation of pollutants in bio-accumulation. In the late 1970's, groundwater pollution was recognized as a major problem, resulting from agricultural chemical inputs or disposal of industrial waste. These developments caused an increase in the number of parameters to be analyzed in each sample. The current trend is to optimize the observation networks to reduce the number of locations and to increase the number of chemical parameters determined for each location. 7. Water Ouality Testing Needs in India. The chemical parameters commonly determined in surface water and groundwater are the ions of calcium, magnesium, sodium, potassium, iron, manganese carbonates, chloride, sulfate and nitrate, together with total dissolved solids, electrical conductivity (EC) and pH. Pollution with toxic metals and organic micro-pollutants has received little attention. Facilities for the chemical analysis of heavy metals and organic micro-pollutants are not available with the project agencies in peninsular India, though some facilities are available at the central laboratory of CGWB at Lucknow. It is intended that routine monitoring be initiated for selected heavy metals and organic micro-pollutants in surface water and groundwater under NP. Attention will also be given to the contamination of suspended solids and bottom sediments, and to the accumulation of pollutants in bio-accumulation. 8. Monitoring Objectives. The common monitoring objectives relate to trend detection, assessment of total loads of contaminants, and testing on compliance of water quality to ceiling levels set for specific functions of water systems. Trend detection is important for establishing policies for pollution control, and to monitor the success of the implementation of such policies. The assessment of total annual loads of contaminants in surface waters is of particular importance for areas where a substantial deposition of contaminated sediments can occur, such as reservoirs, lakes, delta areas and estuaries. Information on loads is often used Dfor the identification of pollution occurrences and for detection of sources of pollution. Ceiling levels specify water quality requirements for specific functions of water systems, such as the suitability of water for irrigation, household use, industrial uses and recreation or to set maximum allowed pollution levels for preser- vation of the environment. Regular monitoring is required to assess the suitability of water in quality terms for various functional uses, and to initiate specific pollution control measures as required. And regular monitoring of surface water is also essential for water bodies at risk from toxic spills, together with clearly defined remedial actions and procedures. 9. Information on water quality is required for a range of purposes, including:
 31 Annex 5 Page 3 (a) water resources assessment and resources development planning; (b) comprehensive assessment of the status of the aquatic environment vis-a-vis prevailing water quality standards and national and international agreements; (c) identification and monitoring of sources and loads of pollutants, and the identification of areas in need of improvement; (d) monitoring of the impacts of regulations and remedial measures for the control of water pollution; (e) assessment of past, present and future effects of significant natural and anthropogenic activities on the aquatic environment,resulting from activities such as dams, diversions, irrigation, and industrial, agricultural and urban developments; (f) planning, design and operation of domestic, industrial and irrigation water supply schemes; (g) maintenance of the requisite quality of water in rivers and lakes for bathing for hygienic, religious and recreational purposes; (h) investigation and control of the discharge of domestic, agricultural and industrial effluents into rivers and aquifers; (i) investigation and control of saline water intrusion in coastal areas, and of salinity problems in irrigated areas; and (j) identification of toxic spills and application of remedial measures. 10. Roles of Central and State Organizations. Responsibilities for water quality monitoring are shared by several central and state organizations. To enable central authorities to formulate nationwide water quality policies and to advise and direct state agencies in these matters, it is necessary that CWC and CGWB maintain monitoring networks which provide an overview of the quality of the nation's waters. Optimization of central agency monitoring networks should focus on minimization of the number of stations, increasing sampling frequencies, and increasing the number of parameters to be analyzed, including heavy metals and organic micro-pollutants. Trend detection is their most important objective. The assessment of total annual loads of specific contaminants in surface waters should become a specific monitoring objective for CWC. The preservation of adequate water quality standards is the responsibility of the States. Both trend detection and testing on compliance of water quality to ceiling levels for specific purposes must, therefore, be part of the mandate of the state agencies participating in NP. Central and state monitoring networks should be optimized to avoid duplication. Due account should be taken of monitoring activities of other state agencies, such as SPCBs. 11. Optimization of Monitoring Networks. The selection of parameters to be monitored, monitoring locations and monitoring frequencies are determined by the monitoring objectives. Trends in certain parameters may occur over large areas, requiring the selection of representative locations for trend detection which can provide information for explaining the observed trend. Correlation analysis is often used to detect redundant locations. Monitoring frequencies are deter- mined by relevant margins (para 13) and the observed variability in time in the measured
 32 Annex 5 Page 4 concentrations. A practical problem is that inter-station correlation's and time variability can only be determined once an abundance of water quality information, both in time and in space, has been collected. Testing of samples for ceiling levels is linked to 'project locations', such as irrigation offtakes, drinking water supply sources and recreational areas. Measurement frequencies are determined by the variability in the parameters to be monitored and the actual use of the waters throughout the year. Thus, the optimization of monitoring networks and frequencies requires in- depth studies which will be undertaken during project implementation. 12. Parameters to be Monitored. In other words, monitoring should be demand driven. 14. Relevant Margin. For each parameter, a relevant margin needs to be defined, which is a measure of the information which is of relevance to the users of the data. The relevant margin has no relation to measurement accuracy or to detection limits. For example, in the event a constituent becomes toxic at a level of 100 mg/I, there may be no need to determine concentrations with an accuracy better than 10 mg/I, even if the detection limit could be 0.01 mg/I. Consequently, relevant margin is a measure of the required accuracy and determines the suitability of specific analysis methods and equipments. It also is a determining factor in the optimization of monitoring networks, including the choice of the monitoring frequency. Laboratories and Equipment 15. Types of Laboratories. Laboratory facilities are graded as Level I, II, II+ and III for project purposes. Level I laboratories are located at surface water flow gauging sites and equipped to measure in-situ certain parameters which need to be determined within 24 hours, such as pH, EC, DO, BOD and TDS. It is assumed that two or three adjacent gauging sites can be covered from one level I laboratory. Level II laboratories are equipped to perform chemical analyses for the basic parameters listed in Table IA. A Level II+ laboratory is a Level II enhanced with an atomic absorption spectrophotometer and a gas chromatograph for the analysis of heavy metals and organic micro-pollutants.  37 Annex 6 Page 1 IMDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Meteoroloeical Activities BackLround 1. Systematic observation of the spatial and temporal variations of meteorological parameters, particularly of rainfall, has a long history in India because these climatic variables impact so broadly on the economy. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) is a central government agency and is organised exclusively to provide the fullest range of meteorological services to the nation. It was established in 1875 and is therefore one of the oldest scientific departments in the country. The administrative or revenue departments were the first agencies at state level to establish rainfall networks and still retain responsibility under law for publication of state rainfall data. The distribution of their networks was in accord with the pattern of administrative headquarters down to district level. Agricultural departments had an obvious interest in historical and current weather information, and established networks of rainfall and climatic stations positioned to suit their specific purposes. And the state irrigation agencies required rainfall and climatic data for developing rainfall-runoff relationships in river basins and for design and operation of irrigation systems, and have commonly supplemented other sources of information with their own networks of rainfall and climatic stations. The CWC has also established a network of rainfall and climatic stations, normally located at manned stream gauging sites. 2. The project will upgrade or repair the existing facilities at rainfall and climatic stations and expand the networks of the surface water irrigation agencies in the participating states and upgrade the existing CWC networks. The IMD will have an important and active function to provide advice and guidance to the operating agencies for selection and siting of the equipment installed at the improved and new observation stations and for operating the networks. This Annex describes the improvements to the meteorological data collection and management systems envisaged under the project. Agency specific information on system improvements for CWC, [MD and for the various state agencies are in the respective annexes. Present Status of Climatic Data Collection 3. Table 1 of this Annex shows the existing meteorological observation networks in the participating states, classified according to operating agency and station type. The table shows that rainfall is observed by one or other agency at a total of about 7,200 stations, while other climatic parameters - typically atmosphere pressure, temperature, humidity, wind direction and speed, evaporation and cloud cover or sunshine hours - are additionally measured at around 640 climatic stations. Most commonly, rainfall stations are equipped with standard daily rain gauges (SRG), but some 1,955 stations have additionally an autographic rain gauge (ARG) with capabilities to measure rainfall duration and intensity within the day. The climatic stations are most commonly manned stations equipped for Penman evaporation calculations. Gujarats Narmada and Water Resources Department has operated five automatic weather stations (AWS) for the past few years, and Orissa's DOI has recently installed three AWSs. Field inspection of a number of CWC and state irrigation agency meteorological observation sites has revealed that improperly located instruments, ill maintained or defunct instruments, and substandard observation procedures are common features. These are reproted to detract from the value of the data recorded.

However, data from only about 4,500 stations are received and processed by IMD at its National Date Centre in Pune, from where computer printouts of daily and monthly rainfall data for periods typically varying from 50 to 100 years (and on other climatic parameters for shorter sequences) can be obtained on a payment basis.  40 Annex 6 Page 4 are replaced. All readings are entered at site in a 'pocket register' and then transferred to permanent registers or prescribed forms. The values from the autographic charts are also tabulated. The data from field stations will be sent to the controlling office (Sub-division) and, after a quality control check, on to the Division where data will be again scrutinized before being processed for computer input. The computerized data will then be forwarded up to the controlling data center. The IMD will train the CWC and state agencies in the processing and storage of data to IMD format and standards. 14. Date Compilation. A project objective is to introduce standardized procedures for data compilation of all meteorological parameters to be collected at project meteorological stations. IMD has prescribed forms for data compilation of the standard parameters. These are to be completed on a daily, weekly, monthly, seasonal and annual basis depending upon the operational requirement. The formats will be made available to CWC and state agencies for processing the data for storage purposes and for supply to users. 15. Quality Control. The basic requirement with respect to quality control is the periodic on- site inspections of observatories to ensure that the instruments are in good working condition,. The exposure conditions should already be to IMD standards when the existing sites are upgraded or remodelled and when new sites are selected. However, the exposure conditions also need to be checked to ensure the foliage growth has not impaired the site. The inspection should ensure that observers are fully conversant with routine quality control work. Entries in the registers/forms would be checked by the supervisory staff to ensure that they are properly made. In addition, field stations would be checked to ensure that they have sufficient stocks of autographic charts, spares, recording stationery, etc. to be operated effectively. Initially, this inspection work would be entrusted to IMD and a procedure would be put in place so that the controlling office takes prompt action on the Inspection Report if any rectification/repair work is needed. Eventually, trained state staff should be able to take over the quality control work with the IMD staff making more infrequent visits. 16. Daa Management Improvements. The meteorological data collected by CWC and the state agencies will be subject to similar management improvement to those intended for hydrological data. Verified basic data will be entered into computer storage at the Subdivisional or Divisional Office in charge of any meteorological observation station, and from there it will be transferred by NICNET or by floppy disk to the concerned data centre (Annex 7). Once entered into the data centre's meteorological data bank, it will become available to all legitimate user agencies, and for exchange or transfer as required between central and state data centres. The data will also be transferred by floppy disk to the state meteorological center of IMD and, after electronic verification at IMD's data center, a copy will be returned to the state meteorological center to be retained in a data base which can be accessed by legitimate users. The improvements effected by the project on the existing meteorological network (para 7 et seq) are intended to improve stations to IMD standards. This should mean that additional stations could be included in the approved list that supplies data to IMD's National Data Centre at Pune where an advanced computerized system for data management is already in place. 17. Training. The IMD is the only organization in India with the resources to undertake a comprehensive range of in-service training in meteorology. Besides training its own employees, it undertakes training of personnel from the Indian Air Force, the Anny and the Navy. The main training center is located in Pune and is recognized as the Regional Training Center for Southeast Asian countries by WMO. This internationally recognized training capability would be used to train project staff (Annex 10).

 45 Annex 7 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Data Management and Communication Systems Background 1. The High Level Technical Committee on Hydrology (HILTECH) was formed by the Government of India (GOI) in 1985 to review the performance of hydrological activities (in the broadest sense) by central and state agencies, to identify deficiencies, and to make recommendation for improvements to recording, processing and management of hydrological data. The report of HILTECH was published in 1987. Among the observations of deficiencies in hydrological practices made by the Committee was the lack of systematic processes for archiving and retrieval of hydrologic data collected by the concerned central and state agencies. This in turn linked to the absence of uniform database management systems for use by the agencies to enhance the efficacy with which data could be exchanged and used. The need for interactive data management systems is highlighted in India's 'National Water Policy' (MOWR, 1987) which states 'the prime requisite for resource planning is a well developed information systemn' and 'there should be free exchange of data among the various agencies.' 2. One important follow-up to the HILTECH report was India's request to the Bank for support for implementation of the Hydrology Project (originally called the National Hydrology Project). During preparation of the project, the importance of using modem, computerized systems for the establishment of interactive data banks for hydrological information in the data collecting agencies was clearly recognised, together with the need to develop appropriate communication systems to enable free and efficient exchange of data between the collecting agencies and easy access to the data bases by all legitimate user agencies. This annex describes the data management systems that will be provided to the central and state data collecting agencies under Part A, while Part B discusses the communication systems by which data will be first assembled in the data banks of the collecting agencies, and then exchanged between data banks, and made available to user agencies. Specific details of the computer hardware and software and other equipment that will be provided to the collecting agencies are discussed in Annexes for the agencies at the national level and the participating states. A. Data Management Systems General 3. The project plans to develop interactive computerized data banks within CWC, CGWB and the state agencies responsible for surface water and groundwater hydrological data collection. Thus, each agency will maintain and have responsibility for a data banking system for the data it collects. This places responsibility for verifying data and maintaining the integrity of the information with the collecting agency. However, all of the participating agencies will use the same computer software programs for data storage to ensure interactivity and compatibility of data bases, and the communication systems provided (Part B of this Annex) will assure the necessary levels of access between data bases. An important protection is that the data bases will be protected to allow 'read only' access to any user of the data. Data Systems Software 4. The project will not be involved in the development of software for data management
 46 Annex 7 Page 2 system. A number of powerful, data management systems of proven efficacy are commercially available. Thus, software with characteristics and capabilities most appropriate to India's medium term needs will be selected. The software will have an open architecture using intemationally available commercial packages without proprietary interfaces. This will allow flexibility in future changes and upgrades without being locked into a single supplier. Any special modifications of the software to meet special requirements in India will be defined, but the applications suppliers will have responsibility for programming the database software configurations according to negotiated agreements. 5. Separate data management systems will handle data on the physical parameters of surface water, groundwater, hydrometeorology, and for water quality data, the last being modified to serve the special needs of surface water and groundwater information respectively. However, the need for using the data storage systems conjunctively must be recognised, and such aspects as the geographic coding systems for data locations in the program must be fully compatible. Groundwater data management is implicitly complex. involving a very wide range of parameters which often must be located three dimensionally. Thus, the groundwater data management system selected should be able to manipulate the numerous parameters stored in a seamless manner for complex hydrogeological analyses such as system modelling. Several surface water and groundwater data management programs exist that use international database systems. The programs that use custom databases will not be acceptable because each change involves a major development that can be done only by the supplier. 6. Applications Software for Hydrological Analysis. The main objective of the creation of water resource data banks with the data collecting agencies is to make basic data readily available to user agencies in an easily applicable format. In many cases, the information required by the user agencies will be the validified rainfall and flow data originally entered into storage in the data banks. However, there will also be a demand for the results of analyzed data - for example, hydrogeological information is commonly disseminated in the form of reports prepared by the data collection agencies which contain the results of data analyses of various complexities. Therefore, the data management system software provided to the agencies will be backed-up by appropriate packages for data analysis. Location of Data Banks 7. As noted (para 3), data banking systems will be established at centers within the CWC, CGWB and the state surface water and groundwater organizations. It is intended that the systems will be interactive hierarchically and laterally to the degree that is necessary for effective exchange of data. The organization within CGWB relates directly to state areas so that matching its data centers below its headquarters with those of the groundwater organizations within the states would present no problems. In contrast, the organization for data collection and management in CWC is based on basin areas, with jurisdictions from Regions through Circles to Divisions transcending state boundaries. With this situation, it is clear that lateral transfer of surface water data between specific state agencies and local CWC offices becomes complicated. Figures 1 and 2 show the surface water and groundwater data flow between locations. 8. CWC Data Centres. A national center for surface water data will be established at CWC headquarters in New Delhi. CWC data centres with appropriate hardware and software, will also be established at the South Central Regional Office in Hyderabad and the Southern Regional Office in Coimbatore. The former controls CWC river gauging stations in basin areas covering the whole or parts, of Orissa, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat and Kamataka, while the latter's jurisdiction is in Tamil Nadu, Kerala and part of Karnataka. As discussed below (para 15), CWC's hierarchy of four Circles and 11 Divisions under the South Central Region and one

Although the data management facilities and the associated communication provisions will not be to the standard of a data center, arrangements will be made for exchange of data as necessary between these offices and the state data centers which have common jurisdictional area. 9. CGWB Data Centers. With CGWB as the apex groundwater organization, a national center for groundwater data will be established at it headquarters in Faridabad. The CGWB will have 13 regional offices after creation of the Madras office for its activities in Tamil Nadu, and seven of these - Bhubaneswar, Hyderabad, Madras, Bangalore, Nagpur, Ahmedabad will service the Board's activities in the seven states participating in NP, and the remaining six in Jaipur, Chandigarh, Lucknow, Calcutta, Guwahati and Trivandrum control activities in state areas or groups of state area out side the strict limits of the project. However, it has been decided to create regional data centers for CGWB data in all thirteen Regional Offices. 10. State Data Centres. Each state will establish data banks for surface water data and for groundwater data, including the respective water quality information. The data centers will be at the headquarters of the state agencies, and in the state capital, excepting in Maharashtra where the banks will be in Pune. This separation of surface water and groundwater information systems will be maintained even when the data collecting agencies are unified within a combined organization in a single department. Essentially duplicate hardware provision, but with appropriate software, are made for state surface water and groundwater banking systems for this purpose (para 18). 1 1. The state data management centers will be located in: Bhubaneswar for Orissa in the Irrigation Department (ID) for surface water and the Rural Development Department (RDD) for groundwater: Hyderabad for Andhra Pradesh in separate agencies within the Department of Irrigation and Command Area Development (DOICAD); Madras for Tamil Nadu in a combined organisation in the newly created Water Resources Department (WRD); Pune for Maharashtra in the ID for surface water and the RDD for groundwater; Ahmedabad for Gujarat in separate surface water and groundwater agencies under the Narmada and Water Resources Department (NWRD); and Bhopal for MP within a combined organisation in the WRD. Data Exchange and Transfer between Data Centres 12. The basic objective for the establishment of interactive data centers in the states and in the regional and headquarters offices of CWC and CGWB is that common pools of data will be created at state and central levels. However, this does not mean that the national data centers with CWC (surface water data) and CGWB (groundwater data) must duplicate storage of the entire state databases. Similarly, it will not,be necessary to duplicate storage of concerned state databases in CWC and CGWB regional office data centers, and vice versa. In fact, with the levels of communication envisaged between data centers (see Part B), interconnected centers become a joint source of data which can be drawn from by either center by file transfer as required. 13. It is envisaged that the CWC and CGWB regional data centers (paras 8 and 9), which each assemble and store their agency's data from within their areas of jurisdiction, will transfer their entire data bases to the respective national data centers on a regular basis. However, the state surface water and groundwater data center will transfer to the CWC and CGWB national data centers, as applicable, only data from agreed selected stations. But the state data centers will maintain up-to-date details of the entire databases that they have in storage, and the catalogues of data will be copied at the national centers. The national centers will be able to access any part of the state databases that they wish to use through the communication system. A downward transfer of data from the national centers to the state centers will also be possible, but lateral exchan-e .t
 48 Annex 7 Page 4 data between the CWC and CGWB regional data centers and the state data centers will be the more normal process (para 14). 14. The CWC regionial data ceniters (and the computer storages at some Circle and Divisional offices) will need to be interactive ftor exchange of data with the state surface water data centers (para 8). A similar arranygemiient will be made for exchange of groundwater data between the concerned CGWB regionial otffice data centers (para 9) and the participating state groundwater data centers. A decision will be made about how much of the databases is actually duplicated in each interacting data center. The data communications system (Part B) will provide great flexibility to transfer information between locations connected to NICNET. Either complete files or selected data can be transfen-ed. Electr-oic mail allows a user to request the transfer of data from a database to another location. At the database, the operator will create a new file with the requested data and will transfer- it to the requestor. The system provides a high level of security and control of the individual database by the agency that ownls it. As use confidence in the communication system increases, duplication of data will become unnecessary because remote access to data is easy. Computer-ization of Data Manageniegnt below Data Centres 15. Initial processing and validationi of suLiface water data begins at the stream gauging stations and continues upwar-ds through the command hierarchy to Divisional or Circle levels in both CWC and the state surtface water oreanlizations. The state groundwater organisation use similar command arrangements down to Subdivisions or sections with areal responsibilities for data collectioll.
