When CGWB unit offices exist in the participating states, they will be provided with appropriate computer hardware and software. And all laboratories of Level II anid above (Annex 5) will be provided with computer facilities. Details of Computing Facilities and Aicillaries 16. Standard packages of computer- hardware and software plus ancillaries have been defined as considered appropriate to meet the requirements of the different levels of data banking and for the offices involved in data collection and processing below the data centers. However, the strict standardization of the packages in part reflects the need for simplification for the purpose of cost estimating, and should not be applied so rigorously that the efficiency of a computing unit could be effected detrimentally. It will be noted that key components - PCs and printers - are duplicated in the smaller computing units, in part to provide backup in case of breakdowns. 17. National Data Center Facilities. The national data centers for surface water at CWC headquarters and for groundwater at CGWB headquarters will require computing facilities to handle information collected from their own national networks, and at least part of the data from the state networks (para 12). Data Communication Systems 22. General. A basic requirement for the establishment of interactive data banking systems in the central and state surface water and groundwater agencies is the provision of sound communication systems for data transfer. And the communication systems should allow unrestricted access between mutually interactive data centers to the degree that is both necessary and practical. 23. Communications in India are rapidly evolving due to changes in the communication laws. Several new data communications services are in the design or early development state. The only service currently available with extensive coverage down to district levels is the NICNET system.
 50 Annex 7 Page 6 The NICNET system, based on satellite communication technology, was established by central govemnment under the National Informatics Centre (NIC) in the last decade to enable rapid transfer of information within the national territory, particularly for government purposes. The NIC service is now very extensive, covering more than 600 locations with a 1.2 Kilobits satellite access (C band system) and 1 1 locations with 2 Megabits access (Ku band system). The NICNET switch in Delhi co-nnects the two systems through two hub earth stations. All file transfers (or messages) go through two satellite hops - one from the originating site to Delhi and then from Delhi to the receiving site. The system does not provide real-time transfer of information. It constitutes a store and forward system where the transfer time is dependant on the amount of data traffic in the queue. 24. Provision of a dedicated NICNET ground station at the data center will eliminate queuing at the receiver end. Computers in separate data centers may be linked through NICNET by modems and telephone. In general, the telephone service within India lacks the security and ease of making a dial-up connection to make this method of communication between data centers a practical proposition over long distances, or even within some of the cities and towns, if unrestricted access between centers is a premium. However, dedicated land lines can be effective and are relatively low cost when used over relatively short distances. Dial-up connections through NICNET can be used for data transfer up to data centerslfrom subordinate offices. 25. Transfer of data by floppy disc, through the postal system or hand-carried, is simple and effective, but accessibility depends on the decision and dedication of the sender. The CWC and the state water surface agencies carry out little or no hydrological research on their own behalf that is not short term and directly project oriented. CGWB and--State Groundwater Agencies. This type of study has been identified as important by several of the participating states, and it is indicated that the work will be carried out by the state surface water organizations. It appears that the complexity of the problem has not been fully appreciated, with the solution requiring an extremely detailed water balance of the selected study area through time. Basin/Sub-Basin Water Resource Evaluations. Such studies may have to be restricted to basin and sub-basin areas encompassed within the bounds of a single state if problems related to inter-state rivalry over surface water data are to be avoided. And the areas chosen for study should not be so large that the data bases become unwieldy. However, the need for such studies is strongly supported by central government and Bank policies on water resource evaluations. Delta areas also present especially complex flow problems, though often with well defined boundary conditions. The studies could be restricted to surface water flows, but inclusion of the underlying-groundwater systems would provide a more complete picture. The studies would almost certainly involve digital modelling. They would best be carried out as a cooperative exercise involving the state agency(s) and a research organization. 14. Organization and Staffing of Hydrological Institutions 2 . Institutional BackgroUIld. Development of surface water resources in India has been dominated since the 1850s by the need to create large public sector irrigatlioni schemes to secure and increase food produictioln to support the gr'owinlg popuilation .Planning anid design of large riverl diversion structures, their appurtenant cianal systems and any supporting reservoir storages, reqLuired knowledge of the hydrological characteristics of the rivers on which they were placed. Thus, hydrological skills were first developed in the state Public Worlks Departments which also had responsibilities for roads and road bridges, flood control and drainage. With the formation of Irrigation Departments in many states (and later Water ResouLrces Depairtmenits), the main responsibility for collection of surface water data was retained with these entities. The Central Water and Power Commission (CWPC) - the forer-unner of the Central Watel Coimiissioni (CWC) within the Ministry of Water Resources (MOWR) - was created in 1953 as the central governiment agency to provide technical advice for direction of central funding support and design clearance to state irrigation and hydropower development projects. And hydrological skills were required within the CWC to carry out its mandate. 3. The massive development of groundwater irrigation by the private sector using motorized pumps, which was initiated in the 1960s, required creation of a strong central agency and of state agencies for oversight of the activity, particularly when large scale institutional credit programs were established to support the development from the beginning of the 1970s. The Central Ground Water Board (CGWB), now under MOWR, was established as the central apex agency for groundwater in 1972, and almost all the states with significant groundwater potential and the need to develop the resource had established SGOs during the period 1970-73. While most of the SGOs were originally established in Departments of Irrigation or Departments of Public Works with irrigation mandates2, the I Until the end of the l9th century, navigation on rivcrs, irrigation canals and single purpose navigation canals was an important use of water resources, but this declined rapidly early in the 20th century. 2 Karnataka was unusual in placing its SGO in the Departrnent of Mines and Geology where it still remains.

The collection of hydrometeorological data, suiface water and groundwater hydrological data, and water quality data in the various river basins of the country is being handled by several central agencies and many state agencies. The responsibilities of the central agencies are well defined and do not materially overlap in the data collection activities. However, at state levels, several agencies are often involved in collecting the same type of data to standards that are defined by their own perceived requirements. This is the situation in the case of hydrometeorological data where state irrigation, agriculture, revenue or administrative departments and command areas development (CAD) authorities may be found operating rainfall and climatic observation networks within the jurisdiction of a state. Similarly, water quality monitoring may be carried out independently by state agencies such as the departments of public health and irrigation, the municipal water supply authorities, the SGOs and the pollution control boards (PCBs). In this situation. collection methodologies vary considerably and there may be no uniformity in the data collected for common parameters. National Institutions 5 . The four organizations at central level with a mandate to monitor hydrological parameters and interpret the data collected are: (i) the CWC with responsibility for surfaze water hydrology; (ii) the CGWB with responsibility for groundwater hydrology; (iii) the India Meteorological Department (IMD) which collects data on all aspects of climate; and (iv) the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) under the Ministry of Environment (MOE) which includes all aspects of pollution under its very broad mandate. The CPCB is a new entity which relatively receoitly started to establish water quality observation networks under its own juiisdiction to support its regulatoty function. 6. Central Water Commission. The CWC. established in 1953. has responsibility for maintaining a network of hydrological gauging stations and rainfalUclimatic stations in the major r iver basins. The Commission has its headquarters in New Delhi and operates through five regional offices under Chief Engineers (CE). It has responsibility for maintaining a network of river gauging stations in all the river basins of India within its broader mandate. State Surface Water Organizations (SWOs). As noted previously, surface water hydrology in the states is vested in organizations with a major responsibility for surface water irrigation which regard hydrological information mainly as an input to design of irrigation schemes and related structures. Thus, river flow observation sites were selected for project specific reasons and were often regarded as temporary. Furthermore, surface water hydrology activities are typically embedded in design units, or, even worse, scattered within the jurisdictions of several circles or CEs with construction and/or O&M as their major responsibilities. Reflecting the above described historical approach to hydrological data collection, hydrology is not treated as a specialist subject. Most state surface water hydrology units are staffed with generalist civil engineers who often are not given specific training in the subject. Postings of professional staff for hydrological duties tend to be temporary. Even when officers have received specialist training in hydrology, there is no certainty that they will be used for this work. And the career structure of professional staff is such that there is not reward for continuity in specialist posts. In the circumstances, it is not surprising that most professional engineers do not place high regard on postings to supervise hydrological field units. Since there are few specialists to set standards, the performance expected from supporting technical staff tends to be low and these staff generally receive inadequate on-the-job training. This is reflected in the quality of the data collection processes and the degree to which data is validated. Surface water quality data collection is at best, afforded only limited importance (and then relating mainly to irrigation water quality) and, at worst, almost entirely ignored. 18. In states where the surface water and groundwater hydrology entities are within the jurisdiction of a single department- -Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh and Tamil Nadu--the SPCCs would be formed within the implementing department and chaired by the Secretary of the controlling department--in most cases, the Irrigation or Water Resources Department. The IMD would have a representative in each SPCC (either from their local regional or state office).  78 Annex 10 Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Training Background 1. The primary objective of the proposed project is to improve the facilities and staff capabilities of the central and state agencies involved in surface water and groundwater hydrology for the collection and management of hydrometric and water quality data and the use of such data for water resources evaluations. The human resource side of this objective would require the development of qualified staff for all hydrological activities from field observers and data processors, through data management experts, to specialists with wide understanding of hydrological data evaluation. The main benefitting agencies will be the CWC, CGWB and the state surface water and groundwater organizations, and the last two will be the recipients of the major part of the training. The NIH will be involved in the preparation of training courses for junior staff, will provide some training supervision for these courses, and will conduct advanced training courses for selected senior professionals from the above central and state agencies. The CWPRS and the IMD will be sources of specialized trainers, in particular for the use of advanced stream gauging and of meteorological observation equipment respectively. Training consultants will be employed in support of the trainilng activities (Annex I 1). 2. The overall staffing structure of CWC allows for development of specialization. Thus. junior professional staff, involved in stream gauging site supervision and hydrometric data processing, can look forward to a career in surface water hydrology. The gauging staff are relatively well trained and supervised. The Commission will therefore be an important source of trainers. The project will also support the establishment of CWC's National Water Academy (NWA) which will have a training function for the project in the longer term (Annex 15). 3'. The CGWB is a professional organization dedicated to groundwater resource exploration, evaluation and development monitoring. It has a long established internal arrangement for training both its own staff and the staff of the state groundwater organizations (SGO) through induction courses for new staff and advanced-courses for upgrading the skills of more experienced staff. The Board is in the process of establishing a National Institute for Groundwater Research and Training (NIGRT) at Raipur, to which the project will provide support (Annex 16). Thus, it is envisaged that CGWB will be an important source of trainers and of training facilities under the project. 4. Providing staff resources to support surface water hydrometry and hydrology in the state agencies will be a major challenge. In all states, professional supervision of observation networks and data processing are undertaken by generalist civil engineers with little or no background in the technology of hydrometry. Similarly, hydrological evaluations often are made by generalists. Moreover, the career structures are such that employment in hydrological units are temporary and there is no reward for specialization. With this situation, the stream gauging teams often are poorly supervised and inadequately trained. And the low status afforded to hydrology results in unpredictable and insufficient funding for what should be a routine task. In addition to provision of training in surface water hydrology, the project would address other institutional strengthening arrangements to improve the organizations (Annex 9). 5. The SGOs of the participating states are generally well organized. They have been able to build up experience in the various tasks to be undertaken, because they employ specialist staff - hydrogeologists, geophysicists, chemists, etc. - with defined career paths within their organizations. Nevertheless, all SGOs would benefit from additional training, particularly in the new technologies to be introduced for network monitoring systems and for data managemenlt.

 86 Annex I I Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Consultant Services Summary 1. Consultants would be employed through the MOWR (see para 12) to assist and advise the project implementation agencies at national, regional and state level. To maintain the project implementation schedule, Government would agree to employ consultant services by March 31, 1996. The services would be as summarized below and as detailed in Part A and B of this Annex. The activities of General Project Support and Assistance in Training Activities are described separately, although it is anticipated that all consultancy work would be undertaken by a single group or association of firms. 2. General Project Assistance. Consultants would be employed to assist MOWR, IMD and the participating state agencies under draft terms of reference given in Part A of this Annex. The consultant services would be some 316 foreign and 1,170 local staff months over about 65 months. 3. Assistance in Training Activities. Consultanis would be employed to assist MOWR, IMD and the participating state agencies in setting up and implementing the training activities under draft terms of reference given in Part B of this Annex. The consultant services would be about 105 foreign and 342 local staff months over a period of about 51 months. 4. General Provisions. For both consultancies the firm, or firms, would provide for positioning and per diem costs of all staff and for administration overheads, including, inter alia, resources for duty visits to the states, printing, postage, communications, equipment rental, office materials and general consumables. The firmns would also provide: office space in New Delhi and elsewhere, as required; for their own transportation, either through purchase of vehicles, or an equivalent per diem transportation allowance, and such office equipment, including computers, that the consultants reasonably require to undertake their duties. Both consultancies would be in place on or about September 30, 1995, and would be employed according to the "Guidelines for the Use of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers and the World Bank as the Executing Agency".. The terms of reference and other documentation for both consultancies would include sufficient information on the project objectives, scope, procedures and criteria to enable short-listed firms to prepare responsive bids. 5. The Consultant Joint Venture. The preferred arrangement would be a joint venture consultant group of international and national firms in which both firms have, inter alia: (a) experience in all aspects of surface water and groundwater hydrology, surface water and groundwater quality, and related hydrometeorological activities; and (b) experience of Indian institutions involved in surface water and groundwater resource monitoring and evaluation. Both foreign and national consultant firms would show evidence that they can mobilize sufficient experienced staff so that an alternate (with equivalent experience) could substitute for, or be rotated with the nominee for each position to ensure continuity in experience. 6. There is strong evidence that none of the established national consultant firms in the water resources sector employ sufficient specialized staff in all aspects of hydrology as full time employees. National firms would therefore have to recruit individual consultants specifically for the proposed consultancy. In this respect, most of the individual national consultants available are
 87 Annex 11 Page 2 likely to be retired senior technocrats with little recent experience in operational hydrology. It may therefore be beneficial to employ the national consultants on an individual basis. Should this approach be necessary, it is recommended that: (a) the foreign consultants be employed (according to ODA's guidelines for the employment of consultants if financed from British technical assistance sources); and (b) once the foreign consultants are in position in India, they would recruit the national team, either through direct negotiations with one or more national consultant firms, or on an individual basis. 7. Another option, to be evaluated by the project authorities, for routine field tasks to be undertaken or supervised by the consultants, would be to staff the consultancy through secondment of experienced mid-career professional officers from the agencies participating in the project. One or two staff with operational experience in hydrology could be selected from each of the participating states and seconded for about a two year period to work directly under the foreign consultants at national and state levels. The seconded staff would generally be senior Assistant Engineer (AE) or equivalent grade, preferably within about three years of seniority for promotion to Executive Engineer (EE) grade. The seconded officer would be given suitable incentives to take up the position with the consultant team including, inter alia, adequate allowances for housing, subsistence, dearness and travel, and possibly one grade increment while on deputation. After a period of about six months working with the project agencies and consultant team at national levels, the seconded staff (who prove to be suitable) would be posted to a state (other than their own state) to assist the consultants' work program. The advantage of this option is that it would solve the problem of recruiting national consultants with operational experience and willing to undertake field work. It would also provide an excellent opportunity for on-the-job training to some of the best staff from the agencies participating in the project. 8. Consultant firms competing for consultancies under Parts A and B of this Annex would produce evidence of their ability to prepare technical and progress reports, and planning and implementation documentation for projects dealing with all aspects of hydrology. They would thus demonstrate, inter alia, their ability to evaluate and produce reports related to: (a) the specific project objectives; (b) project implementation performance and analysis; (c) preparation of action plans and cost estimates; (d) collection and evaluation of surface water, groundwater and other relevant physical resources data; (e) surface water and groundwater chemistry and pollution; and (f) institutional strengthening including administrative, financial and human resource management. Additionally, firms competing for consultancies under Part B of this Annex would produce evidence of their relevant training experience. Credit would be given in the evaluation process to consultant groups with relevant experience in: (a) projects which involved coordination between the types of agencies involved in the proposed project; and (b) similar project activities in India and/or South Asia. Part A. General Project Assistance General 9. The composite team of international and local consultants for Part A would be commissioned by GOI and employed over a period of about 65 months, starting on or about October 1, 1995. The consultancy would entail some 316 foreign and 1,166 local staff months. The international consultant services would consist of long-term technical and managerial assistance with staff resident in India, supplemented by short-term consultants for specialized technical services, as required to effectively implement the project activities. The national consultancy input would also include long-term and short-term specialist services. In addition, the consultants would be required to provide the necessary experienced sub-professional staff to assist in carrying out the services.

The main objective of the consultancy services under Part A would be to provide broad technical and institutional support to the participating agencies and to assist the project authorities to implement the project in accordance with technical criteria, standards, and procedures agreed by the Bank and the Government. The services would be intensive over the first four years of the project period and would gradually diminish thereafter. The main challenge of the consultancy would be to provide adequate resources to assist government during the project start-up period to introduce standard processes and procedures for each project activity. During this period, the consultants would give special assistance to the design of supervision and monitoring procedures to: enable effective management of the project; ensure quality control; and assess project impact. I 1. Additional important tasks of the consultants would be to: (a) assist the project agencies with the general management of the project, including involvement in overall coordination of project implementation, review of annual work programs, and monitoring, evaluation and general reporting of project performance; (b) assist the project agencies with the strengthening of relevant administrative arrangements and reporting procedures; (c) advise the concerned agencies on the processes and procedures for the dissemination of hydrological, geohydrological and water quality information, and for the strengthening of links with user organizations; (d) encourage the coordination between various agencies to: (i) ensure that national and state monitoring networks would be complementary; (ii) establish uniform quality standards and comparability of data; (iii) utilize data of non-participating agencies; (iv) share experiences through workshops and seminars; and (v) enhance utilization of the data; (e) assist the agencies with the rationalization and standardization of groundwater and surface water quality monitoring networks through the development and establishment of methodologies, guidelines and standards for the optimization of networks and monitoring frequencies, and for the selection of measurement methods, chemicaVbiological parameters to be monitored, field/laboratory equipment to be used and analysis procedures to be followed; (f) assist the agencies with the preparation of guidelines and standard methodologies for data processing, general resource assessment (including comprehensive overviews of the water quality in a region), cataloguing data availability, and preparation of a format for the production of surface water, groundwater, and water quality and sediment year books; (g) on the basis of items (e) and (f) above, assist the project agencies in the preparation or updating of manuals for surface water and groundwater monitoring to standardize technical criteria, procedures, and monitoring and evaluation processes for all aspects of hydrological and geohydrological measurements, including water quality and suspended sediment;
 89 Annex 11 Page 4 (h) assist the Project Coordinator to review annual work plans and quantity and cost estimates, and assist in the preparation of annual budgetary requests; (i) assist with the preparation of technical specifications and contract documentation for equipment to be procured under the project and assist, as required, in the procurement process; (j) provide general advice and on-the-job training, as required, to concerned agencies in the installation and/or utilization of advanced monitoring and laboratory equipment, and the introduction throughout the project area of quality control programs relating to all pertinent aspects of hydrometry, hydrology, geohydrology and water quality; (k) cooperate with agencies of GOI to evaluate the performance of innovative hydrological equipment under Indian conditions, such as Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers and GPS systems for reservoir sedimentation surveys; (1) assist with the selection, procurement and installation of the data base system and data processing software for suiface water, groundwater and water quality data, and provide on-the-job training for data input, validation and analysis; (m) develop procedures and processes for the validation of new and historical raw data, and provide support to all participating agencies for the development of validated data bases; (n) assist in the identification of surface and groundwater studies to be taken up in selected basins under R&D studies, and provide advisory support to the institutes taking up such studies; (o) support CWC and CGWB and the State agencies with the establishment of Level 11, Level II+ and Level III laboratories, and with the implementation of pilot pollution monitoring and assessment programs for surface water and groundwater, with due regard to the contamination of suspended solids in surface waters; (p) develop and introduce, with the national R&D institutions, a computational framework for surface water and groundwater quality assessment, as a basis for a better understanding of monitoring results and to provide guidance for the execution of monitoring programs; (q) provide guidance and support to concerned state agencies for implementation of a real-time flood forecasting system for the Brahmani river in Orissa and the Tambraparani river in Tamil Nadu; (r) provide support to CWPRS in the further development of in-house hydrological instrumentation expertise relevant to the project objectives, and to NHP for undertaking project related hydrological R&D and transfer of technology to the participating government agencies; (s) provide institutional support to the CGWB for the establishment of a National Institute for Groundwater Research and Training; (t) provide institutional support to CWC for the establishment of a National Water Academy; and
 90 Annex 11 Page 5 (u) assist the NIH and other project agencies with the preparation of seminars and workshops, including an environmental awareness program, in order to promote a higher visibility of surface water and groundwater hydrology, water quality and their relationship to the environment. With respect to item (n) above, R&D activities may include, inter alia, studies on conjunctive use of groundwater and surface water resources, recharge of groundwater, water balance studies, and basin water resources assessments (Annex 8). Organization of the Consultants 12. The consultancy services would be set up to reflect that the project covers eight states in India (six of which have separate surface water and groundwater hydrology agencies), and five national agencies - CWC, CGWB, NIH, CWPRS and IMD. Thus the consultants will have to advise and assist some 19 separate entities. Given the geographical and institutional spread of the project, it is recommended that the consultancy organization includes a Central Coordinating Team (CCT), consisting of four foreign consultants and up to seven local consultants based in New Delhi. The CCT would work on a daya-to -day basis with the NHP Coordination Secretariat (Attachment 1, Annex 9). The team leader and his associates would collectively have broad experience in surface water and groundwater hydrometry and hydrology, water quality and information management Members of the team would be required to visit the participating states on a regular basis. The local consultants would be designated to particular states and/or central organizations, for regular liaison, coordination, and progress monitoring. 13. State T . Local consultants would be posted in the capital of each participating state to coordinate project activities of the state agencies and the local CWC and CGWB offices. The consultants would have wide experience in the domain of surface water and/or groundwater hydrology and sufficient status and experience to work with senior officials of the concerned state government agencies and with the regional offices of the central agencies. These consultants would include, or be assisted by national staff on position to the consultants from the project agencies (para 7). 14. Short-term Consultants. Short-term consultants would be employed to assist the CCT in undertaking specialized assignments including: (a) preparation of staff manuals to standardize data collection, data processing, resource assessment and quality control procedures; (b) preparation of specifications for specialized monitoring and laboratory equipment; (c) review of the data communication network; (d) assistance in reservoir sedimentation surveys, including use of modern GPS equipment and related processing of measurement data; (e) validation of historical data; (t) monitoring techniques and assessment related to water resource chemistry and pollution; (g) real-time data collection and processing;
 91 Annex 11 Page 6 (h) O&M procedures for hydrological works and equipment (including appropriate manuals); and (i) establishment and start-up of the proposed CWC and the CGWB training academies. These assignments would, so far as possible, be carried out by local consultants. 15. Foreign Consultant Staff.  98 Annex 12 Page I INDIA NATIONAL HYDROLOGY PROJECT Project Supervision and Monitorable Indicators of Development Impact I. This annex describes the project's proposed supervision arrangements (Part A below) and then discusses and presents indicators of Development Impact (Part B). For the latter, a matrix table showing the indicators and assessment methodology for monitoring the project's progress and development impact is attached. A. SUPERVISION ARRANGEMENTS 2. The supervision arrangements for the proposed project would be complex for both Government and the Bank because of the geographical spread, the number of schemes and components, the range of challenges being addressed, and the need to provide project implementation and performance data essential to the supervision process. In this respect, an important function of the consultant services, described in Annex 10, would be to guide and assist Government in project supervision and to strengthen the capabilities of the agencies involved to monitor and evaluate project implementation. However, even with the consultancy input, the project would require above average Bank supervision resources. The recommended supervision requirements are presented in para 5 below. 3. Project supervision will be closely integrated with the project's reporting arrangements and annual review process, as described in chapter V of the main text. The project's review and monitoring tools (main report para 5.04) include: (i) annual Hydrology Institutional Development Reviews (HIDRs); (ii) annual Hydrology Development Workshops (HDWs); (iii) the Annual Project Reviews (APRs); (iv) feedback from Hydrology Data User Groups (HDUGs); (v) meetings and minutes/correspondence of the National Coordination Committee (NCC); (vi) meetings and minutes/correspondence of the State Project Coordination Committees (SPCCs); (vii) the reports of the Hydrology Project consultants; and (viii) Semi-annual reports of the SPCCs and NPC. These reports would form a strong internal management and review structure as part of the project. Supervision objectives would be to foster development of this structure and management process. Successful development of the project management and monitoring system outlined in chapter 5 would not only be an important factor in the project's success and sustainability, but would also reduce the Bank's supervision requirements.
 99 Annex 12 Page 2 4. The supervision arrangements (after the first supervision or "Project Launch" mission - main text para 5.23) would be for the Bank to supervise the project through the resident mission staff with two missions each year. The main mission would be November/December each year and constitute the annual implementation review. It would use results from the HIDRs and the draft APRs as background material. During this mission, appropriate action would be taken to review and amend the annual work program for the following fiscal year (to match the budgetary process). The second mission would take place in about May/June each year. An important task would be to review the budgetary allocations and work program agreed during the main mission. Between the two supervision missions, the day-to-day supervision would be undertaken by NDO staff. The Project Launch mission (Sept/Oct 1995) would require extra staff resources to cover the start-up of the project. In later project years, inputs lower than 18 staff weeks may be feasible (para 3). MONITORABLE INDICATORS OF DEVELOPMENT IMPACT 6 . The monitoring and evaluation (M&E) process and procedures under HP have an important implementation role, since this is the first free-standing Bank/IDA operation of its type in India and elsewhere. It is important that any lessons to be learned as implementation proceeds be used to improve the project design on a continuous process. To enable this process to take place, HP has been formulated as a flexible operation with in-built capability for continuous monitoring, annual reviews and appropriate adjustments. The procedures are illustrated diagrammatically in the Implementation Schedule at Page 7 of this report and in figure I of Annex 9 of this report. 7. The design of the monitoting indicators for the project must take into account that HP is a Iservice' operation. The project concept is to assist the Central Govemment and the participating State water resource agencies in the development of valid, comprehensive, interactive, easily accessed, and user friendly data bases covering all important aspects of the hydrological cycle. A specific design aim is to provide data bases to all legitimate entities involved in management and development of water resources, and the range of information stored and its formatting and accessibility will be designed to meet the requirements of such users. The responsibility for development and archiving of the data bases would reside with organizations which are, to the extent practically possible. institutionally separated froim user agencies.
 100 Annex 12 Page 3 8. Since HP provides only a 'service' to user organizations, the project will not have a direct development impact (see Chapter 6 of the main text) . Instead, all the benefits will be indirect, resulting from savings in capital and recurrent costs through improved planning and design, and through more effective management of water resource investments. This indirect project impact will be assessed as the project proceeds, through the project's reporting mechanism and by obtaining feedback from the Hydrology Data User Groups (organizations in the public and private sectors) to be set up and maintained under the project (Appendix 1, Annex 7). 9. The main monitorable objectives of the project would be to improve the organizational arrangements, technical capabilities and physical facilities available for measurement, validation, collation, analysis, transfer and dissemination of hydrological, hydrometeorological and water quality data, and for basic water resource evaluations within the concerned agencies at Central Government level and in the seven participating states. All these activities will be monitored as the project is implemented and will be continuously evaluated to establish that the data collected meets the needs of the users concerned, both in terms of adequacy and quality (see Tables attached). The methodology for assessment will be the annual reporting requirements under the project and the annual review process. 10. The monitoring of 'development objectives' of HP will depend on monitoring each of the interdependent elements involved in the 'hydrological and hydrometeorological data service' to be provided (i. e., the elements related to data collection, verification, collation and dissemination), since each element has to function effectively if the sole project output - a data service - is to function properly. Since all project activities directly or indirectly involve strengthening of institutions, special attention has been given to the monitoring of the institutional strengthening activities. The project's annual Hydrology Institutional Development Reviews (HIDRs), done by each agency, the annual Hydrology Development Workshops (HDWs), also conducted by each agency, as well as feedback from the Hydrology Data User Groups (HDUGs) will be the principal monitoring tools used to assess institutional strengthening.  106 Annex 13(a) Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Environmental Aspects 1. Introduction. This annex summarizes the findings and recommendations of the appraisal environmental review of the above mentioned Project. Since the project has been assessed as having minimal environmental impact potential, no detailed environmental assessment report has been prepared. Thus, the Bank's classification of the project as a Type C project is valid and justifiable. The project poses minimal environmental risks and considerable indirect benefits. A. General Environmental Issues 2. There no major environmental issues since the project is a service operation and involved only minor works. Thus, the negative environmental impacts of the project would be minimal, infrequent and temporary as the physical infrastructure is individually small and scattered, and does not cause any permanent disturbance. The occasional construction of water gauging stations, meteorological data collection sites, or small buildings would constitute the maximum type of disturbance on the environment envisaged under the proposed project. In most locations, there would be some flexibility in the siting of physical infrastructure to accommodate local needs. 3. The project will generate substantial indirect beneficial effects by providing a reliable and accessible scientific data for future planning and management of surface and groundwater resources; these benefits will far outweigh small and temporary disturbances. 4. A reliable data base will improve the efficiency of water resources development and management. In this respect, poorly designed projects which are not able to function as designed because of inadequate or unpredictable water resources almost always result in a consequential negative environmental impact. 5. Of special importance, the proposed strengthening of the water quality data base would provide substantial environmental and social benefits to a large array of development and preservation/conservation issues which at present cannot be effectively evaluated or managed because of the lack of reliable data. An important objective of the project is to improve the coordination between the users of water quality data, in particular, coordination between the data collection agencies and the pollution control boards at national and state levels. This will be achieved by greatly improved dissemination of data and much easier access to the data bases. 6. Conclusion. There are no pending environmental issues related to the project. All the major issues are indirect and primarily relate to inappropriate development or management of water resources and consequential misuse of the development. It is concluded that a fundamental premise to protect the environment in any water resources development is to base the planning and design on a sound scientific and sufficient data base.

The procurement under the project would be undertaken by the implementing agencies at national and provincial levels, as appropriate. To expedite procurement and promote the standardization of criteria, processes and procedures where possible, Govemment would cause the CWC, CGWB and IMD to set up Project Procurement Committees (PPCs) satisfactory to IDA. The three PPGs would generally be headed by the agency Project coordinator who will represent the agency on the Central Project Coordinating Group. 2. The GOI would maintain the PPCs with terms of reference and membership agreed with IDA. The PPCs would include representatives of the state agencies responsible for implementing work programs as follows; surface water hydrology under CWC; groundwater hydrology programs under CGWB; and hydrometeorological programs under IMD. The first task of the PPCs would be to finalize the procurement implementation plans at national and state levels by implementing agency. Each plan would summarize the project elements, their estimated costs, the proposed methods of procurement, and procurement accounts by years. In this process, the main task would be to then prepare general specifications, where appropriate, to be used in the standardized procurement documentation and agree how the various goods would be packaged. In addition, the PPCs would provide an advisory service to support agencies undertaken procurement at state levels. An important initial action would be to ensure that each agency under the project understands the Bank's procurement procedures and the process when the Bank requires prior review or any other clearance procedure. In this respect, as soon as the PPCs are set up within CWC, CGWB and IMD, it is recommended that short seminars are held in New Delhi to discuss the procurement process and answer any queries that may arise. 3. IDA Procurement Review Process. The procurement documentation would be reviewed and approved by staff from the Procurement Unit, Resident Mission of India (New Delhi). The project Task Manager designated by IDA (based in New Delhi) would be responsible for supervise the procurement process. Project procurement would be based on Bank model procurement documentation (already agreed by GOI and the World Bank and most of the participating states for other Bank supported operations). The specifications for works and goods need to be formulated and standardized by the national lead agencies (i.e., CWC, CGWB and IMD). Where possible, instruments and equipment would be procured to ISI specifications. The procurement documentation for the first two years of project implementation would be approved by the Bank prior to negotiations. The proposed methods of procurement are summarized below. 4.  117 Annex 15 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Central Water Commission Program Background 1. The Central Water Commission (CWC), under the Ministry of Water Resources (MOWR), plays a vital national role in coordinating the development of surface water resources. It oversees all major and medium projects that are primarily planned, designed, and implemented by the individual States.This role acquires added responsibility when a project is located on an inter-State river. Since its formation in 1950, the CWC has become the apex technical organization in the field of water resources planning and development in India. A. Existing Setup for Hydrological Observations and Data Management. Organizational Setup 2. The CWC has a total strength of about 6,500, of which 1,800 are civil engineers and other professionals number about 1,500. The Commission has its head office at Delhi and has five Regional Offices, of which two located at Hyderabad and Coimbatore fall within the HP area. The Chairnan, CWC and ex-officio Secretary to GOI in the MOWR heads the organization. He is assisted by three Members in charge of Design and Research, River Management, Water Planning, and Planning and Progress. 3. The hydrological field organizations of CWC in the HP area fall in the jurisdictions of Chief Engineer (South-Central Region), Hyderabad, who is responsible for the river basins of Godavari, Krishna, Mahanadi, Narmada, Tapi and other smaller rivers in the region and the Chief Engineer (Southern Region), Coimbatore, who is in charge of the Pennar, Cauvery and other southern river basins. The South-Central Region comprises four Circles, 11 Divisions and 42 Sub-divisions, while the Southern Region controls one Circle, three Divisions and nine Subdivisions (Figure 1). At the headquarters of CWC, the Director (River Data Directorate) and the Director (Statistics) look after storage of hydrological data received from the field organizations. Each Circle in the field compiles and publishes a Water Year Book, a Sediment Year Book and a Water Quality Year Book. Existing River Gauging Network 4. CWC has established its own network of hydrometric stations on the major river basins of the country. At present it has about 570 river gauging stations of which 235 are located in the project area with 185 in the South-Central Region and 50 in the Southern Region. The gauging stations are classified according to the parameters measured at the site, which include: stage, discharge, sediment load and water quality. In addition, there are some sites where stage observations are made and /or discharges computed approximately for flood forecasting purposes, and these are not counted as regular gauging sites. CWC also measures rainfall and other meteorological parameters such as wind speed, temperature cloud cover, pan evaporation and humidity at some of the gauging stations. Measurine Procedures 5. The observations of river depths, flow velocity, stage and other basic elements of discharge measurements are recorded by the site-in-charge, who is a Junior Engineer or overseer for important stations, and an experienced observer for other sites. The supporting staff depend on the
 118 Annex 15 Page 2 type of station and equipments used at the site. During monsoon, water levels are recorded every hour (such short-interval data is necessary for flood studies). During the low flow season, stage level observations are taken three times a day. Measurements of discharge are made once a day at 8 a.m. by the area-velocity method in accordance with the standard procedures. No flow measurements are made on Sundays and official holidays. Velocities are generally measured by cup-type current meters which are lowered from boats or from cableways. Depths are measured by echo sounder or sounding rods. Widths of river segments are measured by wading for shallow depths and by segmentation done by the pivot point method for larger widths. When use of boats becomes unsafe, measurements are taken from nearby bridge or computed from slope. Observations are recorded in standard formats. Stage and discharge values are plotted in the field office, and when abnormal deviations are noticed, the computations are re-checked. The past year's rating curves are superimposed to examine if the river bed is changing and to assess the stability of the rating curve. 6. Sediment and Water Quality Sampliny. Sediment samples are collected and analyzed according to standard procedures. CWC carries out sediment analyses from 121 sites in the project area. Water quality sampling commenced at some important sites in the early 1960s. The program was initially undertaken for analysis of water samples covering eight parameters, but in due course, the scope was enlarged to analyze up to 24 parameters. Water quality samples are now taken from 131 gauging stations in the project area at intervals ranging from one to three times each month. There is a Level I laboratory at every water quality observation site and Level II laboratories at the Divisions. 7. Data Processin I and Manaeement. The discharge data collected in the field is arithmetically checked to eliminate computational errors and sent to the Sub-divisional office where the Assistant Engineer carries out scrutiny of the data in accordance with the prescribed guidelines and transmits it to Division. At the Division, the data is again checked and compiled in the specified format for transmittal to the Circle office where the data is finalized. The finalized data is then published in the form of year books. Sediment and water quality data are processed in a similar manner. The water year books are supplied to the concerned States and to CWC headquarters. A beginning has also been made to integrate the data of both the CWC sites and the State sites and publish the combined data in water year books. Computerization of data in the Divisional offices for upward transmittal on floppy disks has been initiated, but most of the data in the Regions is on paper files. The hydro- meteorological data collected at the sites are retained by the Divisional Offices and there is no further processing, except for data incorporated into IMD's archives. The data from all sites is accumulated at the CWC Headquarters in New Delhi where it is stored on computer files. B. Improvements to the Hvdrological Observation System Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure 8. The CWC will not expand the existing observation network, but intends to upgrade the existing stations in the HP area wherever necessary by providing new equipments and structures or by replacing existing equipments. The important provisions under the project are: A. Southem Region (a) 44 autographic water level recorders; (b) three pressure transducer water level recorders and data loggers; (C) three Acoustic Doppicr Current Protilers; (d) 47 propeller type current metcrs with accessorics; I Details of quantities and cost estimates for project inputs are shown by Tablc 1.

(g) 100 digital counters and fish weight sets for current meters; (h) 43 echo sounders; (i) 10 FRP boats, 7 meters long with 40 HP inboard engine; (j) 40 FRP boats, 5.5 meters long without engine; (k) three sets of moving boat equipment; (1) 40 bridge outfits; (m) 40 boat outfits; (n) ten replacement cableway and winch sets; (o) 77 suspended sediment sampling packages; (p) 20 sets of equipment for bed load sampling; (q) 34 sediment analysis laboratories; (r) 20 new sediment analysis laboratories; (s) 10 compressors; and (t) survey equipment packages (71), automatic levels (18) and theodolites (3). The project also provides for construction of 47 residential buildings and 71 equipment stores at river gauging sites. B. South Central Region (a) 40 autographic water level recorders; (b) 40 automatic water level recorders with loggers; (c) ten pressure transducer water level recorders and loggers; (d) 35 propeller type current meters with accessories; (e) 50 cup type current meters and accessories; (f) 20 pigmy current meter sets; (g) 100 digital counters; (h) 30 FRP boats, 7 meters long with 40 HP inboard engine; (i) 22 FRP boats, I meter long with 40 HP engines with trailer; (j) 12 catamaran boats, 12 meters long with twin 50 HP engines; (k) 20 survey equipment packages; (I) 30 sediment sampling packages; (in) establishment of 10 sediment analysis laboratories; and (n) upgrade 50 existing sediment analysis laboratories. The project will also provide 14 buildings for river gauging sites in the South Central Region. Improved Laboratory Facilities 9. The project will provide equipment for one Level Ell laboratory located in Hyderabad, one Level II+ laboratory located in Coimbatore, and ten Level I1 laboratories (at Divisions) and 70 Level I laboratories distributed in the South-Central and Southern Regions. The Level mII, Level II+, and Level II and Level I laboratories will all require new buildings. Details of the equipment to be provided and the analyses to be performed at each type of facility are given in Annex 5. Improvements to the Hydro-meteorological Network 10. The CWC hydro-meteorological network will be upgraded and expanded by the provision and installation of the equipment for: 22 full climatic stations (FCS); 10 standard rain gauges (SRG); and 31 autographic rain gauges (ARG). Provision is also made for spare parts and replacements for the existing instruments in the network. C. Improvements to Data Management and Communication Systems
 120 Annex 15 Page 4 National Surface Water Data Center 11. A national data center for surface water will be established at the CWC Headquarters office in New Delhi. The existing River Data Directorate will operate the center. It will be upgraded with a Chief Engineer at its head. The data center will be provided with a computer package type A comprising: a file server; eight PCs (486dx2); two laser printers; eight dot matrix printers; a plotter (AO colour) a digitizer (AO flatbed); three monitor upgrades and nine UPSs. The software will include: surface water and water quality data systems; a UNIX operating system; a specialized hydrological package; a general purpose package; and a network package. The center will be provided with office furnishings, six air conditioners, a photocopier, a fax machine and a generator. Regional Surface Water Data Centers 12. Data centers will be established at the two Regional Offices of CWC located at Hyderabad and Coimbatore. The data from the hydrological stations and hydromet stations in the respective regions would be transferred up through the divisional and circle hierarchy to the regional data center for storage. Regional data centers will be provided with computer packages type C comprising: two PCs (486dx2), two laser printers, one dot matrix printer, and a plotter, together with two UPSs, an air conditioner, a fax machine, and office furniture. Software provided will include: the surface water and water quality data systems, a hydrological package and a general purpose package. Data Processing Packages for Circles and Divisions 13. The CWC field setup has been organized so that each Circle is in charge of one or more specific river basins which in most cases extend over more than one State2. The Circle Office is responsible for finalization of river flow data of all the hydrological stations under its jurisdiction and also for publishing these data in the form of year books (para 3). To handle these works, the Circle Offices would each be provided with a type D computer package comprising: two PCs (486sx), two dot matrix printers, two UPSs, plus office furniture and an air conditioner, together with software for the surface water and water quality data systems, and a general purpose package. 14. A substantial part of the scrutiny and checking of the hydrological data is carried out at the Divisions which will be supplied with type D computer packages together with surface water data system and general purpose software packages. The Sub-divisions do initial scrutiny of discharge computations submitted from the stream gauging sites. Some of the Subdivisions will therefore be provided with a D type computer package for initial entry of the data into storage according to the surface water data system format. A total of 33 D type computer packages will be supplied of which 13 will be to the Southem Region and 20 to the South Central Region Data Processing Packages for Laboratories 15. The Level m laboratory at Hyderabad will be provided with a type C computer package together with software for the water quality data system and a general purpose package. The three Level II/Level H+ laboratories in the Southem Region and the seven Level II laboratories in the South-Central Region will each be provided with computer package type D and software for the water quality data system and for general purposes. 2 T'he four Circles of the South-Central Region are in charge of the Godavari Basin, the Krishna Basin, the Mahanadi and Eastern rivers basins, and the Narmada, Mahi and Tapi basins and the minor basins of Gujarat, while the Circle of the Southern Region is in charge of the Cauvery and Southem rivers basins.
 121 Annex 15 Page 5 Data Communication Systems 16. The national surface water data center in CWC headquarters at Delhi would be provided with a dedicated NICNET ground station. It is intended that CWC Regional Office data centers and the State surface water data centers will also be linked with the local NICNET groundstation through modems with dedicated telephone land lines. With these systems in place, there will be sound communication systems between the national data centre, the CWC Regional Office data centers and the State data centers. Transfer of data within the CWC hierarchy below the Regional Office will be by dial-up linkage to the local NICNET groundstation or by floppy disk. D. Institutional Strengthening Buildings 17. The office accommodations now available at the Regional Offices, and at Circle, Divisional and Subdivisional levels are insufficient to carry out all the HP activities. Provision has been made for additional accommodation as follows: (a) 400 m2 for each of the two Regional Offices; (b) 400 m2 for each of the five Circle Offices; (c) 500 m2 for each of the ten Divisional Offices; (d) 200 m2 for 30 Subdivisional Offices; (e) 100 m2 for 140 river gauging sites; and (f) five staff quarters. Staffing Provisions 18. It is not proposed to augment the existing staff for hydrological data collection by new appointments. Wherever additional staff are necessary, they will be redeployed from surplus staff elsewhere. However, it may be necessary to make new appointments to obtain the necessary skills to establish the data center and to staff the laboratories. It is estimated that additional staff will have to be obtained by new appointments at a total cost for salaries and allowances of about Rs.21.7 million over the life of the project for the entire CWC operation, averaging about Rs.3.6 million/yr. Vehicles 19. Vehicles would be provided as follows: (a) for CWC Headquarters - two cars; (b) for the South-Central Region - 21 jeeps for field operations, nine jeeps for laboratories, and eight cars for inspection duties; (c) for the Southern Region - nine jeeps and five motor cycles for field operations, three jeeps for laboratories, three cars and two jeep station wagons for inspection duties, and one minibus for training. Training 20. A major component of the training will comprise: (a) training of gauging site staff and supervisory staff in the basic techniques of flow measurement sediment sampling and analysis, and water quality sampling and on-site analysis; (b) training of junior staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized equipment; and (c) training of mid-level professional staff in the use of computers for data processing. Most of this training will be carried out in-house. Provision is made for training of CWC staff in India and abroad through courses in institutions and through study tours. The subjects in which training would be provided include hydrometry, data processing and management, and hydrological analyses. The professional and technical staff in the laboratories will also require training, and provision is made for training in Indian institutions and abroad. The training inputs are shown in detail in Table 1. National Water Academy.
 122 Annex 15 Page 6 21. The MOWR is in the process of establishing a National Water Academy (NWA) with an IDF grant of US$ 365,000 which was approved in late 1992. Setting up of NWA is being supervised by the Central Training Unit of CWC in Pune. The NWA will conduct: (a) in-service training for middle level officers, (b) policy seminars and workshops, and (c) state level training programmes. The NWA would have a direct contribution to attaining the objectives of the HP and therefore, HP would support the operation of the Academy. Allocations are made under the project in support of NWA as follows: building (Rs.33 M); library (Rs.5.0 M); equipment (Rs.5.0 M); and support for operational costs (Rs.1.485 M). E. Procurement Works 22. Apart from the buildings required for the NWA (para 22), all of the building and other CWC works under the CWC component of the project are of small scale and widely scattered. None of the works would attract foreign competition. The works will therefore be implemented either by LCB contracts according to Bank guidelines or by force account, as appropriate. Goonds 23. Implementation of the project will involve procurement of large quantities of specialized hydrometric equipment, some specialized survey and laboratory equipment, and computer hardware and software. These items will be procured centrally by ICB as discussed in para 4.04 of the SAR. The office equipment and furnishings will be procured by LCB or by prudent shopping procedures. The vehicles for the first year will be procured by prudent shopping from the manufacturers according to Government standard rate contracts. Subsequent vehicle procurement will be by ICB or prudent shopping procedures, according to the size of the contract package. Services 24. Consultant services will be procured by Central Government according to Bank guidelines for foreign and local consultants. NIC services will be provided according to negotiated charges and fees arranged by Central Government. All other services will be provided through force account procedures. F. Project Coordination. Monitoring and Evaluation and Review Project Coordination 25. A small Project Coordination Group will be established at CWC Headquarters, reporting to the Chairman. Its function will be to coordinate all project related activities within CWC. The group will also have responsibility for monitoring and evaluation and for the project annual reviews as described below. Monitoring and Evaluation 26. Monitoring and evaluation of CWC activities under the project will be carried out by the Commission's Project Coordination Group (para 25). The exercise will cover both project implementation progress and the performance of the data collection and management systems developed. The results of the monitoring and evaluation will be reported in semi-annual progress reports which will form the basis for the annual implementation reviews (para 27).
 123 Annex 15 Page 7 Project Annual Reviews 27. An annual implementation review of the project will be undertaken under the direction of the Central Project CoordinatingCommittee with the Bank not later than December 31 each year. The review will provide the flexibility required to amend programs of the agencies and states in the following fiscal year to reflect past performance and to incorporate any lessons learned into the future programs. The CWC Coordinating Group will have the responsibility for presentation of information on the Commission's part of the program for the annual review.

 130 Annex 16 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Central Ground Water Board Program Background 1. The Central Ground Water Board (CGWB), under the Ministry of Water Resources (MOWR), is the national apex agency for groundwater resources investigations and evaluations. It was created in 1972 by the amalgamation of the Exploratory Tubewells Organization and a cadre from the Geological Survey of India (GSI) which had been employed on groundwater investigations. The Board has its headquarter at Faridabad, New Delhi. The CGWB plays a vital role at the national level in planning the development of the groundwater resources throughout India. A. Existing Setup for Groundwater Observations and Data Management Organizational Setup 2. The CGWB is subdivided from the apex into two wings - Hydrogeological and Engineering - and all data collection and management fall within the responsibility of the Hydrogeological Wing, the Engineering Wing carrying out the drilling and pump-testing activities. The Hydrogeological Wing has 12 regional offices under Regional Directors (Chart 1), six of which are responsible for the Board's activities in seven participating states in HP-the regional offices of: (i) Bhubaneswar for Orissa; (ii) Hyderabad for Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu; (iii) Nagpur for Maharashtra; (iv) Bhopal for Madhya Pradesh; (vi) Ahmedabad for Gujarat; and (vi) Trivandrum for Kerala. At present, a unit office in Madras, under the Hyderabad regional office, has responsibility for activities in Tamil Nadu, but this unit will be upgraded to a regional office early in the life of the project. The regional offices with jurisdictions outside the participating states are located at Jaipur, Chandigarh, Lucknow, Calcutta and Guwahati. Existing Groundwater Monitoring Network 3. The CGWB's nationwide groundwater level and water quality monitoring network totals about 16,000 observation points of which about 8,700 observation points (54%) are located in the participating states. Some 95% of the total network in the participating states are open hand-dug wells tapping the phreatic aquifer and are not the property of the Board; the remaining observation points are tubewells tapping aquifers at various depths, and most of these were originally constructed for exploration. The entire CGWB network in the participating states is manually measured during fixed ten-day periods, four times each year in January, May, August and November, and samples of water for chemical analysis are taken in May each year from the entire network. In common with all the State groundwater observation networks, a significant proportion of the open wells in the Board's network are failing to provide proper measurements at crucial times because the wells are not being maintained by the owners or go dry due to water level decline towards the end of the dry season. CGWB has the intention of replacing open wells by purpose- built tubewells, but has made little progress in this regard. A breakdown of the CGWB network in the seven participating states by well type is shown by Table I B of Annex 1.
 131 Annex 16 Page 2 Existing Laboratory Facilities 4. The CGWB has a central laboratory located in Lucknow, under an officer of Director grade. It is supposed to be of Level IH grade and provide advanced analytical services relating to chemical and biological pollution to the entire country. In addition, each of the remaining 11 regional offices have laboratory facilities of intended Level II standard. Thus, the Board has seven Level II facilities to serve its activities in the eight participating project states. However, much of the equipment is antiquated or unserviceable, and some of the laboratory buildings are less than adequate for good scientific work. Given the growing importance of the development of groundwater pollution in much of India from both point and non-point sources, the existing laboratory facilities and staff of chemists maintained by CGWB are completely inadequate for the Board to play its proper role in monitoring and evaluation of this development. Data Processing and Management 5. The CGWB headquarters in Faridabad has already started to use a computerized data storage and retrieval system for water level and water quality data. However, the software has very limited capability for data manipulation and processing. Moreover, there is no computerized storage capability for the many other hydrogeological parameters which contribute to understanding of groundwater systems. Similarly, the regional offices of CGWB have acquired computers which are being used for storage of data collected from their groundwater monitoring networks. All the offices use standard software for data management. The NIC system is not generally used for data transfer between the regional offices and CGWB headquarters. B. Improvements to the Groundwater Observation System Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure 6. The improvement to CGWB's groundwater monitoring network will include construction of purpose-built observation tubewells at: (i) existing locations of open well observation sites which are becoming unserviceable; (ii) new sites to monitor the phreatic aquifer systems; and (iii) new sites to monitor deeper confined or semiconfined aquifer systems which are being exploited. A proportion of the purpose-built observation tubewells will be equipped with digital water level recorders. The total CGWB networks in the seven participating states will comprise about 8,800 observation points, the small reduction from the 8,060 locations presently monitored (para 3) retlecting a rationalization of the CGWB network in Karnataka involving a reduction of observation points from 1,226 sites to 635 sites. The improved networks will comprise: (i) 6,298 open well observation points which are manually measured four times each year; (ii) 226 tubewells into the phreatic aquifers which are manually measured four times each year; (iii) 585 tubewells in deeper aquifer which are manually measured four times each year; (iv) 995 tubewells in the phreatic aquifers which are to be equipped with digital water level recorders; and (v) 698 tubewells in deeper aquifers which are to be equipped with digital recorders. Statewise details of observation network improvements are shown by Table 2. Upgrading of Laboratory Facilities 7. The project will upgrade the central laboratory at Lucknow to full Level HI capabilities and the existing I 1 regional laboratories to Level II+ capabilities. In addition, the project will establish a Level 11+ laboratory for the new regional office of CGWB to be established in Madras for operations in Tamil Nadu. Four of the Level 11+ laboratories (Bhubaneswar, Bhopal, Hyderabad and Madras) will be provided with new buildings. Therefore, in respect of laboratory facility I Dctails ol quantities and cost estimates for project inputs are shown by Table 1.
