Details of the equipment to be provided and the analyses to be performed by each type of laboratory facility are discussed in Annex 5. C. Improvements to Data Management and Communication Systems National Groundwater Data Center 8. The national center for groundwater data will be established at the CGWB headquarters in Faridabad and within the Hydrogeological Wing. The data center will be provided with a computer package type A comprising: a file server (RISC work station); eight PCs (486dx2); two laser printers; eight dot matrix printers; a plotter (AO colour); a digitizer (AO flatbed); a scanner; three monitor upgrades; and nine UPSs. The software will include: groundwater and water quality data systems; a UNIX operating system; a specialized hydrogeological package; a general purpose package; a network package; and a WIS multiuser system. The data center will be provided with office furnishings, six air conditioners, a photocopier, a fax machine and a generator. Provision is made for modification of existing buildings to house the data center. Regional Office Groundwater Data Centers 9. The project will assist CGWB to establish data centers in each of the 12 existing regional offices (para 2) and in the new regional office to be established in Madras to oversee the Board's operations in Tamil Nadu. Thus as in the case of laboratory facility improvements (para 7) the upgrading of data management facilities in CGWB will extend beyond the confines of the participating states to have a national impact. The regional office data centers will be provided with computer packages type B comprising: a file server (486dx2, EISA); five PCs (486dx2); two laser printers; five dot matrix printers; a plotter (A3); a digitizer (A3 ) and six UPSs. The software to be provided include: groundwater and water quality data systems; a specialized hydrogeological package; a general purpose package; and a network package. In addition, the data centers will be provided with office furnishings, a fax machine, a photocopier, two air conditioners and a generator. Provision is made for modification of existing building to house the data centers and for a new facility for the Madras regional office (para 16). Data Processing PackaLes for CGWB Unit Offices 10. The CGWB regional offices in Nagpur, Bangalore and Bhopal have unit offices in Pune, Belgaum and Raipur respectively. The unit offices have areas of jurisdiction under their regional offices in which they have responsibility for data collection. To assist in this process, they will be provided with computer packages type D comprising: two PCs (486sx); two dot matrix printers; and two UPSs. The software provided will include the groundwater data system and a general purpose package. Additionally, these data processing setups will be provided with an air conditioner and office furniture. Computer Facilities for Laboratories It. The CGWB central laboratory in Lucknow and the 12 regional office laboratories will have in-house computing capabilities. The central laboratory will be provided with a computer package type C comprising: two PCs (486dx); two laser printers; a graphic plotter (A 3); and two UPSs. The software will include the water quality data system and a general purpose package. In addition, office furnishings and an air conditioner will be provided. The 12 regional laboratories will be provided with computer package type D plus accessories and software for the water quality data system and a general purpose package.
 133 Annex 16 Page 4 Data Communication System 12. The central groundwater data center in Faridabad will be provided with a NICNET dedicated groundstation. As the CGWB regional office for Maharashtra is located in Nagpur while the state groundwater organization (SGO) headquarters is in Pune, it will be necessary to provide the Nagpur office with a NICNET dedicated land line and modem connection so that it can communicate directly with Faridabad and Pune, where the SGO data center will also have a NICNET dedicated land line connection. In all other participating states, the CGWB regional offices and the headquarters of the SGOs are in the same town or city and the corresponding regional data centers and state data centers will be linked through NICNET by dedicated land lines and these facilities will also provide a connection with Faridabad. The regional office data centers in Jaipur, Chandigarh, Lucknow, Calcutta, and Guwahati will communicate with the Faridabad headquarters using the NICNET services available in these cities through dedicated land lines with modems. Transfer of data from unit offices and from laboratories to the respective regional office data centers could be by floppy disc, though the unit offices may use a dial up telephone link to NICNET. D. Institutional Strengthening Staffing Provisions 13. The CGWB has about 650 professional staff - hydrogeologists, hydrologists, geophysicists, chemists, engineers and other scientists - supported by some 3,700 sub- professional and technical staff and about 1,000 administrative and support staff. Given the Board's mandate to explore, evaluate and monitor the development of the nation's groundwater resources, essentially all the professional and technical staff are involved in the development and management of hydrogeological data and information in the broadest sense. 14. Since its establishment in 1972, CGWB has developed a high level of competence in a wide range of hydrogeology-related activities. No major groundwater-related activity under HP would be completely new to the specialized staff. But the scope of some project activities will be much larger than previously experienced. And the organizational arrangements for implementing some activities will involve radical change. For example, maintenance of the digital water level recorders will require dedication of full time staff, while the manual measurement of the remaining observation wells will continue to be implemented by concentrated application of all available staff during 10 day periods, four times each year. While rational redeployment of staff will be used to achieve many of the objectives of HP, some staff increases will be inevitable. Notably, the staffing of the laboratories will have to be increased, experienced computer specialists will be required for the data centers, additional field staff will be required to maintain the digital water level recorders, the additional vehicles will require drivers, and the creation of a Regional Directorate in Madras will involve a major staff increase. However, no basic changes in CGWB's organization are anticipated. It is estimated that the total incremental costs of staff salaries and allowances for implementing CGWB's component of HP will be about Rs.56.1 million, of which about Rs.2.4 million will be for the headquarters, Rs.49.7 million for the regional offices and Rs.4.0 million for the National Training Institute (para 20). Office Buildings and Equipment 15. As noted (paras 9. 10). provisions are made for modification of existing buildings to house the data centers to be created at the Faridabad headquarters and in the regional offices in Bhubaneswar, Hyderabad, Bhopal, Ahmedabad, Bangalore and Nagpur. The project will support the creation of: (a) new regional offices in Madras and Trivandrum through provision of new

Vehicles 16. The project will provide 42 jeeps to be distributed between the CGWB headquarters and the regional offices in the eight participating states for field work and inspection. In addition, a jeep will be provided for each of the 13 laboratories to be supported under the project (para 7). The National Training Institute (para 20) will be provided with one saloon car, two jeeps and two minibuses. The project estimates make provision for the running costs of the vehicles. Details of the distribution of the vehicles are given in Table 1. Training 18. CGWB Staff - Basic Training. The hydrometric observers are all post graduates. Therefore basic training will be restricted to training field staff in the use of digital water level recorders and field monitoring kits. The laboratory technicians will be trained in the use of specialized laboratory equipment and junior professionals in the use of computers for data management. All this training will be provided in the National Training Institute (para 20). Details are shown by Table 1. 12, Sheet 1. 19. CGWB Staff - Advanced Training. The project makes provision for advanced training of selected CGWB staff in hydrogeological and hydrochemical applications through short courses in Indian and foreign institutions and study tours abroad (Table 1.12, Sheet 1). 20. National Trainin2 Institute. The CGWB is presently in the process of establishing a Groundwater Research and Training Institute at Raipur on land provided by GOMP. The activity has Central Govemment sanction. The scope of the training and other activities to be undertaken by the Institute covers a broader reach than the direct objectives of HP. However, special attention will be given to groundwater management, including monitoring procedures and techniques for groundwater quantity and quality indicators, and data base management using computers. The project makes a provision of Rs.91 million for the building and some Rs.17.2 million for equipment and furnishings, and Rs. 1.5 million for vehicles. The Institute will be used to provide groundwater related training to the personnel of both CGWB and the SGOs. Consultancv Services 21. National and international consultants will be employed to assist with project management, to provide specialized technical back-up, and to assist with the project's training programs. As the consultancy inputs serve all participating agencies, they are accounted for separately and described in Annex 10. E. Procurement Works 22. Apart from the buildings for the Training Institute (para 20) and the new regional offices at Madras and Trivandrum (para 16), all of the works under the CGWB component are of small scale and widely distributed. They consist of some small new buildings, modification of existing buildings and the construction of observation tubewells, the last being the most important works components. All buildings will be constructed by LCB contracts. Most of the observation tubewells will be constructed by LCB contracts with local drilling companies, but the wells of the more difficult design may be constructed by force account using CGWB's own drilling equipment.

Implementation of the project will involve procurement of specialized hydrometric equipment such as digital water level recorders, some specialized laboratory equipment, and computer hardware and software. These items will be procured centrally by ICB as described in para 4.04 of the SAR. Office equipment and furnishings will be procured by LCB or by prudent shopping procedures. The vehicles will be procured by prudent shopping from the manufacturers according to Government standard rate contracts in the first year, and in subsequent years by prudent shopping or by ICB procedures, according to the size of the package. Services 24. Consultant services will be procured by Central Government according to Bank guidelines for employment of foreign and local consultants. NIC services will be provided according to negotiated charges and fees arranged by Central Government. All other services will be provided through force account procedures. F. Project Coordination. Monitoring and Evaluation, and Review Project Coordination 25. A small Project Coordination Group will be established at CGWB headquarters, reporting to the Chairrman. Its function will be to coordinate all project related activities within CGWB. The group will also have responsibility for monitoring and evaluation and for project annual reviews as described below. Monitoring and Evaluation 26. Monitoring and evaluation of CGWB activities under the project will be the responsibility of the Project Coordinating Group (para 24). The exercise will involve both monitoring progress with project implementation and the performance of the data collection and management systems developed. The results of the monitoring and evaluation will be reported in semi-annual progress reports which will form the basis for the annual implementation reviews (para 26). Project Annual Reviews 27. An annual implementation review of the project will be undertaken under the direction of the Central Project Coordinating Committee with Bank not later than December 31 each year. The review will provide the flexibility required to amend programs of the agencies and states in the following fiscal year and to incorporate any lessons learned into future programs. The CGWB's own Coordinating Group will have the responsibility for presenting information on the Board's component of the project for the annual review.

 152 Annex 17 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT National Institute of Hydrology I. Backround. The NIH was established at Roorkee in 1978 and is the apex agency in the country for hydrology. Its main objectives are to undertake, promote and coordinate scientific studies in hydrology, to deal with specific regional hydrological problems within India, and to collaborate with other national and international organizations in the field of hydrology. The Institute has facilities in Roorkee for computer systems, remote sensing applications and extension services. It has established regional centers at Belgaum, Jammu, Guwahati, Patna and Kakinada, and a regional center will be established at Sagar in the near future. The NIH currently has some 50 professional staff. A. Existing Roles and Activities 2. Research Activities. The selection of research topics is now often done on the basis of individual experience and preference. The topics chosen do not necessarily address the actual problems or needs of the water sector in India. As a result, NIH is undertaking research in a wide range of hydrological topics, including some for which the need must be very limited. So long as the Institute tries to embrace many fields of hydrology at the same time, it will be difficult to develop sufficient expertise in any of them to introduce the use of these technologies to practical problems in India. Therefore, in order for the NIH to play a role in the HP that meets the project's objectives, it will have to reorient its activities towards providing services that have important practical application. 3. Software Development and Application. and Data Processing. The NIH has already shifted its earlier focus on software development towards software application. However, NIH should D21 have a role in data processing. The responsibility for data processing clearly rests with the staff of the CWC, CGWB, and the concerned state agencies. The primary role of NIH should be in using da for studies, and the studies should be applied research which should be demand led. Thus, the majority of the topics of studies should be identified and suggested by the state water agencies or by the central agencies such as CWC and CGWB. 4. Training. The NIH has conducted training courses for junior professionals and technicians through short-term training courses at state level since 1985. It also carries out workshops at Roorkee on specific aspects of hydrology such as computer applications and introduction of relevant software. 5. Regular Program. The approved program of NIH for 1994-99 includes the following activities: (a) a compre. hensive study of one selected river basin; (b) software development; (c) laboratory and field oriented work; (d) basic research; and (e) activities in conjunction with its Regional Centers. It appears that few of these activities would relate to the objectives of the HP. However, the NIH has indicated readiness and interest in expanding its activities in line with HP to strengthen its role as national agency for applied research in hydrology. B. Proposed Project Activities 6. General. Project support to NIH would focus on institutional strengthening to firmly establish its role in: (a) applied hydrology research for water resources development and management; and (b) carrying out training activities related to hydrometry, hydrology and data management for other central and state water agencies.
 153 Annex 17 Page 2 7. Applied Research. The project would support NIH (and other Indian institutions with the capability of canying out R&D - see Annex 8) in carrying out applied hydrology research activities for central and state agencies on a demand basis. Although NIH has already identified a number of specific study topics, these will have to be reviewed with participating states, together with other proposals that would emerge during project implementation, in order to set priorities. This will require more interaction between NIH and the states and other central agencies than is the case at present. The project would support establishment and/or strengthening of three Regional Offices to provide NIH with the necessary platforms for such actions, while they would also functioning as bases from which the studies could be carried out. The two existing Regional Offices in Belgaum (Karnataka) and Kakinada (Andhra Pradesh), and a new office to be established at Sagar (Madhya Pradesh) would serve this purpose. 8. Some studies have been identified in general terms that may be appropriate to specific areas or projects. They include the following: (a) water balance studies; (b) design storms and flood analysis; (c) reservoir operation studies; (d) flood routing studies; (e) regional hydrology studies; (f) conjunctive water use studies; and (g) evaluation of actual performance of water projects against set standards. 9. Training of Trainers for State Agencies. NIH has already developed a capability for training which would be strengthened and expanded to serve important training objectives of the project as described in Annex 11 and summarized below. Within the state agencies, there is need for training: (a) to improve data processing procedures; and (b) to develop skills in the use of computers and software for water data management. Though much of this training would be an in-house activity of the state agencies either through special courses or on-the-job training, there would be a necessity for training of trainers who would be selected from state agency staff. A major responsibility of NIH would be to provide for training of trainers in some of the required skills through short courses run at Roorkee or in state training facilities such as WALMIs. NIH and the training consultants would also advise the states on the content of the training courses which would be subsequently run in- house by the state agencies using WALMI facilities. It should be noted that CGWB is in the process of establishing a National Groundwater Research and Training Institute at Raipur (Annex 16) which will provide training for state groundwater organization staff in at least some of the groundwater related skills required by the project. Similarly, CWC is establishing a National Water Academy at Pune (Annex 15). The activities of these training institutions will have to be properly accommodated within NIH's training plans for support of HP. 10. Specialized Training for State Agency Senior Staff. Senior professional staff of state surface water and groundwater agencies will require training in advanced hydrological and hydrogeological analysis techniques, including digital modelling using computers. The project will support the provision by NIH of such training through courses of appropriate content and duration to be run using facilities at Roorkee. 11. Training f.QLNIH Staff. A provision is made under the project for training two selected staff of NIH in advanced hydrological/hydrogeological procedures in foreign institutions and the project will also finance five study tours abroad for selected NIH staff. Details of Project Inputs (Table 1) 12. Computing Facilities. The NIH Headquarters in Roorkee will be provided with a computer package type C comprising: two PCs (486 dx), two laser printers, a graphic plotter and two UPSs, plus a photocopier, fax machine, air conditioner and office furniture. The standard software for this package (surface water, groundwater and water quality data systems, a specialized hydrological package and a general purpose package) will be enhanced by additional specialized software and technical literature. The regional offices of NIH in Belgaum, Kakinada and Sagar will each be provided with computer package type D comprising: two PCs (486 sx), two dot matrix printers, and two UPSs, plus air conditioners and office furniture, together with data systems software and
 154 Annex 17 Page 3 general purpose software. In addition, NIH headquarters will be provided with a computer package type D specifically for training activities. The cost estimates for NIH activities includes an allowance for recurrent costs for running the computers and ancillary equipment. The capital cost of the computing facilities and software is about Rs.9.7 million. 13. Instruments. A lump sum allocation of Rs. 1.0 million is made for purchase of specialized hydrological instruments and equipment for testing by NIH staff under field conditions and/or use in training activities. 14. Research and Development. As noted (paras 7 and 8), a fund would be established under the project to finance selected applied research studies which could be implemented by NIH (or other qualified R&D agencies) on behalf of state agencies or central agencies. The lump sum allocation for this component is Rs. 15 million. 15. Strengthening/Establishment of Regional Offices. The project makes provision for furnishing for regional offices in Belgaum, Kakinada and Sagar (in addition to the computing facilities described under para 13) at an estimated cost of Rs. 0.6 million, and for renting the office buildings at an estimated cost of Rs. 200,000/building/year. 16. Training of Trainers. As noted under para 10, NIH will be responsible for training of trainers for state agencies and providing advanced training for senior staff. The project cost estimates provide: a lump sum allocation of Rs.0.85 million for procurement of training material (additional to the computer package for training mentioned under para 13); an allocation of Rs. 2.8 million for preparation of training materials by NIH staff; and an allowance of about Rs. 8.8 million for NIH's other costs for running the training courses, workshops and seminars. 17. Training of NIH Staff. Provision is made under the project for training of NIH staff overseas at a total cost of about Rs. 1.4 million. 18. Vehicles. The rental costs of vehicles used on HP activities is covered in the project cost estimates by an allocation of Rs.2.4 million. 20. Buildings. The rental costs for Regional Office buildings are covered by an allocation of Rs.2.8 million. 21. Incremental Staff. The project will finance the cost of incremental staff employed by NIH for HP activities from an allocation of Rs. 2.38 million. C. Procurement 22. General. The procurement arrangements for the project are described in paras 4.03-4.07 and detailed in Annex 13b. All procurement would follow the standard procurement documentation approved by the World Bank for works, goods and services. 23. Goods. Implementation of the NIH component under the project will involve procurement of: (a) computer hardware and software; (b) office equipment and furnishings; (c) specialized instruments for testing; and (d) training materials. The computer hardware and software will be procured by ICB procedures as described in para 4.04 of the SAR. The office furnishings and equipment will be procured by LCB procedures or by prudent shopping, as appropriate. The specialized instruments and training materials will be procured by direct purchase from the manufacturers or through their official agents in India. 24. Services. All services required for project implementation by NIH will be provided by force account procedures.

A small Project (R&D) Coordination Group will be established in NIH, reporting to the Director of the Institute. The results of the monitoring and evaluation will be reported semi-annually and form the basis for the annual implementation reviews (para 27). 26. Project Annual Reviews. An annual implementation review of the project will be undertakenunder the direction of the Central Project Coordinating Committee (SAR, para 5.19) with the Bank not later than December 31 each year (SAR, para 5.33).  158 Annex 18 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Central Water and Power Research Station Program Background 1. The Central Water and Power Station (CWPRS) established in 1916 and located in Pune, is an autonomous agency under the Ministry of Water Resources (MOWR). It provides hydrological services in the fields of irrigation, hydropower and water transport. The Instrumentation Division of CWPRS was assisted in its activities by two UNDP supported projects - Development of Hydraulic Instrumentation and Hydraulic Instrumentation Center - during 1972 to 1984. The projects provided training of engineers and scientists through fellowships abroad and by visits of consultants in hydrometry. The projects also provided support for buildings and for procurement of equipment. 2. CWPRS carries out current meter calibration as a routine activity for some states but the ancillary equipments and facilities to back-up the basic facility are lacking. Moreover, only minor repairs can be carried out, no spare parts are held in stock, and the tum-round time for calibrating instruments is too long. Hydrological R&D studies have also been carried out by the agency for some states. Apart from these activities, the links between CWPRS and the state hydrology agencies are weak. CWPRS Activities under the Project 3. Current Meter Calibration. CWPRS will continue to provide services for current meter calibration to some of the participating states. The basic facilities available are very good, but the supporting workshop equipment requires serious upgrading. 4. Inspection of River Gauging Sites. The services of an inspection team from CWC and CWPRS will be required by all the participating states for the establishment and operation of river gauging stations. The CWPRS representative on the inspection team will mainly advise on the selection of gauging equipment and on its subsequent operation and maintenance. 5. Selection and Evaluation of Advanced River GaugingEquiprent. Some states plan to introduce the use of advanced types of river gauging equipment under HP. Examples are the acoustic doppler current profiler set proposed for Karnataka and the pressure transducer and logger type water level recorders proposed for Karnataka and Orissa. In order to benefit from CWPRS experience with such equipment at the research station, CWPRS would be involved in the installation and initial operation of the equipment. CWPRS would evaluate the suitability of the new equipment in a report describing its performance as compared with more traditional technology. The report would consider the practical implications of introducing the equipment, including the staff requirements for operation and maintenance, the capital and recurrent costs, and procedures required for data processing and for quality control of data recorded. 6. Training. CWPRS could contribute instructors to the 'Training of Trainers" courses at NIH and state agency courses for field staff and junior supervisors at the WALMIs (see Annex 11). The main subjects of CWPRS instructors would be the use and maintenance of standard equipment for water level, stream flow and sediment transport observations.

The CWPRS is staffed and equipped to carry out demand- driven applied research in many aspects of surface water and groundwater hydrology on behalf of the participating states. The agency will therefore be able to participate in the R&D program that will develop as the project proceeds, with the conditions that: (a) their assistance is requested by a state agency; and (b) the proposed R&D study is cleared by the R&D Evaluation Committee for funding from the lump sum allocation for R&D under the project budget (see Annex 8). The instruments include: several types of current metering packages of foreign and local origin, with propeller and cup type meters; an electromagnetic current meter set; four optical shaft encoder water level sensors; six pressure type water level sensors; and two pneumatic type water level sensors. The estimated cost of this package of instruments is about Rs.2.3 million. 9. Reserch and Development. The project provides a lump sum allocation of Rs.5.0 million to CWPRS to carry out practical research on hydrological instrumentation on behalf of HP. CWPRS may also participate in more general R&D activities on behalf of state agencies (para 7). 10. Training of CWPRS Professional Staff. A small training input for study tours abroad is provided under the project at an estimated cost of some Rs.0.63 million. 11. Vehicles. The project will provide one saloon car and one jeep for the use of CWPRS in HP activities at an estimated cost of Rs.550,000. 12. Travelling Expenses. A lump sum allocation of Rs. 1.0 million is made in the project costs to cover the travelling expenses in India of CWPRS staff on HP activities.

 161. Annex 19 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT India Meteorological Department Program Background 1. The India Meteorological Department (IMD), under the Ministry of Science and Technology, is the central government organization that deals with all aspects of meteorology. Established in 1875 as a scientific department, it is organized primarily to provide a meteorological service to the nation. The department obtains its rainfall and general climatic data from its own network or from approved stations managed by other government agencies. It operates coastal radars for detection of cyclones, radars for detection of thunderstorms, and makes upper air observations and air pollution measurements. IMD caters to the needs of a large number of interests, notably the requirements of aviation, shipping, agriculture and irrigation, flood forecasting and large reservoir operations. Special importance is given to rainfall measurements and data from around 5,000 observation sites are stored at the department's computerized National Data Center at Pune. The department has developed training capabilities in all aspects of meteorology, and it training center at Pune is approved by WMO as the regional training center for South Asian countries. Organizational Set-up 2. With headquarters in New Delhi and a technical center in Pune, IMD operates through five regional meteorological centers located in New Delhi, Calcutta, Bombay, Madras and Nagpur. It has meteorological centers in every state. As noted above (para 1), its data management center and main training facilities are located at Pune. Training units are also located in New Delhi, Calcutta and Madras to provide basic training to junior staff. IMD Participation in HP 3. The IMD sets standards for all meteorological activities in India and, in general, carries out its scientific work according to procedures recommended by WMO. The department manufactures all commonly used meteorological equipments for its own use and can be a supplier to other government agencies. Moreover, IMD, together with the Bureau of Indian Standards, has set specifications for all instruments, under which local manufacturers can market their products, and IMD will individually calibrate and certificate the instruments produced by manufacturers for a fee. In addition, it has standardized specification for site selection and civil works for meteorological stations, and has established procedures and formats for data collection and processing. The department has an internationally accepted training establishment (para 1). With this background and these attributes, IMD will actively participate in the implementation of HP as the primary advisor on all technical matters relating to the meteorological program (Annex 6), will establish computerized data centers at its Regional Meteorological Centers in Nagpur, Calcutta, Bombay, Madras and the state meteorological centers in Ahmedabad, Bhubaneswar, Trivandrum, Hyderabad, Bangalore and Bhopal (Annex 7). It will also contribute in its expertise in the training program (Annex 10), as discussed in para. 9 of this Annex. The base costs of the IMD program is estimated at about Rs. 181.6 million detailed in Table I of this Annex. 4. Project Coordination. A project coordination unit will be established under an Additional
 162 Annex 19 Page 2 Director General (ADG) in the New Delhi regional office building. The project will provide office furnishing and equipment for this unit The unit will function exclusively to coordinate IMD's program under HP with other central agencies and concemed state agencies. 5. Inventory and Review of Existing Meteorological Networks. Before final decisions are made on upgrading and expanding existing meteorological networks, it will be necessary to inventory the CWC and state surface water agency networks in the participating states to identify site and instrumentation defects, and to assess the effectiveness of the measurement and record keeping procedures at the stations. This will be followed by a review of the entire state meteorological networks to determine any network modifications or additions required to obtain optimum coverage for reliable meteorological analysis. These activities will be carried out by the concerned state/central hydrological agencies with the assistance and guidance of experienced officers from IMD, and supported by the implementation consultants to be employed under the project. 6. Site Selection. Design and Instrumentalion. As noted (para 5), IMD will be involved in the network inventory which will identify site and instrumentation defects and propose measures for improvements. In all respects, observation stations will be upgraded to meet IMD standards. The actual location of proposed new stations will be subject to IMD approval, and the civil works and instrumentation will be to IMD standards. Thus, experienced IMD officers (or national consultants employed by IMD) will function as advisors for this part of the work. 7. Operations Inspections for Oualitv Control. The quality of the data collected at meteorological observation sites is finally dependant on the performance of the site operators in equipment maintenance and observation procedures. In addition, site exposure conditions must also be maintained. In order to ensure that the above conditions are achieved, a regular process of site inspections will be established. IMD officers will assist the agencies in setting up the inspection processes and will actively participate in the inspections during the project. 8. Establishment of RegionaVSub-Regional Data Centers in IMD. At present, IMD's National Data Center at Pune is the only place that meteorological data users can access the department's data base. An important project initiative will be to establish computerized data banks for meteorological data in Bombay, Calcutta, Madras, Nagpur, Ahmedabad, Bhubaneswar, Bhopal, Hyderabad, Bangalore and Trivandrum. These data centers will function for initial verification and entry into computer storage of meteorological data from the IMD stations, and also as entry points into the data base for user agencies. The data from the state hydrometeorological observation networks will first be stored in the state surface water data banks, and will then be copied by floppy disk to the meteorological center of IMD in the state capital. The data will be transferred to IMD's National Data Center (pune) for final verification and then retumed to the state center for archiving. The Pune data center will be provided with a computer package type as specified in Section 2.31 of Table 2, Annex 2. The data centers at IMD's regional and state meteorological centers (para 3) will be provided with computer packages type B and Type C respectively (detailed in Section 2.32 and 2.33 of Table 2, Annex 2). All IMD data centers will be provided with software for the meteorological data system and for general purposes. The data will be transferred to IMD's National Data Center by floppy disk. The software will include: the hydromet data system, a UNIX operating system and a general purpose package. The data center will be provided with office furnishings, air conditioners, a photocopier, a fax machine and a generator. 9. Training for Meteorological Staff of CWC/State Surface Water Agencies. IMD's training experience and training facilities will be utilized for project purposes. IMD will provide the initial training courses for site observers and junior professional supervisory staff, and will be a source
 163 AnnexS 19 Page 3 of training for selected senior professional staff from state agencies with the background to become specialists in meteorology. Thus, IMD will provide: (a) basic training courses of four weeks duration for about 3,000 hydromet observers distributed in the participating states using the training facilities available at Calcutta, Madras and Pune; (b) training courses of six weeks duration for about 400 hydromet supervisors (Junior or Assistant Engineer rank) using the central training facility at Pune; and (c) advanced/refresher courses of four weeks duration for about 75 senior staff (Executive or Superintendent Engineer rank) using the central training facility at Pune. The project will also provide training aids and equipment to serve the training program. The training program will be administered by an ADG appointed specially for this purpose. 10. Buildings. No major construction of additional buildings is required for any of the IMD offices to be utilized for project purposes except for small storage/garage facilities. However, some modifications to existing buildings will be required for the establishment of the 11 data centers (para 8). Minor civil works will also be required for installation of observatory equipment for the three training centers in the states (para 9). A training hostel will be taken on rent at Calcutta until the new building is completed. 11. Calibration of Equipment. The IMD have facilities at Pune to test and calibrate scientific instruments used for hydrometeorological measurements. Provision is made under the project to upgrade and improve these facilities to reflect the increased numbers of instruments which will have to be tested and calibrated on a routine basis. 12. Vehicles. The project coordination office in New Delhi will be provided with a saloon car for the use of the ADG (Coordination). The Pune training center will be provided with one four-wheel drive jeep. The eight regional/state offices in Bombay, Madras, Trivandrum, Hyderabad, Bangalore, Ahmedabad, Bhopal and Bhubaneswar which will be involved in the inventory of existing meteorological networks (para 5), site selection for new observatories (para 6) and inspection work (para 7) will each be provided with two four wheel drive jeeps for field work. 13. Overseas Study Tours. A provision is made under the project for overseas study tours for about 24 IMD scientists abroad for periods of aboutfour weeks each. Fields of study will include recent advances in data management and in hydrometeorology. 14. Incremental Implementation Staff. It will be necessary for IMD to increase its establishment to implement its component of the project. The staff build-up will take place over the first two years of the project and remain stable thereafter. The estimated cost of the salaries and allowances for project implementation staff is estimated at about Rs.61.1 million over the six year life of the project. The project also provides for some Rs.7.6 million for staff travel (other than for overseas tours which is costed separately). Both incremental staff costs and travel allowances are based on costs and salary scales as of July 1994. Annual increases in salary scales and travel costs over the project period have been provided for under the physical and price contingenices added to the base costs (see Annex 2).

 166 Annex 20 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Programs in Andhra Pradesh Introduction 1. With a land area of about 275,100 km2 and a population of some 53.5 million in 1989, Andhra Pradesh (AP) is the fifth largest State in India both in area and population. It lies along the east coast and has a generally hot and humid climate with summer temperatures in May and June reaching 450C in some central and northern districts. The mean annual rainfall varies from about 1,200 mm in the mountainous north to 500 mm in the south. Rainfall is principally provided by the south-west monsoon with the north-east monsoon contributing about one-third of the annual rainfall. 2. Section A of this annex describes existing systems for hydrological observations and data management; Section B summarizes proposed improvements to the observation systems; Section C describes the establishment of interactive computerized data banks and inter-bank communication systems; Section D summarizes proposed improvements in reservoir instrumentation and management; Section E describes the proposed improvements in the monitoring of return flows from selected irrigated command areas; Section F covers real time water resources management through improved flood warning systems; Section G summarizes institutional strengthening activities; Section H refers to procurement procedures; and Section I describes arrangements for project performance monitoring and evaluation and for project review. A. Existing Systems for Hydrological Observations and Data Management Suiface Water Hydrology 3. Organizational Setu. All hydrological data collection and management activities in AP come under the CE (Investigations) of the Department of Irrigation and Command Area Development (DOICAD. The Hydrology Circle contains three River Gauging Divisions located at Hyderabad, Karimnagar and Nakerkal which control three, six and four Sub-Divisions respectively . In addition to the three field Divisions, there is a Hydrology and Statistics Division in Hyderabad. 4. River Gauging Stations. The three gauging Divisions of the DOICAD operate 138 stations, which measure both stage and discharge. Suspended sediment is measured at only two stations, and water quality is not routinely monitored. The Central Water Commission (CWC) operates 34 stage/discharge stations in AP. Water quality is monitored at 22 of the CWC stations, and suspended sediment is measured at 13 of the sites. 5. Laboratory Facilities. As water quality is not routinely monitored by the gauging Divisions. DOICAD does not have its own laboratory facilities. The water samples collected by CWC are analyzed at the divisional laboratories. 6. Data Processing and Management. Discharge measurements are obtained by trained technicians at the DOICAD observation sites. The discharge is computed by a Junior Engineer (JE) or Deputy Executive Engineer (DEE). The stage readings and discharge measurements are submitted in a prescribed format to the Divisional office where data are finalized, tabulated and stored in registers. At present, DOICAD does not publish riverflow data and computers are not
 167 Annex 20 Page 2 used for managing the data. Data collected from the CWC observation sites are processed and stored according to standard procedures (Annex 5). Groundwater Hydrology 7. Organizational Setup. A Ground Water Directorate (GWD) was established under the DOICAD in 1971. It is functionally organized into five wings for hydrogeology, hydrology, chemistry, geophysics and drilling, each under a Deputy Director, and there is an administrative and accounts wing. There are 22 district offices and these have multifunctional responsibilities. The GWD has about 400 professional staff comprising hydrogeologists, geophysicists, hydrologists, chemists and civil and mechanical engineers. 8. Groundwater Monitoring Networks. The DOICAD monitoring network consists of 3,189 wells, with 1,065 wells in the iirigation command areas (mainly concerned with monitoring of water logging) and the remaining 2,064 wells outside the major surface water command areas. The locations outside command areas are monitored as follows: a) all wells provide a weekly measurement taken by local observers which are mailed to GWD on special prepaid post cards; b) 45 wells are measured monthly by Directorate observers; c) 250 wells are measured bimonthly by Directorate observers; and d) 1,769 wells provide pre- and post-monsoon water levels taken by Directorate observers. Of the command area wells, 315 are measured five times a year and 770 are measured twice a year by Directorate observers. Water samples are taken for quality analyses twice a year from all wells (pre- and post-monsoon). 9. The Regional Office of Central Ground Water Board (CGWB) in Hyderabad maintains a network of 1,034 observation wells in AP which are monitored for water levels duling 10-day periods four times each year (January, May, August, November). Water samples are taken for analysis once a year in May. The water levels are measured manually. Only 73 of the water obser-vation points are tubewells, and the remaining observation points are open wells which are not the property of the Board. 10. Laboratory Facilities. The GWD has established water quality laboratories at Hyderabad, Cuddapah, Rajahmundry and Kurnool. Chemical analyses include determination of pH, EC, TDS and major cations and anions. Around 7,500 samples are analyzed annually. About 3,000 obser-vation wells are sampled. Other samples are taken during drilling and other investigations. The laboratories are fairly well established, but much of the equipment is old. l 1. The CGWB Regional Office in Hyderabad operates a fairly well established laboratory of the Level II category with experienced staff, but most of its equipment is old. The laboratory was established in 1973 with assistance of CIDA and is equipped to determine the standard chemical parameters of water for irrigation and drinking purposes. The current workload of about 3900 samples includes the annual sampling in May of the Regional Office's observation networks in Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu, re-appraisal surveys, exploratory drilling, short-term investigations for water supply, and pollution studies. There are no facilities for the analysis of heavy metals and micro organic pollutants. 12. Data Processing and Management. Part of GWD's data has been processed using computers. The CGWB Regional Oftice has some computing facilities but, to date, only the historical water level data have been stored in computer files. Hvydiometeorology 13. Organizational Setup. In common with all the states of India, several state agencies in AP maintain networks of rainfall observation stations, including the Revenue Department (RD), the

In addition, the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has a small network of climate stations in AP, and CWC also manages a small number of rainfall and climatic stations. 14. This section refers mainly to riverflow data collected by the Hydrology Divisions of DOICAD. All their data is now on paper files. Although at least part of this data may be of doubtful quality, it must be recognized that it is, at present, all that is available. Therefore, these existing data series must- be stored for use until such time that a long series of higher validity becomes available. Nevertheless, some validation of the data must be made to remove obviously anomalous observations before data are entered into computer storage or, alternatively, a computer routine could be used to recognize possible anomalies after the data are entered. It is evident that this exercise will be very subjective and will require care in application. The next opportunity to review the historical data will be offered when a validated data series is developed through project activities at a stable site where a secure rating curve can be derived. If comparison of the rating curve with historical stage/discharge measurements reveals a 'systematic error' in the discharge measurements, it may then be possible to 'correct' the data series for the site. 24. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies. A basic concept of the project is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a service to the public at large, and thus that all legitimate users of the data should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, the publication of data summaries in the form of year books would suffice. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data, and this could be provided as printouts or on floppy discs. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 48. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to the data bases for legitimate private entities could be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the state. This would give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the fonm of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological service.  183 Annex 21 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGYPRO Programs in Gujarat I. Gujarat has a land area of some 195,890 km2 with a population estimated at about 34 million in 1989. Mean annual rainfall ranges from less than 200 mm in the extreme northwest to about 1,270 mm in the south, almost all of which occurs with the southwest monsoon during June to September. The state contains the lower catchments of several westward flowing rivers, of which the Narmada, Tapi, Mahi and Sabarmati flow to the Arabian Sea, and the Bana and Sarawathi to the Little Rann of Kutch. The Saurashtra peninsula lies entirely within Gujarat and is radially drained by numerous small rivers. 2. Section A of this Annex describes existing systems for hydrological observations and data management; Section B summarizes proposed improvements to the observation systems; Section C covers reservoir sedimentation surveys; Section D describes the establishment of interactive computerized data banks and inter-bank communication systems; Section E covers institutional strengthening activities; Section F refers to procurement procedures; and Section G describes arrangements for project performance monitoring and evaluation, and for the project review process. Detailed cost estimates for state agency activities are shown by Table 1. A. Existing Systems for Hydrological Observations and Data Management Surface Water Hydrology 3. Organizational Setup. The Narmada and Water Resources Department (NWRD) has overall responsibility for surface water hydrology. Hydrological operations at field and office levels are carried by a Division within the Water Resources Investigations Circle (WRIC) of NWRD. The Hydrology Division which has a headquarters at Ahmedabad, has five Subdivisions, each with several Section Offices for field operations. CWC's activities in Gujarat are managed by a Division with a headquarters in Ahmedabad. 4. River Gauging Stations. The Hydrology Division operates 173 river gauging stations of which 19 measure only stage level and the remaining 154 measure both stage and discharge. Suspended sediment is also measured at 143 of the stage/discharge stations. Water quality is not routinely monitored. The CWC operates 29 river gauging stations in Gujarat, of which 13 record only the stage level and 16 provide both stage and discharge measurements. Water quality is monitored at seven of the CWC stage/discharge stations, and suspended sediment is measured at six of these sites. 5. Laboratory Facilities. As water quality is not monitored by the Hydrology Division as a routine, WRIC does not have its own laboratory facilities. The Gujarat Engineering Research Institute (GERI) is a large R&D agency under NWRD. It has a small laboratory facility which can provide services to organizations within the department. The water samples collected by CWC for quality monitoring are analyzed at its divisional laboratory in Ahmedabad. 6. DatjProcessing and_Management. Discharge measurements at NWRD sites are obtained by full time crews. The crew overseer computes the measurements which are then checked by the Junior Engineer during site visits. The gauge readings and discharge measurements are submitted in a prescribed format upwards through the hierarchy with further checks to the Divisional Office where data are finalized, tabulated and published in the form of year books. Computers are not used for managing the data. Data collected from CWC observation sites are processed and stored according to standard procedures (Annex 15). Groundwater Hydrology 7. Organizational Setup. The Ground Water Investigation Circle (GWIC) of the Gujarat Water Resources Development Corporation (GWRDC) is the organization responsible for all aspects of ground
 184 Annex 21 Page 2 water hydrology. GWIC has a headquarters in Gandhinagar and has Regional Offices in Ahmedabad, Rajkot, Bhavnagar and Palanpur, each of which control three to five of the 17 Sub-regional offices. The Central Ground Water Board (CGWB) has a Regional Office in Ahmedabad with responsibilities for the geographical area of Gujarat state. 8. GroundwateLMonitoring Networks. GWIC maintains a network of 2,656 observation wells. These comprise: (a) 719 open wells tapping the phreatic aquifer and distributed in all the districts of the state; (b) 1,394 open wells in the coastal region of southern Saurashtra which is subject to sea water intrusion of the phreatic aquifer, (c) 325 tubewells tapping deeper confined or semi-confined aquifers, mainly in mainland Gujarat; and (d) 218 purpose-built piezometers in the Narmada command area in mainland Gujarat and Sauirashtra. Excepting the Narmada command area piezometers, water levels are measured in the observation wells manually immediately prior to and immediately after the monsoon. Autographic water level recovers have been installed on 26 of the Narmada command area piezometers and the remaining 192 wells are measured manually four times each year. The CGWB Regional Office maintains a network of 1,007 observation wells, of which 850 are shallow open wells and 157 are tubewells. Water levels are monitor by manual measurements in January, May, August and November of each year. 9. GWIC samples its main network of open wells for water quality analyses at the end of the dry season and post monsoon each year. The salinity observation network along the Saurashtra coast is monitored for water quality more frequently. Samples are taken from all CGWB Regional Office open well observation points for water quality analyses in May each year. 10. Laboratory Facilities. GWIC has established laboratories in three of its regional offices in Ahmedabad, Bhavnagar and Rajkot. The CGWB Regional Office has a laboratory facility in Ahmedabad. All the laboratories are intended to carry out the standard chemical analyses associated with assessment of water quality for irrigation. The laboratories require major upgrading in terms of buildings and equipment (para 18). 11. Data Processine and Management. GWIC's groundwater data is processed manually and most is stored in paper files, but part of the water level record has been entered into the CGWB computer files. The CGWB Regional Office has some computing facilities and groundwater software but, to date, only the historical water level data has been stored in computer files. Hydrometeorology 12. Organizational Setup. As with all the states of India, several state agencies in Gujarat maintain networks of rainfall observation stations, including the Revenue Department (RD), the NWRD and the Department of Agriculture (DOA). The last two departments also have established networks of climate observation stations. In addition, the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has a small network of rainfall and climate stations in Gujarat, and CWC manages a small rainfall observation network. 13. Hydrometeorological Networks. The NRWD and other state agencies make rainfall and other climatic observations at 972 sites in Gujarat, outside the Narmada Basin. Of the 972 stations, 300 are full climate stations (FCS) and five are automatic weather stations (AWS), 249 are rainfall stations equipped with autographic rain gauges (ARG), and 418 have standard rain gauges (SRG). It is reported that a large proportion of the equipment on FCS sites is unserviceable. The IMD maintains 12 FCSs, 15 ARG stations with and one SRG station. CWC has 10 rainfall stations of which nine are equipped with ARGs and one with an SRG. The average density of rainfall observation sites in Gujarat is about one rain gauge/194 km2. 14. Data Processing and Management. Computers are not used for storage and management of the rainfall and other climate data collected by the NRWD and other state agencies in Gujarat. The IMD processes data from its own network and from selected state agency rainfall stations using computers at its Pune headquarters.

The surface water observation network improvement program in Gujarat does not involve expansion of either the NWRD or the CWC networks. However, provision is made for upgrading equipment at NWRD observation sites to broaden the range of parameters observed, and for additional office and site buildings. The proposed improvements to the NWRD river observation network include: (a) provision of 30 propeller-type current meter packages including echo sounders, digital counters and camp equipment; (b) provision of 160 cup type current meter sets; (c) provision of 77 bed load sampling equipment sets; (d) provision 20 sets of silt analysis equipment; and (e) construction of site equipment stores at 98 river gauging sites. 16. This section refers mainly to surface water flow data which has been collected by the Hydrology Division of WRIC. All the data is now on paper files. Although at least part of this data may be of doubtful quality, it must be recognized that it is, at present, all that is available. Therefore, the existing data series must be stored for use until such time that a long series of higher validity becomes available. Nevertheless, some validation of the data must be made to remove obvious anomalous observations before data are entered into computer storage or, altematively, a computer routine could be used to recognize possible anomalies after the data are entered. It is evident that this exercise will be very subjective and will require care in application. The next opportunity to review the historical data will be offered when a validated data series is developed through project activities at a stable site where a secure rating curve can be derived. If comparison of the rating curve with historical stage/discharge measurements reveals a 'systematic error' in the discharge measurements, it may then be possible to 'correct' the data series for the site. 24. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies. A basic concept of the project is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a service to the public at large. Thus, all legitimate users should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, the publication of data summaries in the form of year books would suffice. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data, and this could be provided as printouts or on floppy disks. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 43. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to the data bases for legitimate private entities could be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the state. This would give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the form of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological service.
