 198 Annex 22 Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Programs In Madhva Pradesh Introduction I . Madhya Pradesh (MP) is the largest state in India with a land area of 443,450 km2. Its population in 1989 was 52.5 million. The mean annual rainfall varies from about 1,600 mm in the south-eastern part of the state to about 600 mm in the northwest. Many of the major rivers of central India originate in MP. The major river systems of the state are the Chambal, Betwa and Son, tributaries of the Ganges, and the Narmada, Tapi, Mahanadi, Godavari and Mahi. The Ganges Basin and Narmada basin areas within MP are not included under HP for surface water related project components. The remaining basins occupy about 151,000 km2 within MP or about 34% of the state area. The entire area of MP is included under HP for groundwater related project components. 2. Section A of this Annex describes existing systems for hydrological observations and data management; Section B summarizes proposed improvements to the data collection systems; Section C describes the establishment of interactive computerized data banks and inter-bank communication systems; Section D covers institutional strengthening activities; Section E refers to cost estimates and procurement procedures; and Section F describes arrangements for project performance monitoring and evaluation, and for project review. Detailed cost estimates for state agency activities are shown by Table 1. A. Existin2 Systems for Hydrological Data Collection and Data Management Surface Water Hydrology 3 . Organizational Set-Up. The responsibility for surface water hydrology will be placed under a Chief Engineer who will control both surface water and groundwater hydrology and report to the Engineer-in-Chief. The Directorate of Hydrometeorology was established in 1982 under the World Bank assisted MP Major Irrigation Project (Cr. 1177) for hydrological data collection and processing. The Directorate contained four field data collection Divisions, located at Raipur, Rewa, Bhopal and Hoshangabad. Subsequently, the Government of Madhya Pradesh (GOMP) decided to hand over all river gauging stations in the Narmada Basin area in the state to the Narmada Valley Development Authority (NVDA). One Subdivision of the Hoshangabad Division has been transferred and the remaining two Subdivisions together with the Division are to be transferred to the NVDA. The CWC has four Divisional Offices with responsibility for project river basins in MP (Annex 15 of the SDV). 4. River Gauging Network. The WRD currently operates 61 gauging stations on project rivers, of which 59 measure stage and discharge and two observe stage, discharge and sediment load. The CWC network in MP consists of 12 stage/discharge stations and 16 stations where stage, discharge, sediment and water quality are observed. 5. Laboratory Facilities. The WRD has not carried out water quality monitoring and has no chemical laboratory facilities. The CWC has laboratory facilities in its Divisions responsible for monitoring basin systems in MP. 6. Data Processing and Management. Stage and discharge measurements are obtained by full-time crews of WRD. The discharge is measured twice a day except on Sundays or holidays. The crew leader submits observations on standard forms about once a week to Section Officers, who check the work before forwarding them to the Subdivision. After scrutiny by the Assistant
 199 Annex 22 Page 2 Engineer, single copies of the completed forms are submitted to the Divisional Office where about 20% of the data are spot checked. At the end of the water year (1st June to 31st May), the finalized record of daily mean discharges for the year, along with the computed 10 day means and the maximum and minimum daily mean values for each month are sent to the Director, Hydrometeorology in Bhopal for compilation and publication in water year books. The Directorate does not use computer facilities for processing, storage and retrieval of data. The CWC follows its standard procedures for collection and processing of data for the Commission's network in MP (Annex 15 of the SDV). Hydrometeorology 7. Organizational Set-Up. In common with all the states of India, several state and central agencies in MP maintain networks of rain gauge stations and climatic stations, including the Department of Agriculture, the Department of Lands and the WRD. IMD and CWC also maintain hydrometeorological networks in MP. The meteorological stations operated by WRD have been established to IMD standards and they are being periodically checked by IMD inspectors. 8. Meteorological Network. The total network in MP comprises 419 stations with standard rain gauges (SRG), 60 stations with autographic rain gauges (ARG) and 31 climatic stations. The WRD maintains 116 SRGs and three ARGs. CWC has installed 71 SRGs and 44 ARGs. The IMD owned network comprises 36 SRGs, 13 ARGs and 13 full climatic stations (FCS). The distribution pa..ttern of observation stations indicates that some additional rain gauges in the Mahanadi and Godavari river basins would improve the adequacy of the network. Groundwater Hydrology 9. Organizational_Set-Up. The state organization responsible for survey, investigation and monitoring of groundwater resources is the Ground Water Survey Circle (GWSC) which is headed by a Superintending Geologist who comes under the office of the Chief Engineer (para 3). The headquarters of the GWSC is in Bhopal, and there are nine Divisional offices which each control four to six of the 43 Subdivisions. The CGWB has a Regional Office in Bhopal and a Unit Office in Raipur. 10. Groundwater Monitoring Network. The GWSC has established a network of 4,450 observation wells distributed through the 45 districts of the state. All the observation points are open wells tapping the phreatic aquifer systems. The wells re not the property of WRD. Until 1993, water levels were measured manually three times each year (January, May and November), but GWSC now follows the CGWB practice of four measurements each year in January, May, August and November. The GWSC network has not been monitored systematically for water chemical quality. The CGWB Regional Office maintains a network of 1,372 observation wells in MP, all of which are open wells which are not owned by the Board. Water levels are monitored by manual measurements during fixed ten day periods four times each year (January, May, August, November). Water samples are taken from the observation wells for chemical analysis in May each year. Both the CGWB and GWSC networks have growing problems with their open well observation points - some wells go dry during the dry season while others are abandoned and fal1 into disrepair. There is therefore a need to replace such observation points by purpose-built tubewells. I I. Laboratory Facilities. The GWSC maintains four chemical laboratories at Bhopal, Gwalior, Sagar and Jabalpur. Chemical analyses are confined to 13 parameters relating mainly to the use of groundwater for irrigation. The buildings and laboratory equipment are primitive. The CGWB Regional Office has established a water quality laboratory at its Bhopal headquarters, though much of the equipment is antiquated.
 200 Annex 22 Page 3 12. Data Processing and Management. Data are processed at GWSC Divisional Offices from where they are transmitted to the Bhopal headquarters for preparing annual water table fluctuation maps for each of the 45 districts in the state. At present, all data processing is done manually. The CGWB Regional Office in Bhopal has one desk top computer and a limited number of programs for data management.The Regional Office has entered its entire groundwater data base into computer files. The Raipur unit office of CGWB has no computer facilities. Data transfer to CGWB Headquarters in Faridabad is by posting floppy discs. B. Improvements to Existing Hydrological Data Collection Systems Surface Water Hydrology 13. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The proposed upgrading of the WRD river gauging network will entail completion of the program originally planned under the Bank-assisted MP Major Irrigation Project (para 3) by establishing 42 new gauging stations in the Godavari, Tapti, Mahi and Mahanadi basins. The new stations will include 27 sites where stage/discharge measurements are made and 15 sites where stage, discharge, sediment and water quality are observed. The project will also upgrade 69 existing gauging stations. The equipment to be provided includes: (a) 42 AWLR; (b) 11 propeller type current meter packages; (c) 122 cup type current meter packages; (d) 15 cableways for use with boats; (e) 15 cableways for use with cradles or winches; (f) 38 bridge sets; (g) 25 boat outfits without trailer; (h) one moving boat outfit; and (i) 15 sediment sampling packages. In addition, the project will provide 15 sediment analysis laboratory buildings which will also function as Level I laboratories and 42 site equipment stores. The CWC does not envisage any expansion of its network in the state but sites will be upgraded. 14. Improved Laboratory Facilities. Under the HP, groundwater and surface water hydrology will be managed under a single organization under a Chief Engineer in the WRD. Therefore, the laboratory facilities will serve for monitoring both surface water and groundwater. The existing four laboratories at Bhopal, Gwalior, Sagar and Jabalpur now under GWSC (para 11) will be increased by five new laboratories to be established at Rewa, Bilaspur, Raipur, Balaghat and Khandwa (sanction, including staff sanction has been obtained for four of these). Of these nine laboratories, seven would be of Level II standard while the Bhopal and Raipur facilities would be Level II+ laboratories. New buildings will be provided for all nine laboratories. The project will also provide 15 Level I laboratories which will be located at the river gauging sites where sediment and water quality are to be monitored. The CWC Divisional Office laboratories which serve basins in MP will be upgraded to Level II. Details of the equipment to be provided and the analyses to be carried out by each type of laboratory are discussed in Annex 5. Groundwater Hydrology 15. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The GWSC network of observation wells will increase from 4,450 to 4,715 locations after completion of the project. The improved network will comprise 565 tubewells equipped with digital water level recorders, 100 tubewells which will be manually measured and 4,050 open wells which will be manually measured. The CGWB Regional Office observation network will increase from a present 1,372 to 1,488 wells after project completion. The network will include 265 tubewells equipped with digital water level recorders, 30 tubewells which will be manually measured and 1,193 open wells which will be manually measured. Details of the improvements to the GWSC network are given in Table 3. For a more detailed discussion on groundwater network improvements, reference should be made to Annex 4. 16. Improved Laboratory Facilities. Since the State facilities will jointly serve both surface water and groundwater, provisions under the HP have been quantified in para 14 above. The CGWB laboratory at Bhopal will be upgraded to Level H+.
 201 Annex 22 Page 4 Hvdrometeorologv 17. Improvements to the Meteorological Network. WRD will improve/expand its rain gauge network through installation of 44 SRGs and 36 ARGs. Since a number of the existing observation stations have defective or missing meteorological instruments, a lump sum provision has been made for such replacements. The CWC will not expand its network in MP, but improvements are provided for the existing network (Annex 15, SDV). C. Improvements to Data Management and Communication Systems Upgrading of Data Management Systems 18. General. The collection and management of surface water and groundwater data in MP will be managed by a single unit under the Chief Engineer. However, separate computer facilities will be provided for management of surface water and groundwater data at the water data center(s) to be established in Bhopal. CWC's stream gauging networks on the Mahanadi, Godavari, Narmada and Tapi rivers in MP are managed from a Regional office in Hyderabad with Circle and Divisional offices distributed at various localities. The Hyderabad Regional Office will be the main data center for exchange of information with the state. The CGWB Regional Office in Bhopal will establish a data center for information collected from its observation network. Reference should be made to Annex 7 for more detailed discussion of the data management and transfer systems. 19. Checking and Entry of Historical Data in Computer Storage. This section refers mainly to surface water flow data. All of the state data is now on paper files, and some may be of doubtful quality. However, it must be recognized that this data is all that is available at present and it must be stored until a long series of higher validity becomes available. Nevertheless, some validation of the data must be made to remove obvious anomalies, and this exercise will be very subjective and will require care in application. The next opportunity to review the historical data will be offered when a validated series is developed with a secure rating curve through project activities. If comparison of the rating curve with historical stage/discharge measurements reveals a 'systematic elnor' in the discharge measurements, it may then be possible to correct the data series for the site. 20. State Surface Water Data Management System. The surface water data will accumulate at the Bhopal, Raipur, Jagdalpur and Rewa Divisional Offices where most of the verification and final processing will be carried out (para 29). These offices and their Circle Office at Bhopal will be provided with computer package type D comprising two PCs (486 sx), two dot matrix printers plus UPS's, associated office furniture and an air conditioner, together with surface water data system and general purpose software. Transfer of data to the Circle Office and the water data center will be by a dial-up NICNET linkage or by floppy disk. The water data center will be provided with a computer package type B for management of surface water data. The package will comprise: a file saver (486 dx2, EISA), five PCs (486 dx2), two laser printers, a dot matrix printer, a plotter and a digitizer, together with a generator, two air conditioners, a fax machine, photocopier and office furniture. Software provided will include: the surface water and water quality data systems, a hydrological package, a general purpose package, and a network package. The nine laboratories will be provided with D type computer packages plus water quality and general purpose software. Transfer of data from the laboratories to the water data center will be by a dial-up NICNET connection or by floppy disk. 21. Seiroundwater Data Management Systems. The groundwater data collected by WRD accumulates from 43 Subdivisional Offices into nine Divisional Offices. The latter will be provided with computer packages type D plus groundwater data system and general purpose software. The two circle offices of the groundwater organization (para 29) will also be provided with computer package type D with groundwater data, water quality data and general purpose software. The water data center will be provided with computer package type B together with groundwater data, water
 202 Annex 22 Page 5 quality data and general purpose software. As noted (para 22) the nine laboratories will be provided with computer packages type D and appropriate software. Transfer of data from the Divisional Offices and the laboratories to the Circle Offices and the water data center will be by a dial-up NICNET linkage or by floppy disk. 22. CWC Data Management Systems. The CWC Divisional offices and Circle offices concerned with collecting surface water data in the Mahanadi, Godavari and Tapi basins in Madhya Pradesh will be provided with type D computer packages plus surface water data and general purpose software. They will transfer data collected from gauging stations to their Regional Office in Hyderabad by dial-up NICNET linkages or by floppy disk. The Regional Office will be provided with a computer package C together with surface water data, water quality data and general purpose software. The Regional Office will be the main location of interaction with the MP water data center. 23. CGWB Regional Office Data Management System. The CGWB Regional Office in Bhopal will be provided with computer package type B together with groundwater data, water quality data and general purpose software. Its laboratory at Bhopal and the Unit Office in Raipur will be provided with computer packages type D together with appropriate software. Transfer of information from the unit office to the Regional Office data bank will be by a dial-up NICNET connection or by floppy disk. 24. IMD Data Management System. The IMD Meteorological Center in Bhopal will be provided with a computer package type C and appropriate software for management of the rainfall and climatic data generated by CWC and WRD in MP. Transfer of this data from the state water data center to the IMD center will be by floppy disk. Communication Systems between Data Banks 25. The surface water data banks established in WRD and in the CWC Regional Office must be interactive and the communication system provided must allow each entity access to the other party's data base on a 'read only' basis. Similarly, the groundwater data banks in WRD and the CGWB Regional Office must be directly interactive through a communication system. And the state data banks for groundwater and surface water would be required to communicate with the national data banks for groundwater at Faridabad and for surface water at New Delhi. CGWB, Faridabad, and CWC, New Delhi, will be provided with dedicated NICNET ground stations. The state water data center and the CGWB and CWC regional office data centers will be provided with modems and dedicated land telephone lines to their local NICNET ground stations. With these facilities in place, all parties would be able to communicate and transfer data through the NICNET system. E. Institutional Strengthening 26. General. Institutional performance needs to be strengthened for data collection, validation, storage and dissemination. Appropriate skills will have to be developed to operate the computing and laboratory facilities provided under the project and to maintain the improved hydrometric networks. A high level of inter-agency coordination will be required for development of computerized data banks which are inter-active and accessible between data centers and can be accessed by other public and private entities. 27. The project would finance incremental staff and other inputs to support new institutional initiatives intended to implement the project and to ensure its sustainability into the future. These would include: office buildings; equipment and services; consultant services; project specific staff training; and vehicles and their operational costs. Support for selection of specialized equipment,
 203 Annex 22 Page 6 computing facilities and software, and for training of state agency staff will be provided, as appropriate, by CWC, CGWB, NIH, CWPRS, IMD and the consultants of the project. 28. Organizational LSet U. GOMP have decided to merge the activities associated with collection and management of surface and groundwater data within a single organization under a CE, who will report to the Engineer-in-Chief, WRD. An SE will be in charge of the data centers. Groundwater field operations will be carried out by two Circles which will control the nine Divisional Offices and the 43 Subdivisions. The third Circle will control four surface water hydrology field Divisions. A Senior Chemist at the Bhopal laboratory will administer the nine Level II+ or II laboratories. The organizational set up is shown by Figure 1. 29. Office Building and Equipment. A state water data center will be established in Bhopal. Provisions are made under the project for modifying existing office space at headquarters to house the data centers. Provisions are also made for modifying office space at Divisional and Circle Offices to house the computers to be provided at these localities. 30. Computers for Administration and Management. As noted previously, all the computing facilities provided for surface water and groundwater data management (paras 21, 22) will include general purpose software packages. These are intended primarily for administrative and office management purposes. 3 1. Vehiclbs. 'The state water data center will be provided with four saloon cars and a car will be provided for the CE. The field Divisions for suiface water data collection will require 10 jeeps. The two Circle Offices, nine Divisional Offices and 43 Sub-divisional Offices responsible for groundwater monitoring will be provided with a total 54 jeeps (with replacement of 50% of the vehicles in the year six of the project). Each of the nine laboratories intended to serve for analyses of groundwater and surtface water samples will be provided with a jeep. A minibus will be provided for training activities. 33. Staffing Requirements and Costs. So far as possible, staffing of the new organization established for surface water and groundwater data collection and management will be achieved by re-deployment. However, implementation of the project will demand significant additional staff to cteate new divisions and Circle offices, to man new gauging sites, for the additional vehicles, and for specialist posts in the data center and laboratories. The estimated cost of incremental staff over the life of the project totals about Rs. 81.0 million, of which about 53% is for surface water activities, 30% for groundwater activities, and 17% for water quality activities. The average annual cost for incremental staff is around Rs. 13.5 million. Training (Annex I 1) 34. Surface Water Training Activities. The following will be the main subjects of training under the project: (a) training of stream gauging staff and junior supervisory staff in hydrometry and maintenance of instruments and ancillary equipment; (b) training of field level staff in sampling technology for sediment observations and in sediment analysis and for water quality sampling and on-site analyses; (c) training of junior professional staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized laboratory equipment; and (d) training of professionals in the state water data center in the use of computers for hydrological data processing and for other software applications. Essentially all this training will be carried out in-house within the WRD through appropriate training courses, and on-the-job training. In order to implement in-house training courses, it will be necessary to train selected staff to become trainers. The training of trainers would be implemented with the assistance of NIH, CWC and CWPRS. The WALMI at Bhopal will become the principal facility for this training activity. Consultant services would be retained under the project to provide oversight and advice on the design, context and implementation of these training activities.

Additional to the above described training which relates to basic data collection and data management systems, senior professional staff of the surface water hydrology unit will be provided with training in analytical hydrology and advanced computer software applications through training courses run by NIH in Roorkee, by post-graduate training in Indian universities, and by study tours in India and abroad to observe appropriate hydrometric and data management systems. 36. Hydrometeorological Observation Training. The hydrometeorological observation networks maintained by WRD would be improved under the project. While the expansion element of the improvement program is limited, improvement of the performance of the existing network would be an important activity. This will involve training of observers in the proper performance of their duties, including maintenance of instruments. The training will be provided by IMD staff at the Pune or Calcutta IMD Training Centers. Training of supervisors for WRD meteorological stations and more advanced training in hydrometeorology will be provided at the IMD training center in Pune. 37. Groundwater Training Activities. The main subjects of groundwater training under the project will be: (a) training of field staff in manual water level observations, water quality sampling, use of field measuring equipment (biaxial electric tapes, EC meters, pH meters, etc.), and servicing of digital water level recorders; and (b) training of groundwater professionals in the state water data centre, and in the groundwater Circles and Divisions in the use of computer software for data processing and other software applications. The training will be provided through the National Groundwater Training Institute to be established by CGWB in Raipur, with more junior staff trained through courses run using WALMI facilities. The suppliers of digital water level recorders will be required to provide training on servicing and maintenance of the equipment. Project consultants will provide oversight and advice for the training programs. 38. The above training all relates to basic data collection and data management systems. In addition, senior professional staff of the groundwater unit will be provided with training in advanced hydrogeological analysis techniques, including computer modelling, through training courses run by NIH in Roorkee. and post-graduate training in Indian universities. Study tours in India and abroad will be provided to observe appropriate groundwater monitoring networks and data management systems. 39. Training Cost Estimates. Quantities, cost estimates and timing for all training activities are shown by Table 1. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies 40. A basic concept of the project is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a service to the public at large. Thus, all legitimate users of the data should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, the publication of data summaries in the form of year books would suffice. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data, and this could be provided as printouts or on floppy discs. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 41. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to the data bases for legitimate private entities could be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the state. This would give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the format of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological services.
 205 Annex 22 Page 8 F. Procurement 42. General. The procurement arrangements for the project are described in paras 4.03-4.07 and detailed in Annex 13b. All procurement would follow the standard procurement documentation approved by the World Bank for works, goods and services. 43. Works. The civil works to be implemented by the WRD consists of relatively small buildings and small structures for hydrological and climatic stations. These will be implemented by LCB contracts according to Bank guidelines or force account, as appropriate. The drilling works under the project will be construction of observation tubewells, most of which will be procured by LCB contracts with local drilling companies, but the wells with more difficult designs will be constructed using the government's own drilling rigs under force account. 44. Goods . Implementation of the project will involve procurement of large quantities of specialized hydrometric equipment, some specialized survey and laboratory equipment, and computer hardware and software. These items will be procured centrally by ICB as described in para 4.0 of the SAR. The office equipment will be procured by LCB or by prudent shopping procedures. The vehicles for the first year will be procured by prudent shopping from the manufacturers according to Government standard rate contracts. Subsequent vehicle procurement will follow ICB or prudent shopping procedures, according to the size of the package. 45. Services. Consultant services will be procured by Central Government according to Bank guidelines for foreign and local consultants. NICNET services will be provided according to negotiated charges and fees arranged by Central Government. All other services will be provided by the concerned agencies through force account procedures. G. Project Coordination. Monitofing and Evaluation & Review 46. Proiect Coordination. A small Project Coordination Group will be established in WRD, reporting to the Secretary of the Department, to coordinate all project activities. An important function of the group will be liaison with the Divisional, Regional and Central Offices of CWC with the Regional and Central Offices of CGWB, and with other agencies (IMD, NIH, CWPRS) which are involved in project programs in the state. The Project Coordination Group will also have the responsibility for project monitoring and evaluation, and for the project reviews as described below. 47. Monitofing-and-Evaluation. The monitoring and evaluation of this structurally complex project will be carried out in MP by the State Project Coordination Group. The exercise will cover both project implementation progress, and the performance of the data collection and management systems developed. The results of monitoring and evaluation will be reported in semi-annual reports and form a basis for the annual implementation reviews (para 48). 48. Project Annual Reviews. Semi-annual progress reports will be prepared for the state by the State Project Coordination Group and submitted to the Central Project Coordinating Secretariat for inclusion in the project semi-annual progress reports. An annual implementation review of the project will be undertakenunder the guidance of the Central Coordinating Committee with the Bank not later than December 31 each year. The annual review arrangement will provide the flexibility required to amend the state program for the following fiscal year to reflect performance in the past year, and to incorporate any lessons learned into the future program. The State Coordinating Group will have responsibility for presentation of information on the performance of MP's part of the program for the annual implementation review.

 211 Annex 23 Page 1 INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Programs in Maharashtra Introduction 1. Maharashtra has a land area of 308,000 km2 and the population was about 62.8 million in 1989. There are three rainfall zones. The Western Ghats, with a relatively high annual rainfall of between 1,000-3,000 mm, run parallel to the coast and serve as a barrier to the advancing southwest monsoon. East of the Ghats is the rain shadow region where mean annual precipitation drops below 500 mm and which is chronically drought prone. Further to the east, the rain shadow effect decreases and mean annual rainfall increases to 1,000 to 2,500 mm. The Godavari and Krishna, which rise in the mountain range of the Westem Ghats and flow eastwards into the Bay of Bengal, are the major river systems. A large number of small rivers drain to the coastal plain west of the Ghats into the Arabian Sea. The Tapi river in the north drains part of Maharashtra into the Arabian Sea. 2. Section A of the report describes existing systems for hydrological observations and data management; Section B summarizes proposed improvements to the data collection systems; Section C describes the establishment of interactive computerized data banks and inter-bank communication systems; Section D covers monitoring of return glows; Section E is concerned with real-time water resources management; Section F describes support for reservoir instrumentation and management; Section G covers institutional strengthening activities; Section H refers to procurement procedures; and Section I describes arrangements for project performance monitoring and evaluation, and for project review. All surface water hydrology is presently the responsibility of the Chief Engineer Water Resources (CEWR) under the Secretary Irrigation. The hydrological field data is collected and regularly published through four divisional offices for respective basins. Hydrological analysis is carried out by the Hydrology Cell at Nasik. 4. River Gauging Network. The Maharashtra Irrigation Department (MID) maintains 139 river gauging stations where river stage and discharge are monitored (a further 114 gauging stations are under construction). At 55 of the sites, discharge is measured by current meter, and at the remaining 84 sites, discharge is measured by the float method. Sediment load observations are made at one stage/discharge station, and both sediment and water quality are observed at 15 stations. The CWC operates 62 river gauges in Maharashtra, of which 24 also observe both quality and sediment and six observe quality. 5. Laboratory Facilities. MID operates one laboratory at Nasik which is about Level II standard, but most of the equipment requires upgrading. CWC has laboratory facilities with its Divisional Offices. 6. Data Processing and Management. River flow observations are obtained by full-time crews, reinforced by temporary staff hired during the monsoon season. Measurements are checked by the Junior Engineer during site visits. Data are submitted in a prescribed fornat with further checks to the Sub-divisional and thence to basin Divisional Offices where data are tabulated for publication as yearbooks. Computerization of this process started in 1984 at the Pune
 212 Annex 23 Page 2 Divisional Office, but in the three remaining Divisional Offices, data processing is still carried out manually. Groundwater Hydrology 7. Organizational Set Up. The State's Groundwater Surveys and Development Agency (GSDA), set up in 1972, is a Directorate under the Rural Development Department (RDD) and has broad responsibilities for all aspects of groundwater development in Maharashtra, including rural water supply. GSDA's headquarters is in Pune, and it operates through six Regional Offices (Pune, Kokan, Nasik, Aurangabad, Amravati and Nagpur) which, in turn, control four to seven District Offices, out of a total of 29 District Offices. The CGWB regional office located in Nagpur has responsibility for the Board's activities in Maharashtra. It maintains a unit office in Pune. 8. Groundwater Monitoring Network. The GSDA's groundwater observation and assessment system is based on 1,503 defined watershed areas (ranging in size from 80 km2 to 160 km2) located within the 15 river basins which together cover the surface of the State. The observation well network now totals 3,920 points with two to three observation locations in each watershed area, located to give bottom catchment and side slope hydrographs. The network is based entirely on open wells in the phreatic aquifers. Water level measurements are made manually four times each year (October, January, March, May) at all observation points, and observations may be extended monthly into the monsoon in selected areas during times of drought. Samples are taken for water quality analysis once each year immediately prior to the monsoon. The CGWB Regional Office monitors 1,453 wells for water level fluctuations and water quality. The network is entirely restricted to observation of the phreatic aquifer systems. Water level observations are made manually during fixed 10 day intervals four time each year (January, May, August, November). Water quality aamples are taken from all observation points in May each year. 9. Laboratory Facilities. GSDA is operating five regional water quality laboratories at Nasik, Kokan Bhavan, Aurangabad, Amravati and Nagpur and a central laboratory at Pune. Chemical analyses currently include 21 parameters (one of which is coliform) and concentrate particularly on the suitability of groundwater for drinking purposes. The laboratories require major upgrading in terms of equipment, buildings and staffing. The CGWB Regional Office at Nagpur maintains a laboratory at about Level II standard, though most of the equipment requires replacement. 10. Dam-Management. The entire GSDA groundwater database is on computer files in the Pune headquarters. The groundwater data (including water quality data) is entered into computers at the Regional Offices and is then transferred up to the Central Office on floppy discs. The CGWB Regional Office, Nagpur, has in-house computer capability for storage, retrieval and analysis of groundwater data. Data transfer to CGWB headquarters is by floppy disc. Hdrmeterology 11. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies 47. A basic concept of the project is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a service to the public at large. Thus that all legitimate users of the data should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, the publication of data summaries in the form of year books would suffice, and the project provides funds for this purpose. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data and this could be provided as printouts or on floppy disks. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 48. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to the data bases for legitimate private entities might be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the state. This would give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the form of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological service.

 Annex 24 227 Page l INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Programs in Orissa 1. Orissa lies on the east coast of India. It has a land area of 155,700 kmn2 and a population of 26.5 million in 1989. The mean annual rainfall is about 1500 mm, most of which occurs during the southwest monsoon from July to September. October is also a wet month due to Bay of Bengal cyclones. The main rivers are the Mahanadi, Subernarekha, Brahmani and Baitarani. 2. Section A of the annex describes existing systems for hydrological observations and data management; Section B summarizes proposed improvements to the observation systems; Section C describes the establishment of interactive computerized data banks and inter-bank communication systems; Section D discusses proposed improvements in reservoir instrumentation and management; Section E describes the proposed improvements in the monitoring of return flows from selected irrigated command areas; Section F covers real-time water resources management through improved flood warning systems; Section G summarizes institutional strengthening activities; Section H refers to procurement procedures; and Section I describes arrangements for project performance monitoring and evaluation, and for project review. Detailed cost estimates for state agency activities are shown by Table 1. A. Existing Systems for Hydrological Observations and Data Management Surface Water Hydrology 3. Organizational Setup. The organization for hydrological services is under the Chief Engineer (Water Planning) within the Orissa Water Resources Department (WRD). The Hydrology Directorate under an SE controls six divisions, three of which are responsible for field data collection, one for data processing and storage, one for water quality and one for reservoir surveys. Each hydrology field division controls three or four sub-divisions. 4. River Gauging Networks. WRD has established 49 gauging stations in ten river basins. All the gauging stations make stage and discharge measurements. The CWC operates 21 stage/discharge stations in Orissa, of which two also observe sediment load and 9 monitor both sediment and water quality. 5 . Laboratorv Facilities. WRD does not maintain its own laboratory facilities for water quality analysis. Water samples collected from the seven observation stations are analyzed by the laboratory of the Orissa Agriculture University in Bhubaneswar. The analyses are concerned mainly with the suitability of the water for irrigation. CWC analyses water samples taken from its network at the Divisional laboratory in Bhubaneswar. 6. Data Processing and Management. Discharge measurements at the WRD gauging sites are obtained by trained technicians to develop stage/discharge rating curves. Discharge is computed by a Junior Engineer. At present the WRD does not publish year books of riverflow data. The Hydrology Directorate has recently started processing and storage of data on computers. The CWC processes its data according to standard procedures (Annex 15). Groundwater (GW) Hydrology 7. Organizational Setup. The responsibility for GW exploration and assessment rests with the Groundwater Survey and Investigation Board (GWSIB) of the Orissa Lift Irrigation Corporation
 228 AnnexL 24 Page 2 (OLIC), which comes under the Ministry of Rural Development (MRD). GWSIB is headed by a Chief Engineer who is assisted by two SEs. There are eight field Divisions, seven of which carry out hydrogeological investigations and GW monitoring and one is a Mechanical Division in charge of drilling and pump testing. The CGWB has a Regional Office in Bhubaneswar which is responsible for the Board's activities in Orissa. 8. GW Monitoring Networks. The GWSIB collects water level data from a monitoring network of 1,054 wells consisting of 90 open wells and 74 tubewells, where water levels are recorded twice a year (pre- and post-monsoon), and 890 open wells where only pre-monsoon levels are recorded. The open wells are not the property of the Board. Water quality monitoring is not carried out systematically. 9. The Regional Office of CGWB maintains a network comprising 1,131 observation wells which, are monitored for water levels during 10-day periods four times each year (January, May, August, November), and water samples are taken for analysis once a year in May. The water levels are measured manually in the network. Only 51 of the observation points are tubewells, the remainder being open wells which are not the property of the Board. 10. Laboratory Facilities. The GWSIB has limited facilities to undertake chemical analyses of water samples. The central laboratory at Bhubaneswar and four regional laboratories are poorly equipped. Provision is made under an ongoing KfW (German Technical Assistance) project to establish two laboratories in the coastal zone. 11. The CGWB Regional Office has a well established Level II laboratory with experienced staff. This handles the water analysis requirements of the office, and the staff is also involved in interpretive work which has resulted in various scientific publications. 12. Data Processing and Management. Essentially all GWSIB data is processed manually and stored in paper files, though a recent development has been to use commercial computing facilities for data storage. The CGWB Regional Office is using computers for management of its data and makes use of NIC facilities in Bhubaneswar through a telephone linkage. Hydrometeorology 13. Organizational Setup. Several State and Central agencies in Orissa maintain rainfall and climate stations, including the Department of Agriculture (DOA), the Department of Revenue (DOR), the CWC, and the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD). At present, the WRD does not maintain a meteorological network in the State. 14. Hydrometeorological Network. The DOA, DOR, the CWC and the [MD together operate 460 rainfall stations. In addition, the IMD maintains 18 full climatic stations (FCS). WRD is in the process of installing three automatic weather stations (AWS). 15. Data Processing and Management. Computers are not used for storage and management of the rainfall and other climate data collected by the state agencies in Orissa. However, the IMD National Data Center at Pune receives data from 253 of the rainfall stations and the 23 FCSs operated by IMD, and this information is stored on computers. B. Improvements to Hydrological Observations Systems Suiface Water Hydrology 16. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The component includes upgrading of all 49 existing river gauging stations and the provision of 26 new stations of various types. The project wouild provide the following instrumentation for the existing and new stations:
 229 Annex 24 Page 3 Instrumentation/Equipment Upgraded New AWLR (chart type) 25 Data-loggers, pressure transducer type - 26 Current meter packages: Type B propeller 5 Type C standard cup 44 26 Bridge outfits 10 5 Moving boat outfits - 2 Type B boat with trailer 3 2 Type C boat without trailer 2 3 Cableways (span>lOOm) 5 Cableways (span<lOOm) - 5 Sediment sampling package 5 26 Sediment analysis labs 5 26 17. Improved Laboratory Facilities. WRD proposes to implement a routine water quality moni- toring program for its rivers and reservoirs. This would entail constructing and equipping 11 Level I laboratories for on-site analyses and a central chemical laboratory (Level II) at Bhubaneswar. Each Level I station can also cover two or three adjacent stations. CWC's laboratory at Bhubaneswar will be upgraded to Level II. Details of the equipment to be provided and the analyses to be performed by each type of laboratory are described in Annex 5. Groundwater Hydrology 18. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The GWSIB would install 305 observation tubewells ranging in depth from 30 m to 300 m. Digital water level recorders would be installed on the 305 new tubewells and on 70 existing tubewells. The CGWB would construct 175 observation tubewells to a range of depths (30 - 300 m) and these would be equipped with digital water level recorders. Details of the improvements to the State observation network are shown by Table 2. 19. Improved Laboratorv Facilities. GWSIB will establish Level II laboratories at Balasore, Berhampur, Bolangir and Sampalpur and a Level II+ laboratory at Bhubaneswar. All five laboratories will be provided with new buildings. The CGWB Regional Office laboratory will be upgraded to Level II+. Details of equipment to be provided and the analyses to be performed by each type of facility are discussed in Annex 5. Hydrometeorologv 20. Improvements to Observation Network. The project would support installation of 75 standard rain gauges (SRGs), 15 autographic rain gauges (ARGs) and nine FCSs at the new and existing river gauging sites (para 16). C. Improvements to Data Manazement and Communication Systems Upgrading of Data Management Systems 21. General. Separate state data centers would be established for surface water and for groundwater. The surface water data center would be within the jurisdiction of the CE (HP) and it would be located in Bhubaneswar. The state groundwater data center would be a unit within GWSIB located in Bhubaneswar (GWSIB would be made a free-standing line organization in the DRD - para 37). The CWC's stream gauging and hydrometeorological observation networks in Orissa are managed by a Division located in Bhubaneswar. The CGWB Regional Office in Bhubaneswar would establish a data center for information collected from its observation network. The data management systems of the four agencies would be fully computerized with software designed so that the data bases could be interactive. Reference should be made to Annex 7 for more detailed discussion of data management and data transfer systems.
 230 Annex 24 Page 4 22. Checking and Entry of Historical Data into Computer Storage. This section refers mainly to riverflow data collected by the Hydrology Directorate. Most of this data is now on paper files. Although much of the data may be of doubtful quality, it must be recognized that it is, at present, all that is available. Therefore, these existing data series must be stored for use until such time that a long series of higher validity becomes available. Nevertheless, some validation of the data must be made to remove obviously anomalous-observations before data are entered into computer storage or, alternatively, a computer routine could be used to recognize possible anomalies after the data are entered. It is evident that this exercise will be very subjective and will require care in application. The next opportunity to review the historical data will be offered when a validated data series is developed through project activities at a site where a secure rating curve can be derived. If comparison of the rating curve with historical stage/discharge measurements reveals a 'systematic error' in the discharge measurements, it may then be possible to 'correct' the data series for the site. 23. State Surface Water Data Management -System. The data collected from the WRD's gauging stations are first accumulated in the Sub-divisional Offices of the Hydrology Divisions after collection from the sites by the concerned Section Offices. The three Divisional Offices and 10 Sub-divisional Offices would be provided with computer package type D comprising: two personal computers (486 sx) and two ink-jet printers, plus UPSs, associated office fumiture and an air conditioner, together with surface water data system and general purpose software. Data will be verified and entered into computer storage at the Subdivision. Transfer of data to the Divisions and to the surface water data center will be by a dial-up NICNET connection or by floppy disk. The surface water quality laboratory will be provided with computer package type D with water quality data system and general purpose software. Transfer of data from the laboratory to the SW data center will be by floppy disk. The state SW data center will be provided with a computer package type A comprising: file server (486dx2, EISA), eight personal computers (486dx2), two laser printers, 8 dot matrix printers, plotter and digitizer, together with 9 UPSs, 6 air conditioners, a fax machine, a photocopier and office furniture (see item 2.31, Annex 2, Table 2). Software provided will include: the surface water and water quality data systems; an appropriate hydrological package; a general purpose package; and a network package. 24. State Groundwater Data Management System. A type B computer facility with accessories and software for the GW and water quality data systems, a hydrogeological package, a general purpose package, and a network package will be provided to establish a State groundwater data center in Bhubaneswar. In addition type D computer facilities plus accessories and software for the GW data system and general purposes will be provided for each of the existing seven field Divisions and a new Division to be formed (para 37), and type D facilities with water quality data system and general purpose software will be provided in each of the five laboratories. Transfer of data from the field Divisions and from the laboratoties to the data center will be by a dial-up NICNET connection or by floppy disk. 25. CWC Divisional Office Data Management System. The CWC Divisional Office in Bhubaneswar will be provided with a computer package type D together with surface water and water quality data systems and a general purpose software package. The Divisional Office will be provided with a dial-up NICNET connection for communication with its controlling Circle and Regional Offices. 26. CGWB Regional Office Data Management System. The CGWB Regional Office in Bhubaneswar will be provided with a computer package type B in order to establish a data center for the data collected from its network. The software packages to be provided include the groundwater and water quality data systems, an appropriate hydrogeological package, and a general purpose package. The Regional Office laboratory will be provided with a computer package type D together with water quality data system and general purpose software. Data will be transferred from the laboratory to the Regional Office data bank by floppy disk. 27. Communication Systems between Data Banks. The data banks established in WRD and in the CWC Regional Office in Hyderabad for surface water data must be interactive and the communication
 231 Annex 24 Page 5 system provided must allow each entity access on a 'read only' basis. Similarly the data banks established for groundwater data in GWSIB and the CGWB Regional Office must be directly interactive through a communication system allowing unrestricted access. All these data centers will be provided with dedicated telephone land line connections with their local NICNET ground station to achieve the necessary communication linkages. 28. It will be necessary to transfer data collected by the WRD and CWC Regional Office surface water data centers to CWC's national data center in New Delhi. It will also be necessary to transfer groundwater data from the GWSIB and CGWB Regional Office data centers to CGWB's national data center in Faridabad. NICNET ground stations will be provided by the project for the central surface water data bank in CWC headquarters and for the central groundwater data bank in CGWB headquarters. The dedicated land line connections to NICNET provided for the state and regional office data centers will allow communication with the national data centers. D. Improvements to Reservoir Instrumentation and Management Reservoir Instrumentation 29. WRD will undertake a study to check the gate ratings for a number of existing reservoirs. This work would be carried out using physical modelling of the gates at the WRD's Engineering Research Laboratory in collaboration with CWPRS. A second WRD study relates to measurement of reservoir releases through the undersluice gates of Hirakud dam. This will involve installation of a number of gauging stations on the downstream canals and river. The data collected could provide information on existing gate leakage and would also provide a means of checking the assumed ratings of outlet gates. Lump sum provision of Rs. 3.5 million is made for the studies. Reservoir Sedimentation Surveys 30. WRD has proposed a program of sedimentation surveys for the existing 35 major and medium reservoirs. The project would provide a package of specialized equipment for this purpose comprising: 25 ft/40 HP boat and trailer; satellite trisponder position system; distomat electronic measurer; echotrac echosounder; general survey equipment; walkie talkie radio sets; digital planimeters; and sediment sampling and analysis sets. The survey package will include one jeep and one lorry. One type D computer package will be provided for calculation and graphics. E. Monitoring of Return Flows 31. The project would support experimental work for monitoring of return flows in the Chaukinallah area. The study involves detailed monitoring of the hydrological regime of the command area. The data requirements include rainfall and other meteorological parameters, time series of irrigation diversions, observed return flows which would be measured at specially installed gauging stations downstream the command area, and groundwater levels and abstractions. A mathematical model capable of describing the hydrological regime of the command area may be developed. A lump sum provision of Rs. 1.0 million is made for this study. F. Improvements to Real-Time Water Resources Management 32. Improved Telemetry on Brahmani River. The Brahmani delta in Orissa is ravaged by floods almost every year. The flooding is occasionally amplified by flood water from the Baitarani river, which is linked to the Brahmani delta. The Rengali dam controls about two thirds of the Brahmani catchment area. Releases from the dam are presently decided only on the basis of conditions at the dam and CWC predictions of inflow, based on gauge to gauge correlations and using data of one upstream real-time station. To enable more efficient management of Rengali reservoir, and to provide better information for flood forecasting on the Brahmani delta, the project will support provision of additional telemetering equipment in the Brahmani basin in two phases:
 232 Annex 24 Page 6 (a) installation of ten telemetering stations in the basin in Orissa is expected to provide a lead time of about 24 hours for the inflow forecasts to the reservoir and the delta. The cost of the telemetry system is estimated at about Rs.8.0 million; and (b) Phase II will extend the telemetering system to include the upper catchment of the Brahmani river in Bihar in order to provide a longer forecast lead time. This extension has been estimated to cost about Rs.6.7 million. 33. Flood Forecasting Study for the Brahmani River. Development of a real-time flood forecasting system for the Brahmani river is to be undertaken as a study under the HP. The study will utilize all historical rainfall and flow data from State and CWC stations and other sources in the Brahmani catchment. Catchment modelling techniques will be used to develop a validated flood forecasting system for the basin. The results of the study would be used to define the locations for the telemetering stations to be installed in the Brahmani basin (para 32). A provision of about Rs. 10 million is made for procurement of a suitable flood forecasting model and for specialist consultancy services on flood forecasting. G. Institutional Strengthening Genereal 34. Institutional performance needs to be strengthened for data collection, validation, storage and dissemination. Appropriate skills will have to be developed to operate the computing and laboratory facilities provided under the project and to maintain the improved hydrometric networks. A high level of inter-agency coordination will be required for development of computerized data banks which are inter-active and accessible between data centers and can be accessed by legitimate public and private entities. 35. The project would finance incremental project staff and other inputs to support new institutional initiatives intended to implement the project and to ensure sustainability into the future. The latter would include office buildings, equipment and services; consultant services; project specific staff training; and vehicles and their operational costs. Support for selection of specialized equipment and of computing facilities and software, and for training of state agency staff will be provided, as appropriate, by CWC, CGWB, NIH, CWPRS, IMD and the retained consultants of the project. Proposed Organizational Setup 36. Surface Water. Under the proposed Orissa Water Resources Consolidation Project, a Water Planning Organization (WPO) is being established in WRD under a CE. The WPO will be responsible for the tasks of River Basin Planning. The GOO has agreed to create a post of CE exclusively for HP for collection and management of all surface water data. A Director (Hydrometry) of SE rank will be responsible for surface water data collection and management. He will be assisted by three Deputy Directors of EE rank which will command river gauging Divisions, based in Cuttack, Balasore and Berhampur. A Director will also be responsible for the running of the State water data center. He will be assisted by three Deputy Directors of EE rank in charge of Divisions responsible for: (a) water quality and reservoir sedimentation surveys; (b) coordination and training; and (c) computing (data processing). The CE (WPO) will act as Member- Secretary of the Orissa Water Resources Board (OWRB) which is being created to develop and coordinate the State's long-term water policy and planning. The CE (HP) will also be a Memeber of the OWRB. An organization chart are shown by Figure 1. 37. Groundwater. It is proposed to delink GWSIB from the OLIC and make it a free-standing line organization within the Ministry of Rural Development. It will continue with its basic functions
 Annex 24 233 Page 7 of groundwater data collection and management and hydrogeological investigation. The basic structure of GWSIB will not change, but a unit of about division strength will be created for the data center, an additional field hydrogeological Division will be created, and the laboratories will be strengthened. An organization chart is shown by Figure 2. 38. Office Buildings and Equipment - State Agencies. The State surface water data center will be in the headquarters of the project in Bhubaneswar. The land for a new building for the HP has already been allocated. A provision of some Rs. 1 5.8million is made for new office buildings and staff accommodation. The cost of new and improved office buildings for the GWSIB will be bome by the project. A provision of about Rs.6.5 million is made for buildings for a new headquarters office, for computer facilities and for staff quarters. The project will provide office furnishings and training and other related equipment at a cost of about Rs.3.9 million for surface water hydrology activities and Rs. 1.31 million for groundwater hydrology activities. 39. Computers for Administration and Management. As noted (paras 23, 24), computing facilities for water data management systems will be provided in the water data centers, and various offices and laboratories of the Hydrology Directorates of the HP and of GWSIB. The computers in each of these offices will be provided with a general purpose software package, primarily for administration purposes. 40. Vehicles. The SW data collection and management activities under HP would require 19 vehicles as follows: 11 jeeps for hydrometry, one jeep attached to the laboratory, three cars for the CE (HP), Director (hydrometry) and the Director SW data center respectively; one minibus to be used for training activities; and one jeep and one lorry for reservoir sedimentation surveys. The GWSIB would be provided with a total of 28 jeeps for field operations and five jeeps to be attached to the laboratories. Training (Annex 10) 41. Surface Water Training Activities. The following will be the main subjects of training under the project: (a) training of stream gauging staff and junior supervisory staff in the technology of hydrometry and maintenance of instruments and ancillary equipment; (b) training of field level staff in sampling technology for sediment observations and in sediment analyses; (c) training of field staff in water quality sampling and on-site water quality analyses; (d) training of junior professional staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized laboratory equipment; and (e) training of professionals in the state surface water data center, in the field hydrology Divisions and Subdivisions and in the laboratories in the use of computers for hydrological data processing and for other software applications. Essentially all this training will be carried out in-house within the Hydrology Directorate through appropriate training courses, and on-the-job training. In order to implement in-house training courses, it will be necessary to train selected staff from the Directorate to be trainers. The training of trainers would be implemented with the assistance of NIH and CWC. Consultant services would be retained under the project to provide oversight and advice on the design, context and implementation of these training activities. 42. Additional to the above described training which relates to basic data collection and data management systems, senior professional staff of the Hydrology Directorate will be provided with training in analytical hydrology and advanced computer software applications through training courses run by NIH in Roorkee and post-graduate training in Indian universities. Study tours in India and abroad will be provided to observe appropriate hydrometric and data management systems. Senior professionals from the laboratories will also be provided with advanced training. 43. Hydrometeorological Observation Training. A hydrometeorological observation network to be maintained by the Hydrology Directorate would be established under the project. This will involve training of observers in the proper performance of their duties, including maintenance of instruments. The training of observers will be provided by IMD at its Calcutta Training Center.

The main subjects of groundwater training under the project will be: (a) training of GSWIB field staff in manual water level observations, water quality sampling, use of field measuring equipment (biaxial electric tapes, EC meters, pH meters, etc.), and servicing of digital water level recorders; (b) training of the junior professional staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized laboratory equipment; and (c) training of professionals in the state groundwater data center, in the field Divisions and in the laboratories in the use of computer software for hydrological data processing and other software applications. This training will be provided through the National Groundwater Training Institute to be established by CGWB in Raipur, with junior technical staff trained through courses run using WALMI facilities. The suppliers of digital water level recorders will be required to provide training on servicing and maintenance of the equipment. Retained consultants will provide oversight and advice for the training programs. 45. The above training all relates to basic data collection and data management systems. In addition, senior professional staff of GSWIB will be provided with training in advanced hydrogeological analysis techniques, including computer modelling, through training courses run by NIH in Roorkee and post-graduate training in Indian universities. Study tours in India and abroad will oe provided to observe appropriate groundwater monitoring networks and data management systems. Senior professional staff from the laboratories will also be provided with advanced training. 46. Training Cost Estimates. The establishment of a new Hydrology Unit in the HP will mainly involve redeployment of existing staff. However, some specialized professional posts (chemists, experienced computer specialists) and staffing of new stream and rain gauging sites will have to filled by new r ecruitment. The estimated incremental costs of salaries and allowances under the Hydrology Unit total about Rs.30.4 million, equivalent to about Rs.5. 1 million/yr over the life of the project. 48. The existing staff for GWSIB will be adequate to implement most of the state groundwater programs. but newly recruited staff will be required for some specialist posts. The incremental costs of staffing and allowances for the groundwater activities under the project are estimated to total about Rs. 12.0 million, averaging about Rs.2.0 million/yr over the life of the project. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies 49. A basic concept of the project is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a service to the public, and thus that all legitimate users of the data should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, the publication of data summaries in the form of year books would suffice. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data which could be provided as printouts or on floppy disks. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 50. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to the data bases for legitimate private entities might be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the State. This would
 235> Annex 24 Page 9 give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the form of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological service. H. Procurement 5 1. General. The procurement arrangements for the project are described in paras 4.03-4.07 and detailed in Annex 13b. All procurement would follow the standard procurement documentation approved by the World Bank for works, goods and services. 52. Works. The works to be implemented by the Hydrology Directorate consist of buildings and small structures for hydrometric and hydrometeorological stations. These will be implemented by LCB contracts according to Bank guidelines or by force account, as appropriate. The major works element under GWSIB will be construction of observation tubewells, most of which will be procured by LCB contracts with local drilling companies, but the wells with more difficult designs will be constructed with agency's own drilling rigs under force account. 53. Goods. Implementation of the project will involve procurement of large quantities of specialized hydrometric equipment, some specialized survey and laboratory equipment, and computer hardware and software. These items will be procured by ICB as described in para 4.04 of the SAR. The office equipment will be procured by LCB or prudent shopping procedures. The vehicles for the first year will be procured from the manufacturers by prudent shopping according to Government standard rate contracts. Subsequent vehicle procurement will be by ICB or prudent shopping, according to the size of the contract package. 54. Services. Consultant services will be procured by Central Government according to Bank guidelines for foreign and local consultants. NICNET services will be provided according to negotiated charges and fees arranged by Central Government. All other services will be provided by the concerned agencies through force account procedures. I. Project Coordination. Monitoring and Evaluation and Review 55. Project Coordination. A small Project Coordination Group will be established in the State to cooredinate project activities implemented by the Hydrology Directorate of WPO and by the GWSIB (SAR, paras 5.18, 5.20). An important function of the group will be liaison within the central and local offices of CWC, CGWB and IMD and with other agencies (NIH, CWPRS) with project functions in the State. The Project Coordination Group will also have the responsibility for project monitoring and evaluation and project reviews described below. 56. Monitoring and Evaluation. The monitoring and evaluation of this structurally complex project in Orissa will be carried out by the State Project Coordination Group (para 54). The exercise will cover both project implementation progress and the performance of the data collection and management systems developed. The results of monitoring and evaluation will be reported in semi- annual progress reports and form a basis for the annual implementation reviews (para 57). 57. Project Annual Reviews. Semi-annual progress reports will be prepared for the state by the State Project Coordination Group and submitted to the Central Project Coordinating Secretariat for inclusion in the project semi-annual progress reports. An annual implementation review of the project will be undertakenunder the guidance of the Central Coordinating Committee with the Bank not later than December 31 each year. The annual review arrangement will provide the flexibility requi-ed to amend the state program for the following fiscal year to reflect performance in the past year, and to incorporate any lessons leamed into the future program. The State Coordinating Group will have responsibility for presentation of information on the performance of Orissa's part of the program for the annual implementation review.
