 243 Annex 25 Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Programs in Tamil Nadu Background 1. The State of Tamil Nadu, lying on the south-eastern coast of India, has a land area of 130,210 km2 and a population of about 56 million in 1989. The climate is generally hot and humid. Precipitation is caused mainly by the northeast monsoon during October-December. The southwest monsoon is also active and the state receives significant rainfall from June to September. Some rainfall occurs in March to May due to thunderstorm activities. The Cauvery is the largest river system in the state, but there are numerous smaller systems. 2. Section A of this Annex describes existing systems of hydrological data observations and management. Section B summarizes proposed upgrading of data collection system. Section C describes the proposed upgrading of data management through the establishment of interactive data banks and inter-bank communication system. Sector D summarizes proposed improvements in reservoir instrumentation and management. Section E describes improvements to monitoring of return flows from selected irrigation schemes; Section F covers institutional strengthening activities; Section G refers to procurement procedures. Section H summarizes arrangements for project peiformance monitoring and evaluation, and for the project review process. Detailed cost estimates for state agency activities are shown by Table 1. A. Existing Systems for Hydrological Observations and Data Management Surface Water Hydrology 3. Organizational Setup. Under the proposed World Bank funded Tamil Nadu Water Resources Consolidation Project (WRCP), the existing Public Works Department (PWD) is to be split into two departments, namely the Water Resources Department (WRD) and the Buildings Department. The surface water and groundwater data collection and processing will be the responsibility of a unit under a CE within the WRD. At present, there is only one Division with two Sub-Divisions in charge of river gauging and data collection. The professional and non-professional staff engaged in surface water hydrology totals about 80 and the annual budget provision for the Hydrology Division during 1993-94 was about Rs. 3.0 million. 4. River Gauging Stations. The Hydrology Division of PWD operates 54 gauging stations of which 12 are located in the Cauvery basin. Flows are also being measured by the PWD at some of the existing anicuts and reservoirs. The CWC operates 20 gauging stations in various basins as follows: Cauvery (8), Palar and Ponniar (3 each), Vaigai (2) and Barthpuzha, Cheyyar, Vellar and Vaippar (1 each). Sedimentation studies have been carried out by PWD in 7 reservoirs in the State with studies in progress in a further 11 reservoirs. Sediment sampling is not being carried out at present by PWD, but CWC collects data at eight of its existing observation stations. The CWC collects water samples for quality analyses from eight of its gauging stations. 5. Laboratory Facilities. The PWD does not have a regular surface water quality monitoring program. The water quality data are only collected for the purpose of project design, and the interest of PWD lies primarily in the suitability of water for irrigation. The CWC has a laboratory facility in Tanil Nadu at its Coimbatore Divisional Office.
 244 Annex 25 Page 2 6. Data Processing and Management. The data collected in the field are processed manually at Sub-Divisional offices and kept in registers in the Divisional, Circle or CE offices. The transmission of data is done by messenger or by post. Tamil Nadu's Institute of Water Studies (IWS) also acts as a repository for river flow and meteorological data. Computers are available at IWS which has started computerized processing and storage of data. Groundwater Hydrology 7. Organizational Setup. The Ground Water Wing (GWW) of the PWD, headed by a CE with a headquarter in Madras, is the organization responsible for all aspects of groundwater hydrology. It comprises three Circles with headquarters in Madras, Thanjavur and Madurai. The Circles run a total of ten Divisions and there are 37 Engineering Subdivisions and 19 Geological Subdivisions. The GWW has more than 400 professional staff. The Central Ground Water Board (CGWB) Regional Office in Hyderabad has a Unit Office in Madras (which will be upgraded to a Regional Office) with responsibilities for the geographical area of Tamil Nadu. 8. Groundwater Monitoring Networks. The GWW monitors a network of about 2,500 observation wells, most of which tap the phreatic aquifer systems. There are 102 tubewells equipped with automatic water level recorders in the network. The remaining open wells have their water levels measured manually in the first week of each month. Water samples are taken for chemical analyses from all open wells twice each year, immediately prior to and after monsoon season. Two other State government agencies monitor groundwater levels. The Water Supply and Drainage Authority (in the Department of Health) has established a network of 300 tubewells for monitoring water levels, and these are measured pre- and post-monsoon. The Madras Metropolitan Development Authority monitors levels in about 60 open wells in the city by weekly manual measurements. 9. The CGWB Unit Office in Madras maintains a network of 834 observation wells of which 685 are open wells in the phreatic aquifer systems and 149 are tubewells. Water levels are measured manually in the entire network during fixed ten-day periods four times each year (January, May, August and November). Water samples are taken from open wells for chemical analysis in May each year. 10. Laboratory Facilitie. The GWW has established laboratories in its Regional Offices in Madras, Thanjavur and Madurai. All GWW laboratories are intended to carry out the standard chemical analyses associated with assessment of water quality for irrigation. They together carry out about 9,000 sample analyses each year. The CGWB unit office has no laboratory facility in the State and the samples collected are analyzed in the laboratory of the Regional Office in Hyderabad. 11. Data_Processing andManagement. The GWW database is presently on files which are managed manually. There are no computers in the Circle or Divisional Offices. The CGWB Unit Office shares a PC with the CGWB Drilling Division in Madras which is located in the same building. The computerized data is normally transferred to the Hyderabad Regional Office as a file print-out, but a staff member from the Regional Office visits Madras from time to time to lift information from the computer on floppy disk. Hydrometeorology 12. Qrganizational Setu. As in other states of India, several state agencies in Tamil Nadu maintain networks of rainfall and climate stations, including the PWD and the Departments of Revenue, Railways, Forest and Agriculture. In addition, the India Meteorological Department ([MD) has its own network of rainfall and climate stations. The CWC has no rainfall or climatic stations in Tamil Nadu.
 245 Annex 25 Page 3 13. Hvdrometeorological Networks, The State network (other than PWD) comprises 619 standard rain gauges (SRG), 29 autographic rain gauges (ARG) and 17 full climatic stations (FCS). The PWD operates 330 SRG, 151 ARG and 13 FCS. The IMD maintains 15 SRG, 25 ARG and 17 FCSs. 14. Data Processing and Man.agement. Computers are not used for routine processing and management of the rainfall and climatic data collected by PWD and other state agencies in Tamil Nadu. The IMD's data center in Pune receives data from 387 rainfall stations in Tamil Nadu, and this information is stored by computers. B. Improvements to Hydrological Observations Systems Surface Water Hydrology 15. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastrupture. The upgraded WRD network will consist of 120 gauging stations of various types while the CWC network will remain at 20 stations. In addition to river flow data, sediment samples will be collected at 40 WRD stations and water quality sarnples will be taken at 35 stations. Details of the objectives of the upgrading of data collection infrastructure are discussed in Annex 3. 16. The proposed improvements to WRD's gauging network include: (a) establishment or upgrading of 120 gauging stations of which 100 stations would be equipped with autographic water level recorders and 20 with staff gauges; (b) provision of four propeller-type and 60 cup-type current meter packages including echo sounders and other ancillary equipments; (c) provision of 60 bridge outfits, five cableways outfits (fitted with winch and cradle), and 15 standard cableways, and 12 boats with engines; (d) provision of ten sediment sampling packages for collecting sediment data at 40 stations; (e) construction of 15 new silt analysis laboratories at selected gauging sites and provision of silt analysis equipment; and (f) construction of 41 site equipment stores. 17. Laboratory Facilities. Surface water and groundwater quality samples will be analyzed at four shared chemical laboratories to be located at Madras, Madurai, Tiruchi and Pollachi. (The existing GWW groundwater laboratory at Thanjavur will be shifted to Tiruchi.) The facility at Madras would be upgraded to Level II+ standard. The Madurai, Tiruchi and Pollachi facilities would be of Level II standard. New buildings will be provided for the laboratories at Madras and Pollachi and buildings will be upgraded from the Madurai and Tiruchi facilities. In addition, the project would construct and equip 15 level I laboratories at selected river gauging station sites. Details of the equipment to be provided and the analyses to be carried out by each type of laboratory are discussed in Annex 5. Ground Water Hydrology 18. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The existing GWW network of observation wells will increase from 2,500 locations that are monitored at present to 2,583 locations after completion of the project. The project will provide 773 purpose-built observation wells. The improved network will comprise 603 tubewells equipped with digital water level recorders, 102 tubewells equipped with float type AWLR, 320 tubewells which will be manually measured, and 1,558 open wells which will be manually measured. The CGWB Regional Office observation network will increase from the present 835 wells to 903 after completion of the project. The network will include 318 new and existing tubewells equipped with digital water level recorders, 235 tubewells which will be manually measured, and 350 open wells which will be manually measured.
 246 Annex 25 Page 4 Details of the improvements to be provided to the State network are given in Table 1. Reference should be made Annex 4 for more detailed discussion of groundwater network improvements. 19. Laboratory Facilities. Analysis of groundwater samples will be made at a Level H+ facility in Madras and at Level II laboratories in Madurai, Tiruchi and Pollachi. The laboratories will serve for monitoring both surface water and groundwater as described in para 17. The CGWB Regional Office to be created in Madras with responsibility for Tamnil Nadu will be provided with a Level II+ laboratory. Hydrometeoroloyg 20. Improvements to Observation Network. The existing PWD network in Tamil Nadu will be augmented by installation of 42 ARGs, 20 FCSs and three automatic weather stations (AWS). A budget provision is made for replacements and spare parts for existing and new equipment. The CWC will establish three ARG stations and five FCSs. C. Improvements to Data Management and Communication System {Watr DMa Centers 21. Separate state data centers for surface water and for groundwater would be established within the water data management unit of WRD. The CGWB's new Regional Office in Madras would establish a data center for information collected from its observation network in Tamil Nadu. The CWC's Regional Office in Coimbatore would also establish a surface water data center. The data management systems would be fully computerized with software designed so that the data bases can be interactive. Checking and Entry of Historical Data into Computer Storage 22. This section refers mainly to surface water flow data collected by the PWD which is now on paper files. Although at least part of this data may be of doubtful quality, it must be recognized that it is, at present, all that is available. Therefore, these existing data series must be stored for use until such time that a long series of higher validity becomes available. Nevertheless, some validation of the data must be made to remove obviously anomalous observations before data are entered into computer storage. It is evident that this exercise will be very subjective and will require care in application. The next opportunity to review the historical data will be offered when a validated data series is developed through project activities at a stable site where a secure rating curve can be derived. If comparison of the rating curve with historical stage/discharge measurements reveals a systematic error, it may then be possible to correct the data series for the site. The PWD has an ongoing program of sedimentation surveys of some 62 existing major and medium reservoirs and tanks. Surveys of 12 reservoirs have been completed and of further 11 surveys are in progress. Lack of appropriate equipment and funds has been a major constraint in completing the surveys. The Institute of Hydraulics and Hydrology, Poondi, which comes under CE Design and Construction, carries out the survey work. The project will provide a package of reservoir surveying equipment comprising: 25 ft/40 HP boat with trailer; satellite trisponder position system; distomat electronic measurer; echotrac echo sounder; general survey equipment; walkie talkie radio sets; digital planimeters; and sediment sampling and analysis equipment. A type D computer package will be provided for calculations and graphics. The set will include one lorry and one jeep. The surveys will be repeated at intervals of about five years. Reservoir Instrumentation 30. Under HP, autographic water level recorders will be installed on 150 existing reservoirs and tanks. Discharge relationships for some "unconventional anicuts", will be determined by hydraulic studies at a cost of about Rs.5.0 million. E. Monitoring of Return Flows 31. In common with other states, Tamil Nadu faces the problem of assessing return flows from irrigated command areas. Pilot studies would be carried out on selected irrigation command areas. This study proposal needs detailed development and, pending this, a lump sum provision of Rs. 5.0 million has been made in the project cost estimates. F. Real-Time Water Resources Management Improved Flood Forecasting 32. The Tambraparani river system experiences floods, usually during the north-east monsoon from October to December. The latest major flood in 1992 affected some 500,000 people and caused severe damage to the area. The time of concentration of the flood is approximately 24 hours. A communication system for the basin will be provided under the project, consisting of 16 VHF radio sets. In addition, a consultancy input of nine person months will be provided for training in catchment modelling. G. Institutional Strengthening General 33. The project would finance incremental project staff and other inputs to support new institutional initiatives intended to implement the project and to ensure its sustainability into the future. Surface water data collection will be the responsibility of a circle comprising four field divisions, headed by an SE. The groundwater data collection unit in WRD will comprise the existing three groundwater Circles, each headed by an SE, and they will be responsible for field operations and control of the ten field Divisions. A Chief Chemist at the Madras laboratory will control the laboratories at Madurai, Tiruchi and Pollachi. An SE in Madras will manage the separate surface water and groundwater data centers. The surface water data collection activities would require a total of 25 vehicles as follows: 20 jeeps for supervision of WRD river gauging stations, four jeeps to be attached to the laboratories, and one minibus to be used for training activities. The package of reservoir sedimentation survey equipment would include one jeep and one lorry (para 29). The groundwater data collection activities would require 25 jeeps for field operations and four jeeps for the laboratories. Two saloon cars will be provided for use by the CE (Hydrology) and the SE in-charge of the data centers. Training - State Agency (Annex 11) 38. Surface Water Training Activities. The following will be the main subjects of training under the project: (a) training of stream gauging staff and junior supervisory staff in the technology of hydrometry and maintenance of instruments and ancillary equipment; (b) training of field level staff in sampling technology for sediment sampling and in sediment analyses; (c) training in water sampling and on-site analyses; (d) training of junior profession staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized laboratory equipment; and (e) training of professional staff in the state surface water data center, in the field Hydrology Divisions and Subdivisions and in the laboratories in the use of computers for hydrological data processing and for other software applications. Essentially, all this training will be carried out in-house within WRD through appropriate training courses (some using WALMI facilities), and on-the-job training. However, in order to implement in-house training courses, it will be necessary to train selected staff from WRD to be trainers, and this training of trainers will be implemented with the assistance of NIH and CWC. Additional to the above training which relates to basic data collection and data management systems, senior professional staff of the surface water data center will be provided with training in analytical hydrology and advanced computer software applications through training courses run by NIH in Roorkee and post-graduate training in Indian universities. Senior staff of the laboratories will be provided with training in interpretation of water quality data. Study tours abroad will be provided to observe appropriate hydrometric, water quality monitoring and data management systems. 40. Hydrometeorological Observation Training. Training of supervisors and advanced training in meteorology will be provided by IMD's training facility in Pune. 41. Groundwater Training Activities. The main subjects of groundwater training under the project will be: (a) training of field staff in manual water level observations, water quality sampling, use of field measuring equipment (biaxial electric tapes, EC meters, pH meters), and servicing of digital water level recorders; (b) training of junior technical staff in the laboratories in the use of advanced equipment; and (c) training of professionals in the state groundwater data center and in the field offices in the use of computer software for hydrological processing and other software applications. This training will be provided through the National Groundwater Training Institute to be established by CGWB in Raipur, with junior technical staff trained through courses run using WALMI facilities. The senior staff of the laboratories will receive advanced training in interpretation of groundwater quality data. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies 45. A basic concept of the project is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a service to the public at large. Thus, all legitimate users of the data should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, the publication of data summaries in the form of year books would suffice. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data, and this could be provided as printouts or on floppy disks. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 46. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to the data bases for legitimate private entities might be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the state. This would give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the format of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological service.  259 Annex 26 Page I INDIA HYDROLOGY PROJECT Programs in Kerala 1. Introduction. The state of Kerala has a land area of about 38,860 km2 and the population was around 29 million in 1989. It lies on the west coast of India and at the southern end of the peninsular. Most of this elongated state is formed by the Westem Ghats with a narrow and discontinuous coastal plain fringing the Arabian Sea. Rainfall ranges from about 2,000 mm/yr adjacent to the coast to more than 4,000 mm/yr on the crest of the Ghats and averages about 3,000 mm/yr on the state area. The rainfall occurs mainly during the south-west monsoon from May to September and the north-east monsoon from October to December, but short duration storms are fairly common during the relatively dry months of January to April. Most of the state is drained westwards to the Arabian Sea by 44 relatively small river systems which originate on the uppermost slopes of the Westem Ghats. A small part of the eastward draining Cauvery basin lies within Kerala. 2. Section A of this annex describes the existing systems for hydrological data collection and data management; Section B describes the proposed improvements to the observation systems; Section C discusses the establishment of computerized data management facilities and their associated communication systems; Section D covers institutional strengthening activities; Section E refers to procurement procedures; and Section F summarizes arrangements for project performance monitoring and evaluation and for the project review process. Detailed cost estimate for the activities of the concemed state agencies are shown by Table 1. A. Existing Systems for Hvdrological Observations and Data Management Surface Water (SW) Hydrology 3. Organizational Setup. Kerala state's surface water hydrological data collection and management is carried out by a circle within the jurisdiction of the Chief Engineer (Planning, Investigation and Design) in the Irrigation Department (ID) who reports to the Secretary to the Minister of Irrigation of the Govemment of Kerala. The Hydrology Circle, with headquarters at Trissur, contains two river gauging Divisions located at Calicut and Adook, each of which control three Subdivisional offices with three section offices under each Subdivision. The CWC's surface water gauging network in Kerala is managed by the Westem Rivers Division (located at Cochin) of the Cauvery and Southern Rivers Circle (with a headquarters in Bangalore) which reports to the CE, Southern Region in Coimbatore. 4. River Gauging Stations. The Hydrology Circle of the Kerala ID operates 70 river gauging stations where stage levels are measured and discharge is estimated by slope area methodology involving float velocity measurements. Sediment load and water quality are not monitored on a routine basis. The CWC operates 19 stage/discharge stations in Kerala with sediment load measured at 16 sites and water quality monitored at 19 sites. 5. Laboratory Facilities. The surface water hydrology unit of Kerala ID does not at present monitor water quality and therefore has no laboratory facilities. The water samples collected by the Western Rivers Division of CWC are analyzed at site laboratories for parameters with unstable characteristics and in the Coimbatore Divisional laboratory for more complete analyses. 6. Data Processing and Management. Discharge measurements are made by technicians of the hydrology unit of Kerala ID with initial computations being made at site. However, unlike most other states, the gauging stations are manned only by stage observers with discharge being
 260 Annex 26 Page 2 estimated by visiting crews. Data verification is carried out at Section and Subdivision levels. Data storage is at present on paper files. Data collected from the CWC observation sites are processed and stored according to the Commission's standard procedures (Annex 15). Groundwater (GW) Hydrology 7. Organizational Setup. The State Groundwater Department (SGD) of Kerala is a free- standing organization under a Director of CE rank who reports directly to the Secretary to the Minister of Inrigation.With headquarters in Trivandrum, it comprises a Hydrogeological Circle and an Engineering Circle together with headquarters units responsible for administration and finance, and operates through multipurpose offices located in the district headquarters of all 14 districts of the state. The CGWB has a Regional Office in Trivandrum with responsibility for the Board's activities in Kerala. 8. Groundwater Monitoring Networks. The SGD has established an observation network comprising only 206 hand-dug wells tapping the phreatic aquifer systems. Water level observations are made only once each year at the end of the dry season, and samples are then also taken for water quality analyses. The existing monitoring network is inadequate in terms of both density and frequency of water level measurements. The CGWB maintains an observation network of 625 dug wells in the phreatic aquifers, 16 piezometers in sedimentary areas and ten piezometers in hard rock areas, the last tapping only the phreatic zone. There are five automatic water level recorders installed on piezometers. Otherwise, water levels are measured manually during fixed ten-day periods four times each year (January, May, August, November). Samples are taken for water quality analyses once each year at the time of the May water level measurement 9. Laboratory Facilities. The SGD now operates only one laboratory located at Trivandrum which requires upgrading in terms of both building and equipment. The CGWB Regional Office has a laboratoiy equipped to about Level II+ standard, but much of the equipment is old, of poor serviceability and requires replacement. 10. Data Processing and Management. The data collected by SGD is presently stored on paper files. The CGWB Regional Office was equipped with computer hardware and software with some peripheral in a Swedish technical assistance project which closed in 1988. But much of the equipment is now unserviceable or requiring maintenance/spares. Nevertheless, the water level and water quality data bases have been computerized. Hydrometeorology 11. Organizational Setup. In common with all the states of India, several agencies of the Kerala State government maintain networks of rainfall observation stations, and some have climatic stations. These include the Revenue Department (RD), the Department of Agriculture (DOA) and the ID. In addition, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) and the CWC maintain small networks of rainfall and climatic stations in Kerala. 12. Hydrometeorological Networks. The total number of rainfall stations in Kerala is 229. The ID maintains 82 stations equipped with standard rain gauges. The [MD operates 70 stations of which 60 have SRGs and 10 are FCSs. The CWC manages 19 stations which are partially equipped climatic stations. The remaining 87 stations are managed by other govemment agencies and some tea estates. 13. Data Processing and Management. Computers are not used for storage and management of rainfall and other climatic data collected by state agencies, apart from the selected data archived by IMD. The CWC data resides at the Cochin Divisional Office and is not computerized. The IMD computerizes the data from its own stations and approved stations of other agencies in Kerala at its
 261 Annex 26 Page 3 Trivandrum Meteorological Center, from where it is transferred to the IMD's National Data Center at Pune where it is electronically checked and then included in the national data archive. B. Proposed Improvements to Hydrological Observation Systems Surface Water (SW) Hvdrolo2v 14. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The proposed improvements to the ID Hydrology Circle river observation network include: A. Existin2 Stations 1. Provision and installation of 70 AWLRs with staff gauges; 2. Provision of 50 cup type current metering sets; 3. Provision of ten boat outfits without trailer; 4. Provision and installation of 27 cableways with winch and cradle; 5. Provision and installation of 23 cableways for use with boats; 6. Provision of ten bridge outfits; and 7. Provision of six sets of silt analysis equipment. B. New Stations 1. Construction of 24 crump weirs; 2. Provision and installation of 10 staff gauges; 3. Provision and installation of 30 AWLRs with staff gauges; 4. Provision of ten cup type current metering sets; 5. Provision of three boat outfits with trailers; 6. Provision and installation of two cableways with winch and cradle; 7. Provision and installation of eight cableways for use with boats; 8. Provision of five bridge outfits; 9. Provision of ten silt analysis laboratories with equipment; 10. Construction of 80 site equipment stores (at new and existing stations); and 11. Construction of 15 offices and quarters at new sites. 15. Improved Laboratory Facilities. The project will provide the building and the equipment to establish a Level II laboratory at the Hydrology Circle Office in Trissur. The project will also establish ten Level I laboratories at selected river gauging sites, each laboratory handling samples from about three adjacent sites. Groundwater Hydrology 16. Upgrading of Data Collection Infrastructure. The SGD network of observation will increase from 206 wells that are monitored at present to 565 locations under the project. The network will comprise 206 dug wells in the phreatic aquifer system which will be monitored for water levels at monthly intervals, 290 tubewells in the depth range 30-120m in hard rock of which 241 will be equipped with digital water level recorders, 59 tubewells in the depth range 30-200 m in sedimentary formations which will be equipped with digital water level recorders, and ten tubewells about 60 m deep in sedimentary formations which will be installed for pollution/water quality monitoring (Table 1). Thus, some 300 wells in the SGD network will be equipped with digital water level recorders. 17. The CGWB Regional Office network in Kerala will increase from 651 sites that are monitored at present to 766 sites under the project. The network will comprise 500 existing open wells which will be monitored four times each year, 26 existing tubewells of which five are equipped with automatic water level recorders and 21 are measured four times each year, 175 new tubewells in hard rock in the depth range 30-120 m of which 105 will be equipped with digital
 262 Annex 26 Page 4 water level recorders, 45 new tubewells in sedimentary formation in the depth range 30-350 m which will be equipped with digital water level recorders, and ten new tubewells of about 60 m depth which will be installed for pollution/water quality monitoring. Thus, some 150 observation sites will be equipped with digital water level recorders. Reference should be made to Annex 4 for more detailed discussion of the groundwater network improvements. 18. Improved Laboratory Facilities. The water quality monitoring workload is expected to increase substantially for the SGD, and both SGD and CGWB will place greater emphasis on pollution monitoring studies. The existing SGD laboratory at Trivandrum will be upgraded to Level II+ and provided with a new building. The regional offices to be established in Emakulam and Calicut will be provided with a laboratory building which will be equipped to Level II standard. The CGWB Regional Office laboratory will be upgraded to Level II+ standard. Details of the equipment to be provided and the analyses to be carried out by each type of laboratory facility are discussed in Annex 5. Hydrometeorology 19. Improvements to Observation Network. The Kerala ID's network will be improved by the installation of 30 SRGs, 20 ARGs and nine FCSs. A lump sum provision is made for replacement of defective and missing equipment at the existing ID observation sites. The SGD will be provided with eight FCSs to be installed at their district offices where this type of information is not available in the vicinity. C. Improvements to Data Management and Communication Systems Upgrading of Data Management Systems 20. General. Separate state data centers will be established for surface water and groundwater information with the ID hydrology unit (Figure 1) and in the SGD (Figure 2) respectively. The surface water data center will be a unit under the CE (Planning, Investigators and Design) and located in Trivandrum. The groundwater data center will be created with the headquarters of the SGD at Trivandrum. As noted (para 3), CWC's stream gauging and hydrometeorological networks in Kerala are managed by a Division based on Cochin where data will accumulate in computerized format before being transferred to the Circle Office in Bangalore and the Regional Office in Coimbatore. The CGWB Regional Office at Trivandrum will establish a groundwater data bankl for information collected by the Board in Kerala. Reference should be made to Annex 7 for detailed discussions of the data management and data transfer systems. 21. Checking and Entry of Historical Data into Computer Storage. This section refers mainly to surface water flow data collected by the hydrology unit of ID. All that data is now on paper files. Although much of the data may be of doubtful quality, it is all that is now available and it must be stored in computers for use until along series of higher validity data is available. Nevertheless, some validation must be made to remove obvious anomalies before data are entered into storage or, alternatively, a computer routine could be used to recognize and eliminate anomalies after data entry. It is evident that this process will be very subjective and will require care in application. The next opportunity to review the historical data will occur when a validated data series has been developed through project activities at stable sites where a secure rating curve can be obtained. If comparison of the historical flow data with the rating curve reveals a systematic en-or in the discharge measurements, it will then be possible to correct the site historical data series. 22. State Surface Water Manaeement System. The data collected from the gauging sites by supervisors from Section Offices then accumulates for validation at the six Subdivisional Offices. The Subdivisional Offices will be provided with computer packages Type D comprising: two personal computers (486 sx) and two dot matrix printers plus two UPSs, associated office
 263 Annex 26 Page 5 furniture and an air conditioner, together with software for the surface water data system and a general purpose package. Thus, after verification, data will be entered into computer storage at the Subdivisions. Computer packages Type D with ancillaries and software listed above will be provided for the three Divisional Offices and at the Circle Office. Transfer of data to the higher level offices and to the surface water date center in Trivandrum will be by floppy disk or by a dial- up NICNET connection. The laboratory at the Circle Office in Trissur will enter its data into the D type computing facility provided for that office, and for this purpose, it will be provided with a water quality data software package. The transfer of water quality data from the laboratory to the surface water data center will be by floppy disk or through the Circles' dial-up NICNET connection. The state surface water data center will be provided with a computer package Type B comprising: a file saver (486dx2, EISA), five personal computers (486 dx2), two laser printers, a dot matrix printer, a plotter and a digitizer, together with six UPSs, a generator, two air conditioners, a fax machine, a photocopier and office fumiture. Software provided will include: the surface water and water quality data systems, an appropriate hydrological package, a general purpose package, and a network package. 23. State Groundwater Management System. The 14 District Offices of SGD will be provided with computer packages Type D plus ancillaries and software for the groundwater data system and general purposes (para 22). Storage of data after verification will be initiated at this level. The three Regional Offices of SGD will also be provided with computer packages Type D andGW data system and general purpose software. The laboratories at Trivandrum, Calicut and Emakulam will be provided with Type D computer packages with water quality data system and general purpose software. The GW data center at Trivandrum will be provided with computer package Type B (para 22) together with software for the groundwater and water quality data systems, an appropriate hydrogeological package, a general purpose package and a network package. Transfer of data from the District Offices to the Regional Offices and to the data center, and from the laboratories to the data center will be by floppy disk or by dial-up NICNET connections. 24. CWC Divisional Office Data management System. The CWC Divisional Office at Cochin will be provided with a computer package type D together with the software for the surface water data system and general purposes. The three Subdivisions of the Cochin Division will be provided with similar type D computer packages, and data entry will be initiated at the Subdivisional level with data transfer to the Divisional Office by floppy disk. 25. CGWB Regional Office Data_Management System. The Regional Office in Trivandrum will be provided with a computer package Type B (para 22). The software packages provided will include: the groundwater and water quality data systems, an appropriate hydrogeological package, a general purpose package, and a network package. 26. IMD Data Management System. The IMD Meteorological Center in Trivandrum will be provided with a computer package type C and appropriate software to manage the rainfall and climatic data generated by the ID. Transfer of data from the surface water data center to the meteorological center will be by floppy disk. Communication System between Data Banks 27. The Kerala ID's surface water data center should be able to exchange data with CWC's Divisional Office in Cochin. This could be achieved by transfers on floppy disks. Similarly, the state groundwater data center and the CGWB Regional Office data center must be interactive through a communication system allowing unrestricted access. As both data centers will be in Trivandrum, the required level of communication could be achieved by a telephone land line through the local NIC facility. 28. It will be necessary to transfer the SW data collected in Kerala by the ID hydrology unit and
 264 Annex 26 Page 6 the CWC to the central surface water data bank to be established at the CWC Headquarters in New Delhi. Similarly, the state ground water data center and CGWB's Regional Office data center must be able to communicate with the central groundwater data banking system to be established at the CGWB Headquarters in Faridabad. NICNET ground stations will be provided for the central surface water data center in New Delhi and for the central groundwater data center in Faridabad. The Kerala ID's data banking system will be provided with a NICNET modem with dedicated land line for transfer and exchange of data with the central surface water data center. The CWC Southern Region Office in Coimbatore, which controls the Cochin Division of CWC, will also have a NICNET modem for transfer of data collected within its jurisdiction to the central surface water data center at CWC Headquarters, New Delhi. As the state groundwater data center and the CGWB Regional Office data center will be connected to NIC, Trivandrum by dedicated land line to the local NICNET ground station, and the NICNET facility will be used for transfer and exchange of data with the central groundwater data bank in CGWB Headquarters, Faridabad. D. Reservoir Sedimentation Surveys 29. Reservoir sedimentation surveys are included under the project because the work is given high priority by the concerned central and state agencies. To facilitate this work, the project would provide Kerala ID with one set of specialized equipment comprising: 25 ft/40 HP boat with trailer, a satellite trisnonder position system, a distomat electronic measurer, an echotrac echosounder, general survey equipment, walkie-talkie radio sets, digital planimeters, and sediment sampling and analysis sets. One jeep and one lorry will be provided with the equipment set. A D type computer package will be supplied for calculations and graphics. With the equipment provided, it should be possible to survey about 20 reservoirs every five years. E. FloodForecg 30. To enhance the flood forecasting capability of Kerala ID, the project will provide 17 wireless sets for transmission of real-time data from selected locations on flood-prone river systems. F. Institutional Strengthening 31. General. The institutional performance of the Kerala ID and SGD needs to be strengthened for data collection, validation, storage and dissemination. Appropriate skills have to be developed to operate the computing and laboratory facilities provided under the project, and to operate and maintain the improved hydrometric networks. A high level of inter-agency coordination will be necessary for development of computerized data banks which are inter-active and accessible between data centers and which can be accessed by other public and private entities. 32. The project would finance incremental staff and other inputs to support new institutional initiatives intended to implement the project and to ensure its sustainability into the future. The latter would include: office buildings, equipment and services; consultant services; project specific staff training; and vehicles and their operational costs. In addition, support for selection of specialized equipment, computing facilities and software selection, and for training of state agency staff will be provided, as appropriate, by CWC, CGWB, NIH, CWPRS, IMD and the retained consultants of the project. Office Buildings and Equipment and State Agencies 33. The project will finance a new headquarters for the Kerala ID surface water unit (Rs. 4.5 million) and buildings for 15 new river gauging stations. The project will also finance the costs of a headquarters building for SGD in Trivandrum, two regional offices at Calicut and Ernakulam respectively, and 18 officer quarters distributed between the above locations (Rs. 54.7 million).
 265 Annex 26 Page 7 Allowances are also made in the project budget for office equipment and furnishings for the above buildings additional to the computing facilities mentioned in paras 22 and 23. 34. Computers for Administration and Management. As noted (paras 22, 23), the computing facilities provided to the ID and GWD for data management will include a general purpose package among the software. This software is intended primarily for administration purposes. 35. Vehicles. TheSW data collection and management activities will require some 16 vehicles distributed as follows: one saloon car for the surface water data center, eight jeeps for supervision of the gauging stations, three jeeps for working with the boat outfits with trailers, one lorry and one jeep for the sedimentation survey operations, one jeep for the laboratory, and one minibus for training activities. The groundwater data collection and management activities will be provided with 21 vehicles distributed as follows: one saloon car for the groundwater data center, fourteen jeeps for the district offices, three jeeps for the regional offices, and three jeeps for the laboratories. Training 36. SW Training Activities. The objectives, procedures and management arrangements for training are discussed in Annex 10. The following will be the main subjects of training under the project: (a) training of stream gauging staff and supervisory staff in the technology of hydrometry; (b) training of field level staff in sampling technology for sediment observations and in sediment analyses and in water quality sampling and on-site analyses; (c) training of junior professional staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized equipment; and (d) training of junior professionals in the state surface water data center, the field units of the Hydrology Circle and the laboratory in the use of computers for hydrological data processing and other software applications. Much of this training will be carried out as an in-house activity of the ID through appropriate training courses and on-the-job training. In order to implement the in-house training courses, it will be necessary to select staff from the Hydrology Unit to be trained as trainers. The training of trainers will be implemented with the assistance of NIH. Consultant services retained under the project specifically for training would provide oversight and advice on the design, content and implementation of the training activities. 37. Additional to the above described training which all relates to basic data generation and data management systems, more senior professional staff of the hydrology unit will be provided with training in analytical hydrology and advanced computer software applications through training courses run by NIH and post-graduate training in Indian universities and foreign institutions. Study tours abroad will be provided to observe appropriate hydrometric and data management systems. Senior professionals from the laboratories will also be provided with advanced training in appropriate Indian and foreign institutions. 38. Hydrometeorological Observation Training. The hydrometeorological observation network maintained by the ID will be upgraded and expanded under the project and a number of FCSs will be provided to SGD (para 19). This will involve training of the observers in the proper performance of their duties, including maintenance of instruments. The ID staff involved in supervision of the networks will also require training, and some more advanced training in hydrometeorological applications relating to hydrology will be provided to more senior staff of ID's hydrology unit. The observatory staff training will be provided by IMD at its Madras Training Centre while the supervisor staff and senior staff will be trained through courses run under IMD's training establishment at Pune (Annex 19). 39. Groundwater Training Activities. The expansion of SGD's groundwater observation network, the introduction of digital water level recorder, the establishment of a computerized system for data management, and the provision of laboratory facilities will involve staff training. The main subjects of groundwater training under the project will be: (a) training of SGD field staff
 266 Annex 26 Page 8 in manual water level observation, water quality sampling, use of field measuring equipment (biaxial electri tapes, EC meters, pH meters, etc.), and servicing of digital water level recorders; (b) training of junior professional staff of the laboratories in the use of specialized laboratory equipment; and (c) training of professionals in the state groundwater data center and the regional and distrcffices in the use of computers for data processing and other software applications. This training will be provided through the National Groundwater Training Institute to be established by CGWB at Raipur, with the junior technical staff training for groundwater observations carried out using WALMI facilities. The suppliers of digital water level recorders will be required to provide training on servicing and maintenance of the equipment. 40. The above training relates to basic data collection and data management systems. In addition, senior professional staff of SGD will be provided with training in advanced hydrogeolo,gical analysis techniques, including computer modelling, and hydrochemistry through training cou=es run by NIH in Roorkee and in Indian universities and foreign institutions. Study tours abroad will be provided to observe appropriate groundwater monitoring networks and data management systems. 41. Trainiine Cost Estimates. Quantities, cost estimates and timings for training activities are shown by Tahle 1. Staff Requirements and Incremental Costs - State Agencies 42. The creation of the state surface water data center and the establishment of a laboratory for suiface water analyses will require additional professional staff. And the vehicles provided to ID will require drivers. However, the establishment for surface water activities will be provided from the existing staff or by redeployment. 43. The SGD will have to employ additional specialists for the groundwater data center and the laboratories. The creation of three Regional Offices will require some additional staff posts which will be filled by new employments, promotions or transfers. Drivers will have to be employed for the vehicles provided under the project. The estimated annual costs of salaries and allowances for incremental staff are about Rs. 2.0 million. Hydrological Services and Interaction with Data User Agencies 44. A project concept is that hydrological data collection and its management and dissemination should be regarded as a public service. Thus all legitimate data users should have clearly defined and easily acquired access to the data. Moreover, the data collected should be made available in formats that are useful to the users. In many cases, publication of data summaries and/or yearbooks would suffice. Groundwater data often requires interpretation in the form of maps and explanatory reports. Some users may require the original data, and this could be provided as a printout or on flopping disks. The possibility of payment for such services should be considered. 45. Arranging access for interested government agencies should not present difficulties. Provision of easy access to legitimate private entities could be a problem. It is proposed that a committee of interested data users should be established in the state. This would give prominence to the availability of the data, reveal the demand for the type of data required and the form of its presentation, and give direction for improvements to the hydrological service. G. Procurement 46. General. The procurement arrangements for the project are described in paras 4.03-4.07 and detailed in Annex 13b. All procurement would follow the standard procurement documentation approved by the World Bank for works, goods and services.
 lli7 Annex 26 Page 9 47. Works. The works to be implemented by ID consist of buildings and small structures for hydrological and hydrometeorological stations. These will be implemented by LCB contracts according to Bank guidelines or by force account, as appropriate. The major works element under SGD will be construction of observation tubewells, most of which will be procured by LCB contracts with local drilling companies, but the wells with more difficult designs will be constructed with agency's own drilling rigs under force account. The SGD buildings for offices and laboratories will be implemented by LCB contracts. 48. Goods. Implementation of the project will involve procurement of large quantities of specialized hydrometric equipment, some specialized survey and laboratory equipment, and computer hardware and software. These items will be procured centrally by ICB as described in para 4.04. The office equipment will be procured by LCB or by prudent shopping procedures. The vehicles will be procured for the first year by prudent shopping from the manufacturers according to Government standard rate contracts. Subsequent procurements will be by ICB procedures or prudent shopping according to the size of the contracts. 49. Services. Consultant services will be procured by Central Government according to Bank guidelines for foreign and local consultants. NICNET services will be provided according to negotiated charges and fees arranged by Central Government. All other services will be provided by the concerned agencies through force account procedures. H. Project Coordination. Monitoring and Evaluation and Review 50. Project Coordination. A small Project Coordination Group will be established in the ID, reporting to the Secretary of the department, to coordinate project activities implemented by the surface water hydrology unit and by the SGD (SAR, paras 5.18, 5.20). An important function of the group will be liaison with the central offices of CWC, CGWB and IMD and their offices in Kerala and with other agencies which are also involved in project programs in the State (NIH and CWPRS). The Project Coordination Group will also have the responsibility for project monitoring and evaluation and for the project annual reviews as described below. 51. Monitoring and Evaluation. The monitoring and evaluation of this structurally complex project in Kerala will be carried out by the State Project Coordination Group (para 50). The exercise will cover both project implementation progress and the performance of the data collection and management systems developed. The results of the monitoring and evaluation will be reported in semi-annual reports and form a basis for the annual implementation reviews (para 52). 52. Project Annual Reviews. Project Annual Reviews. Semi-annual progress reports will be prepared for the state by the State Project Coordination Group and submitted to the Central Project Coordinating Secretariat for inclusion in the project semi-annual progress reports. An annual implementation review of the project will be undertakenunder the guidance of the Central Coordinating Committee with the Bank not later than December 31 each year. The annual review arrangement will provide the flexibility required to amend the state program for the following fiscal year to reflect performance in the past year, and to incorporate any lessons learned into the future program. The State Coordinating Group will have responsibility for presentation of information on the performance of Kerala's part of the program for the annual implementation review.

doc.abstracts: The Hydrology Project will assist the Government of India (GOI) and the seven participating states to develop comprehensive, easily accessed and user friendly data bases covering all aspects of the hydrological cycle, including surface water and groundwater in terms of quantity and quality and climatic measurements, particularly of rainfall. The project supports the objectives of GOI's national water policy and the Bank's strategy for India's water sector and policy regarding water resources management. Special attention will be paid to standardization of criteria, processes and procedures for measurement of hydrological parameters and for storage and retrieval of information so that data series will be compatible and the data bases will be interactive. The project will be structured as a six-year operation and include support of: upgrading and expanding the physical infrastructure for all aspects of the collection, collation, processing and dissemination of hydrological and hydrometeorological data; provision of equipment and materials; institutional strengthening including technical assistance and training; and new buildings and incremental operating and maintenance costs.
